Lithuania is out, or soon to be. Chuvashia, however, is in. Latvia, Estonia, Karelia and Georgia are saying goodbye as fast as they prudently can. Tatarstan, Komi, Mari, Dniester and Gagauz are ready to take their places. ``Sometimes, it's hard to know where you live anymore,'' said Pyotr Gorbanenko, a legislator in Moldavia, which is simultaneously seeking independence from the Soviet Union and trying to put down two internal separatist movements. It used to be simple. In 1988, the Soviet Union had 15 republics, each with its own legislature. Scattered among them were 20 smaller ``autonomous republics,'' or homelands for various ethnic groups. The country has been fragmenting since President Mikhail S. Gorbachev loosened Moscow's grip on power and allowed aggrieved minorities to speak out. That hampers Gorbachev's plans for nationwide economic reform and getting an agreement among the republics to replace the 1924 treaty of union. It also has led to violence, most recently in Moldavia. Several regions are trying to secede, following the lead of Lithuania, which declared independence in March. In addition to the Baltic republics, there are strong independence movmements in Karelia, a district of about 140,000 people north of Leningrad that wants to join neighboring Finland; the western Ukraine, where many people want unification with Poland, and the southern republics of Armenia, Georgia and Azerbaijan. Regions that don't want to leave the Soviet Union also are pushing for sovereignty. Several regions are actually trying to become Soviet republics. Some ethnic minorities, such as Moslem Abkhazians in Georgia, want to break away from larger groups they accuse of discrimination. Others, such as the Tatar, Chuvash, Komi, Mari and Chukchi peoples in the Russian republic, seek to raise their legal status - from district to autonomous republic, or from autonomous to full-fledged republic. Their goals include political power, cultural preservation and control of natural resources. Ethnic and political friction has led repeatedly to violence in the past two years. In Moldavia last week, the regional government sent troops to clear roadblocks set up by separatists who had declared a new republic east of the Dniester River. At least four people were killed. The unrest stemmed from a combination of historical injustices, ethnic grievances and unfounded rumors, a typical mix that shows how explosive self-determination can be in a nation whose borders have changed often in the 20th century. Moldavia, which had been a Soviet republic since 1924, more than doubled in size at the start of World War II, when Stalin annexed neighboring Bessarabia from Romania under a secret protocol of his non-aggression treaty with Hitler. For the next 45 years, Soviet leaders relentlessly pursued a policy of Russification. They made Russian the official language, instead of Romanian, encouraged cultural assimiliation and sent Russians to run schools, industries and political posts. Anatol F. Plugaru, an ethnic Moldavian and former member of the republic's Communist Party Central Committee, told The Associated Press he had access in 1987 to a list of the Moldavian ``nomenklatura,'' the top government, business and law enforcement jobs controlled by the party. Although Russians made up only 15 percent of the republic's 4.3 million people, he said, they filled two-thirds of those positions. That began changing last year. Thanks to Gorbachev's reforms, competitive elections gave ethnic Moldavians a parliamentary majority, including a substantial bloc of delegates aligned with the pro-independence People's Front. The new parliament voted in August 1989 to make Romanian the official language. While the law said Moldavian citizens retained the right to speak Russian, it required all people in jobs dealing with the public, from doctors to hairdressers, to pass tests in Romanian by 1995. Protest strikes were held by Russians and Ukrainians, who are concentrated within Moldavia's prewar borders east of the Dniester. They formed Yedinstvo, a group pressing for Moldavia to remain in the Soviet Union. Plugaru claims the Russians were ``were afraid of losing their privileged positions, which they shouldn't have had to begin with.'' Ilya Trombitsky, a legislator who sides with the Russian minority, said the language law was ``a clear attempt to favor one ethnic group over another'' and caused widespread fear of Moldavian nationalism. Protests also broke out last year in the Gagauz region, a southern corner of Moldavia inhabited by about 150,000 descendents of Christian Turks who fled religious persecution in Bulgaria in the early 19th century. Yuri Roshka, a leader of the Moldavian People's Front, said Russians from the Dniester area artificially incited discontent in Gagauz. Gagauz leaders say their people were legitimately angry over the language law and lack of investment in their underdeveloped agricultural area. The conflict boiled over this fall, when the Gagauz and Dniester regions declared themselves Soviet republics and went ahead with elections for new legislatures. Plugaru says he is confident Moldavia will remain whole and gradually move toward independence after convincing Gagauz and Dniester residents they have nothing to fear. Trombitsky said he expects the Dniester area to remain part of the Soviet Union, while western Moldavia eventually reunites with Romania, possibly taking Gagauz along. ``We are all victims of history,'' he said. ``We must learn to respect each other's rights, because bloodshed is no answer.''

DOC.HEAD: Heart-Liver Transplant Pioneer Dead at 13, Transplant Will Help Others
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `Preliminary autopsy ...', to CORRECT by subbing `it' for `her death'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PG1, PG2
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones' painful journey, which ended with her sudden death at age 13 six years after her pioneering heart-liver transplant, blazed the way for other multiple transplants, doctors say. ``We've been able to provide better quality of life and longer life for many people'' because of Stormie's ordeal, Dr. Jorge Reyes, staff physician at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh, said after Stormie died there Sunday. But Stormie didn't like being under a media spotlight, acquaintances recalled. ``She wished everybody would treat her normal instead of like she had an operation, because she didn't like everybody asking her how she felt or if she was feeling OK,'' said Crystal Millikan, Stormie's best friend in her hometown of White Settlement, Texas, a Fort Worth suburb. Stormie endured organ rejection and hepatitis after her historic double transplant on Valentine's Day 1984 and a second liver transplant this February. ``She went through a lot of pain, you know, as a guinea pig and as necessity,'' her stepfather, Alan Purcell, said at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport before flying to Pittsburgh. ``The pain is over with,'' Purcell said. ``She doesn't hurt any more.'' Stormie was rushed from her home to a Texas hospital Saturday night with a sore throat and fever. She then was flown to the Pittsburgh hospital. Stormie was dehydrated when she arrived, Reyes said. Her condition didn't appear serious then, but it deteriorated rapidly, hospital spokeswoman Lynn McMahon said. Her mother at her side, Stormie went into cardiac arrest and died at 9:52 a.m. Doctors tried for more than an hour to resuscitate her. Preliminary autopsy results were inconclusive, but Reyes said that if Strmie had a flu virus, it could have caused a rapid or irregular heartbeat. Funeral arrangements were pending, Ms. McMahon said. Stormie was 6 when she became the first person to receive a transplanted heart and liver. Since then, University of Pittsburgh hospitals have performed at least 10 other transplants involving the liver and another organ. No national statistics are kept on multiple-organ transplants. Most have been performed at the university's hospitals, the only ones authorized to use FK-506, an experimental anti-rejection drug Stormie was taking. The nation knew her as a brave teen-ager, but Stormie was famous around Children's Hospital for her generosity to other patients. She once bought a book on Chinese so she could communicate with a 3-year-old patient in the toddler's language. ``She did that kind of thing all the time,'' McMahon said. ``She was just so highly regarded by other children. She went to great lengths to take the time to play with them and talk with them.'' ``With her strength, she gave strength to other children,'' Reyes said. Stormie required the multiple transplant because her own organs were harmed by familial hypercholesterolemia - blood cholesterol 10 times higher than normal. Hepatitis damaged the transplanted liver and Stormie received a second liver transplant in February. The girl returned to Children's in May after her body began rejecting the liver and again in June because of hepatitis. She was released from the hospital after a few weeks, but she and her mother, Lois ``Susie'' Purcell, stayed in the city until the infection was controlled. Doctors at the time determined Stormie had developed the same type of hepatitis that damaged her first transplanted liver, but didn't know why. Although any transplant patient is susceptible to infection because anti-rejection drugs weaken the immune system, ``I wouldn't particularly focus on the FK-506 as a specific cause,'' Reyes said. Doctors, family and friends often had marveled at Stormie's determination to recover from her many physical setbacks. ``I guess it's just hope. There's a thing in the back of your head that says, `Get up,''' Stormie once told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Observe Veterans Day Amid Fears of New War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Deletes apostrophes from Veterans Day throughout, conforming to style.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: The threat of war in the Persian Gulf shadowed Veterans Day observances from the Vietnam Veterans' Memorial in Washington to an Army post in Eastern Saudi Arabia. ``It looks like many people will be marching in next year's Veterans Day parades with a banner saying Desert Shield '90-'91,'' 2nd Lt. Benjamin Lacy, 23, of Largo, Fla., said at the Mideast post on Sunday. The human cost of any offensive against Iraq to liberate Kuwait is ``a question that's on everybody's mind,'' Lacy said. It was on people's minds here, too. It's ``just a matter of time'' until the United States is at war again, Bob Horsch of Rahway, N.J., a veteran of Army service in Vietnam, told a reporter at the Vietnam memorial Sunday. Horsch said he believes the military buildup in the Persian Gulf is the right thing to do because ``it is in the interest of the United States and other countries.'' Stephen Reuben of Lapwai, Idaho, a member of the Nez Perce tribe who also served in Vietnam, declined to say whether he believed the buildup was a good idea, but said he fears the country will go to war. ``I am afraid so, but I pray and hope we don't,'' Reuben said. Teresa Swain of Hagerstown, Md., when asked if she supported the buildup, said, ``We have to protect our interests.'' As to whether it would mean war, she said, ``I certainly hope not.'' Mrs. Swain said she has a son-in-law in the Air Force. At Arlington National Cemetery, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney placed a floral wreath at the Tomb of the Unknowns and told a crowd of about 5,500, ``Those who have been deployed to the Persian Gulf and Saudi Arabia are probably the best-trained soldiers we have ever had.'' Meanwhile, the jury selecting a design for a memorial to women who served in Vietnam, to be built adjacent to the Vietnam Veterans' Memorial, announced that it has selected two finalists instead of one winner. One of the winning designs, by sculptor Eileen Rose Barry of East Islip, Long Island, is a statue of a woman standing alone with a helmet in her hand. ``She looks like she has been to war and she is going somewhere else,'' said juror Raquel Ramati, a New York urban desgner. ``She is dignified and courageous, but she looks like she is part of the human race. She is not superwoman.'' The other finalist, by landscape architect Robert Diamond of Arlington, Mass., consists of 240 jets of water with a large white marble block at the center. The white will contrast with the black marble wall, with the names of more than 58,000 Vietnam war dead on it, that is the central feature of the Vietnam memorial. Ms. Ramati said the nine-member jury was divided. Veterans favored a representational sculpture; designers leaned toward an abstract design. Diane Carlson Evans, director of the project, said the two finalists would be asked to refine their proposals and the final design would be a collaboration of the two. The target date for dedication is 1992. At the Vietnam memorial, representatives of military and patriotic groups placed wreaths in front of the wall as a bagpiper played ``Abide With Me.'' The National Park Service estimated the crowd at 5,000. The weather was bright and sunny, with a crisp wind. The ceremonies were held on Sunday, the traditional Veterans Day, although today is the official national holiday. Veterans Day is not a holiday for the 230,000 American troops deployed in the Persian Gulf, but many remembered their fellow soldiers who fought in previous wars. Lacy said Veterans Day ``means many people before me put their life on the line. Many died, some are scarred for life. It's time to honor them.'' Forty-six soldiers have died so far in Operation Desert Shield, which was launched in response to Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: With Obit-Stormie Jones, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of the life of Stormie Jones, the world's first heart liver transplant who died Sunday at the age of 13. -Feb. 14, 1984: Her liver and heart damaged by a condition giving her abnormally high blood cholesterol, Stormie becomes the first person to receive a heart-liver transplant. She is 6. -Oct. 26, 1988: She returns to Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh for removal of an obstruction to her bile ducts. -Jan. 8, 1988: She is readmitted because of rising enzyme levels, a sign of possible organ rejection. -Nov. 3, 1989: She suffers an episode of liver rejection and begins receiving the experimental anti-rejection drug FK506. -Jan. 6, 1990: She returns to Pittsburgh with suspected hepatitis. -Feb. 20, 1990: Her liver damaged from hepatitis, she receives a second transplanted liver. She is discharged 17 days later. -May 20, 1990: The dosage of FK506 is increased after Stormie suffers a rejection episode. -June 23, 1990: Tests confirm a second case of hepatitis and doctors administer a protein-like substance to bolster Stormie's immune system. -Nov. 11, 1990: Stormie returns a final time to Children's Hospital with flu-like symptoms. She dies at 9:52 a.m. after respiratory distress and a cardiac arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Home Sought for Truman's Presidential Yacht
DOC.TEXT: The U.S.S. Williamsburg, once Harry S. Truman's official presidential yacht, is rotting near a sewage plant on the Potomac River outside Washington and faces demolition. The vandalized 243-foot-long hulk has trees growing through its deck and is covered with broken glass and empty beer bottles, The Kansas City Star reported Sunday. If no one takes the former beauty of black steel, teak trim and mirror-polished brass, it faces demolition in July 1992, the newspaper reported. Through the years the Williamsburg has had a variety of owners. It had a brief stint as a floating restaurant in New Jersey in 1969, and before that the National Science Foundation in Norfolk, Va. used it as a laboratory, the Star said. The ship became available about two weeks ago to anyone who could prove to the District of Columbia that it would be restored, said Kim Nielsen, chief of photography for the Smithsonian Institution's Freer and Sackler museums. ``People have no conscience about destroying things of historic value,'' said Nielsen, a nautical history buff. ``They want to see George Washington's teeth and Abraham Lincoln's chair. But here we have President Truman's yacht, where he spent half of his presidential career, and nobody cares.'' Nielsen is trying to find a future for the yacht and he envisions the Midwest as its brightest hope. Independence, Mo., to be more specific - Truman's home. But the idea of moving the Williamsburg to the Midwest is hopeless, local leaders and entrepreneurs say. ``It's one of those cases where the powers that be have turned their backs on it,'' said Richard Lynn, a Kansas City, Kan., riverboat operator who researched the possibilities of the investment. ``It's nothing but a rusting hulk.'' The ship weighs 2,000 tons and is 36 feet wide with a 14-foot draft. ``The depth did us in,'' Lynn said. ``We don't have that much in the river.'' The Williamsburg also isn't seaworthy and probably wouldn't fit under many river bridges. Nielsen estimated that even though the ship would be donated, the restoration would cost about $7 million - more if the ship is to ever sail again. Nielsen said to build a ship its size from scratch today would cost somewhere between $12 million and $20 million. And the Williamsburg could be eligible for federal funds if it were to be named a national landmark. Dan McGraw of Independence looked into bringing the yacht to Independence about four years ago. When he finally tracked it down, it was privately owned and scheduled to again become a floating restaurant in New Jersey. The city of Independence dropped its queries. Then Nielsen called McGraw two weeks ago to say the ship was available. But now, McGraw said, ``I don't think the city's going to get involved in it. I don't know what the city of Independence would do with it.''

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Guerrillas Launch Offensive; 40 Dead
DOC.TEXT: In their biggest offensive of the year, leftist guerrillas attacked two adjacent towns in northern Colombia and about 40 people were killed, authorities said. The army and police drove back some 1,000 members of two guerrilla groups who together attacked the towns of Taraza and Caceres in northern Colombia Saturday, the Antioquia state government said Sunday. Nine soldiers and 16 guerrillas died in the five-hour gun and mortar battle in Taraza, 250 miles north of Bogota. Eight soldiers were also wounded before the rebels were driven back into the mountains, the government said in a statement. Among the dead was the Taraza army base commander, Lt. Col. Jaime Farjardo, who fought alongside his men and became one of the highest ranking casualties of Colombia's 30-year guerrilla struggle. In Caceres, the rebels killed a police officer, destroyed the city hall and damaged the police station. The retreating guerrillas carried more than 10 dead and several wounded with them into the mountains, it said. Authorities said Saturday's attacks were carried out by the country's two active guerrilla groups - the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, and the National Liberation Army. Late Saturday, four rebels were killed in another battle between the army and the Liberation Army, according to a Defense Ministry statement. Just Thursday, the two guerrilla groups had offered to initiate peace talks with the government, and released 22 police hostages as a goodwill gesture. In a statement released Sunday, President Cesar Gaviria's administration said ``the possiblity of peace talks is being driven farther into the distance'' by the rebel attacks. About 10,000 people belong to six major rebel groups. More than 75,000 people have died in political violence associated with the guerrilla war. The April 19 Movement, or M19, became the country's first rebel group to transform itself into a political party when it laid down its arms last April. Commentaries published in the two newspapers, meanwhile, reflected divisions over how Gaviria should deal with another major problem - drug traffickers, now believed holding nine kidnapped journalists. ``President Gaviria and his government now more than ever have the opportunity to exercise their authority,'' said an editorial in El Espectador newspaper, a leading advocate of tough policy against drug traffickers. The Medellin cocaine cartel is accused of bombing El Espectador's Bogota offices last year as part of a terrorist campaign to pressure the government into calling off its anti-drug crackdown. It also allegedly murdered El Espectador's publisher, Guillermo Cano, in 1986. Juan Gomez Martinez, the publisher of Medellin's El Colombiano newspaper, offered in a letter published Sunday to allow drug traffickers to publish their denunciations of government human rights violations. The cartel claims police have tortured and slain its members since the government launched a crackdown on the cartel in August 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Bombs Case Pits Powerful Prosecutor, Bold Ponytailed Defenders
LaserPhoto AX2
DOC.TEXT: The legal showdown in the Southeastern mail bombs case will pit the man who prosecuted New York's ``Pizza Connection'' drug case against a pair of ponytailed lawyers known for defending controversial clients. Added to that mix is outspoken U.S. District Judge Richard Freeman and a crime that has held the Southeast's attention for nearly a year. Walter Leroy Moody Jr., of Rex, Ga., is accused of mailing bombs to a federal judge and a civil rights lawyer last December, killing both. Defending him are Atlanta lawyers Bruce Harvey and Michael Hauptman, both associated with the American Civil Liberties Union but acting in this case as court-appointed attorneys. Each wears a diamond earring and graying hair pulled back in a ponytail. Hauptman appeared on Geraldo Rivera's television talk show this year, discussing his marriage to Dolores French, author of ``Working: My Life as a Prostitute.'' Prosecuting the case is Assistant U.S. Attorney Louis Freeh, who handled the 1987 ``Pizza Connection'' drug case in New York. ``You've got three great lawyers,'' said Robert Fogelnest, a New York lawyer familiar with all of them. Freeh, he said, ``is as tough as they come.'' The defense lawyers are ``courageous and not afraid to take on unpopular cases.'' Moody was named in a 70-count indictment last week after an 11-month investigation of the mail bomb killings of U.S. Circuit Judge Robert Vance in Alabama and attorney Robert Robinson in Georgia. If convicted on all 70 counts, Moody could be sentenced to seven life terms plus 385 years in prison and fines of $16.9 million. No trial date has been set. In the first of a number of expected pretrial motions, Moody's lawyers last week asked that every federal judge in the United States be barred from the case, claiming no such judge could be impartial. That motion is pending. Each defense lawyer has taken several controversial cases. Among Harvey's past clients are convicted Columbus, Ga., ``stocking strangler'' Carlton Gary and Jerome Bowden, a convicted murderer whose 1986 execution continued the debate over whether capital punishment should apply to the mentally retarded. Hauptman, president of the Georgia ACLU, recently successfully challenged the state's mask law on behalf of a member of the Ku Klux Klan. The law had banned Klan members from wearing masks in public. He also has represented many capital murder defendants. Although deadly serious in the courtroom, they display a wry sense of humor outside. After seeking to bar federal judges from the case, Harvey was asked where - if the motion succeeds - the case might end up. ``Hopefully, somewhere near a beach,'' he replied. Freeh, known as low-key but extremely tough, prosecuted the 17-month-long heroin importing case dubbed the ``Pizza Connection'' because participants allegedly used pizza parlors as fronts. In that case, Salvatore Catalano, a reputed former chief of the Sicilian Mafia, was convicted and sentenced to 45 years in prison. Freeman, an outspoken judge who tightly controls his court, earlier this year criticized the FBI for leaking details of the investigation, saying Moody's right to a fair trial was risked by ``some loudmouthed agent.'' However, he may excuse himself from the trial. ``The chance of an Atlanta judge trying this case is small,'' said Atlanta attorney James K. Jenkins. ``You have a collegiality among judges in a circuit that have relationships that would make any judge look at it (excusing himself) seriously.''

DOC.HEAD: Akihito Enthroned, Leftists Launch Attacks
LaserPhotos TOK13,16,17
DOC.TEXT: Emperor Akihito ascended to the world's oldest hereditary monarchy today, the first in a legendary 2,600-year-old line of emperors to be enthroned as a national symbol rather than a living god. Leftist extremists, who consider the institution of emperor an unconstitutional relic of Japan's militarist past, attacked military bases, train stations and Shinto shrines in protest. Police counted at least 34 guerrilla attacks timed to coincide with the coronation of the late Emperor Hirohito's 56-year-old son. None appeared to cause any injuries. A record 37,000 police had been mobilized to guard the ceremonies as well as the attending dignitaries from 158 countries, including Vice President Dan Quayle and Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana. For his coronation, Akihito wore a red-brown silk kimono and hat of ancient design and sat on an elaborate lacquered throne in front of an Imperial Palace courtyard filled with attendants carrying bows and swords. He vowed to ``discharge my duties as symbol of the state and of the unity of the people'' under Japan's postwar constitution, which fundamentally restructured the monarchy. Hirohito had renounced his divine status after the war, but Akihito becomes the first of Japan's 125 emperors, including those listed only in legend, to take the throne as a mere mortal and not a priest-king. He said he would perform his role in the same spirit as his father, who ``shared joys and sorrows with the people at all times'' during a 62-year reign that encompassed both the devastation of World War II and Japan's dramatic recovery. Empress Michiko, dressed in a multicolored gown, her face painted white, sat motionless on her own throne at Akihito's side throughout the 30-minute ceremony. The ritual ended with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu standing stiffly before Akihito in a morning suit and leading the Japanese guests in three cries of ``Banzai'' - he traditional wish for long life. He led the cheers from a point level with the base of the throne, to underscore the constitution's stress on popular sovereignty. A 21-gun salute blasted from an adjacent park. The ancient, mystical enthronement rites are said to date back to 660 B.C. Akihito and Empress Michiko later left the palace grounds in an open Rolls Royce, ringed by dozens of police motorcycles and waving and smiling to cheering crowds. They had changed to formal Western clothes. Many of the estimated 110,000 people along the three-mile parade route to Akasaka Palace, the couple's home, yelled ``Banzai'' and waved national flags as the 44-car parade passed. Nearly 10,000 police lined the route. There was one shaky moment, however, when firecrackers popped as the emperor's car passed by. Police with German shepherds rushed in and arrested several people, some of whom handed out leaflets calling Hirohito a war criminal. Leftist radicals who want the imperial house abolished made themselves heard all across the capital. Police said they arrested about a dozen of the several thousand protesters who held anti-imperial rallies around Tokyo. In one park, hundreds of masked members of the ultra-leftist Chukakuha, or Middle Core Faction, chanted ``Smash the enthronement ceremony!'' One man attempted to commit hara-kiri, or traditional suicide by disembowelment, in front of the Imperial Palace but was rushed to a hospital, police said. There were no immediate details on his condition or motivation. Radicals launched projectiles at three suburban military bases and a fourth in western Tokyo, the Defense Agency reported. Police reported another attack outside the U.S. naval base at Atsugi, 24 miles southwest of Tokyo. Radicals also were accused of setting early morning fires at three Tokyo train stations that stopped traffic on two major commuter lines, police reported. Fires erupted at four Shinto shrines in Tokyo, including one less than a mile from Akihito's residence, destroying two. Japanese flags lined the main streets in the Ginza shopping district, where cars and trucks painted with rightist slogans paraded. Speakers blared ``Long live the emperor,'' as riot police stood by. But many Japanese were ignoring the ceremonies, taking advantage of the special holiday to take weekend trips and crowd golf courses and driving ranges. Long lines of people queued in front of movie theaters. One poll indicated nearly half of the Japanese were not interested in the enthronement. Akihito became emperor immediately after the death of Hirohito in January 1989, but his enthronement was delayed until after a period of mourning.

DOC.HEAD: Chad Says Its Forces Have Repelled Assault
DOC.TEXT: The government of Chad says its troops have beaten back an attack by Libyan-supported mercenaries who crossed the border from Sudan. The invaders were repelled after 24 hours of ``violent combat'' in the Tine region of eastern Chad, said a communique issued late Sunday by Chad's Embassy in Paris. Chad said the offensive was launched Saturday by the Islamic Legion, which it described as a force of 2,000 mercenaries equipped with armored vehicles and supported by Libya and Sudan. Both those countries subsequently denied any role in the fighting, saying that only Chadian dissidents were involved. The Chadian communique made no mention of casualties, but said the attackers retreated in disarray toward their base in the Sudanese province of Darfour. Libya and Chad fought a war in the early 1980s and have since engaged in sporadic negotiations over their disputed border. The most recent round of talks were held last month.

DOC.HEAD: New Japanese Emperor A Product of Postwar Age
With PM-Japan-Entronement, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Emperor Akihito has long lived in the shadow of his father, the late Emperor Hirohito, and the memories of Japan's headlong march into the Pacific War that Hirohito's name evoked. But now that Akihito has assumed the throne left by his father's death, many Japanese are looking to him as the symbol of a new age - that of the generation who experienced war as children and rebuilt the nation in peace. Akihito was 11 at the end of World War II, which Japanese militarists had urged the nation into in the name of his father. The impact of surrender and reform under the guidance of U.S.-led occupation forces deeply affected his youth. Before Akihito turned 13, Hirohito made his historic renunciation of imperial divinity. Occupation troops departed Japan in 1952, leaving behind them a democratic constitution that renounced war and defined Japan's monarchs as ``symbols,'' not the priest-kings of bygone days. That imperial role seems to fit Akihito, who in one of his first duties after assuming the throne upon the death of Hirohito in January 1989 promised to uphold the constitution ``along with the people.'' Akihito, born Dec. 23, 1933, bears a strong physical resemblance to Hirohito, and has inherited his father's short, almost frail, build. He also has his father's passion for science, and is a respected scholar in the study of gobies, a type of mud-sucking fish. Akihito speaks fluent English and is Japan's most widely traveled emperor. He has made official visits to 37 countries, his first to England for the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II in 1953. Reflecting the circumstances of his upbringing, Akihito is often described by former schoolmates and palace officials as a more democratically-minded, warmer person than the quiet, reclusive Hirohito. He has also been far more prone to set his own precedents. Just three years after completing his education - Akihito was the first emperor schooled alongside commoners - the royal heir chose a commoner for his bride, making another break from the past. The woman, Michiko Shoda, was the daughter of one of the nation's wealthiest businessmen, but their marriage in 1959 sent shock waves through Japan's former nobility. To the rest of the nation, however, the wedding was welcomed as none before. About 500,000 people lined the streets for a chance to see Akihito and Michiko in their horse-drawn carriage during a parade after the ceremony. The royal couple again broke with tradition by raising their own children, a decision prompted in part by Akihito's desire to have the family life he was denied as a child, according to Minoru Hamao, a former imperial chamberlain. Taken away from his parents at an early age to be raised by strangers, Akihito at times complained of the loneliness he felt when his classmates would talk to him about their homes, said Hamao, who served Akihito for two decades. Akihito's first child and heir, Crown Prince Naruhito, was born Feb. 23, 1960. They have another son, Prince Akishino, and daughter, Princess Nori. Though the crown prince remains single, Prince Akishino earlier this year wed Kiko Kawashima - who, like the empress, had no royal lineage.

DOC.HEAD: More Sun in West, Snow in East
DOC.TEXT: Clear skies and warm temperatures prevailed again today throughout most of the West, Southwest and Southeast, but it was wintry in the Midwest and Northeast. Showers were expected today in western Washington, already deluged by two days of heavy rains that caused widespread flooding, damage and evacuations. However, sunshine Sunday gave the soggy state some time to dry out. Snow and cold, windy weather was forecast through at least tonight across the Great Lakes into Pennsylvania, New York and New England. Light snow fell in parts of the region Sunday night. Temperatures were unseasonably warm Sunday in the West, with record highs in many cities. Among them was Helena, Mont., which reached 72 degrees, one degree above the mark in 1894 and 28 degrees warmer than normal for the date. The high temperature for the nation Sunday was 93 degrees at Monrovia, Calif., and San Gabriel, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Four Dead in House Fire; Fifth Seriously Burned
DOC.TEXT: A house fire early today killed four people and seriously burned a fifth, authorities said. The fire started in the one-story house shortly before 1 a.m. and quickly engulfed the building, fire dispatcher Vic Vreeland said. He said the fire was brought under control within about a half hour. Four people died, said Vreeland, who couldn't immediately give further details. The fifth victim, a 30-year-old man, was taken to Brackenridge Hospital with second- and third-degree burns and severe breathing problems. He was in very critical condition, said a hospital spokeswoman who would not identify herself.

DOC.HEAD: Panic-Buying As Fuel-Saving Plan Takes Effect
DOC.TEXT: Huge lines formed at gasoline stations throughout the city today as a government plan went into effect to limit sales and save fuel in the wake of the Persian Gulf crisis. Industry officials warned that the panic-buying was dangerously depleting gasoline supplies. Industry and congressional sources criticized the government plan and complained that President Corazon Aquino's administration had failed to consult the private sector. They also criticized the government for failing to inform the public on details of the fuel-saving plan. The Philippines imports all its oil, and about 85 percent comes from the Middle East. Station owners said panic-buying began Sunday, one day before the start of government restrictions on hours of operation. Many stations closed early Sunday, claiming they had run out of supplies. Others limited customers to purchases of $4.50, enough for a quarter tank in mid-sized cars. Last week, the Energy Regulatory Board ordered stations to operate only between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. during work days and to close at 5 p.m. on Sundays. On Friday, Mrs. Aquino also ordered the three national oil companies to curb sales by 10 percent as part of the conservation plan. Under the order, service stations will only receive supplies every 10 days. Pedro Lobos, vice president of the Philippine Petroleum Dealers Association, said that if panic-buying continues, the 10-day supplies will be gone in two or three days. Lobos urged the government to suspend the 10 percent reduction order to allow time to devise a workable conservation plan. Long lines extended from the stations out into major streets, clogging traffic during the morning rush hour. Presidential Executive Secretary Catalino Macaraig said there was no cause for panic-buying. ``I don't know about it, but I will look into it,'' he said. ``Maybe this was brought about by the price increase being predicted in the media.'' Mrs. Aquino was out of the country today. She had left Sunday for Japan to attend the enthronement of Emperor Akihito despite a self-imposed ban on foreign travel because of the country's economic and political problems. Before leaving, she ordered the Cabinet Security Committee to meet today to discuss contingency plans for saving fuel. ``If we don't discipline ourselves, then we cannot prolong our present inventory of oil,'' said the committee's chairman, Justice Secretary Franklin Drilon. The country's fuel crisis was brought about by the steep decline in dollar reserves because of the depreciation of the Philippine peso. That was caused in part by a decline in convertible currency coming into the country after thousands of Filipinos lost their jobs in Kuwait after the Aug 2. Iraqi invasion. Transportation Secretary Oscar Orbos said the government was considering other conservation measures, including rationing fuel and banning private cars during certain hours. The Energy Regulatory Board said last month that the country had enough oil reserves for 59 days. The board said the normal reserve was 70 days.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower against all major currencies in European trading this morning. Gold was lower. Dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: -1.4794 German marks, down from 1.4875 -1.2465 Swiss francs, down from 1.2495 -4.9690 French francs, down from 4.9940 -1.6720 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6775 -1,113.60 Italian lire, down from 1,119.50 -1.1652 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1698 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9675, compared with $1.9670 late Friday. Japan's markets were closed today for a national holiday as Emperor Akihito was enthroned. In London, the dollar was quoted at 128.45 yen, down from 130.50 yen at the close in Tokyo on Friday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $381.90 per ounce at midmorning, down from $384.75 bid per ounce late Friday. In Zurich, the bid price was $381.90, down from $385.80 late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold dropped 97 cents an ounce to close at $383.61. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.20 a troy ounce, from Friday's $4.25.

DOC.HEAD: Floodwaters Recede as Governor Proclaims State of Emergency
DOC.TEXT: A day of sunshine eased flooding that caused millions of dollars in damage. Many people returned to their homes, but two islands remained evacuated today. After heavy rain Friday and Saturday, warm, sunny weather on Sunday lowered flood waters enough that Interstate 5 in Skagit County and some smaller roads could reopen, said Michael Stewart, spokesman for the state Division of Emergency Management. ``It is receding, but it isn't gone away,'' Stewart said. Several roads, including some highways, remained closed. No injuries were reported and most dikes and levees held. The National Weather Service canceled flood warnings for all but the Skagit and Snohomish rivers. Light, scattered rain was forecast this afternoon. Gov. Booth Gardner declared a state of emergency Sunday in five counties where flooding of seven northwest Washington rivers forced more than 600 people from their homes. Damage was expected to reach more than $10 million. About 200 residents of Fir Island, a farming community near the mouth of the Skagit River, and at least 100 residents of Ebey Island on the Snohomish River, likely would not be allowed home before Tuesday, Stewart said. The western half of Fir Island was under water and livestock was rescued. There was a 200-foot break in the island's dike. Gardner's proclamation covers Skagit, Snohomish, Whatcom, Grays Habor and King counties and directs state resources to local governments. Property damages in Whatcom County could approach $10 million, said Bill Quehrn of the county Department of Emergency Services. A damage estimate for Skagit County will not be available until flood waters recede and residents return, Stewart said. Red Cross shelters housed about 100 people and provided more than 2,000 free meals over the weekend in Skagit and Whatcom counties. Three houses were destroyed in the resort town of Glacier. In Vancouver, British Columbia, flooding in Fraser Valley was receding. Rail lines and highways in the area had been washed out or blocked. The raging Salmon River stranded families in the Sayward Valley on northeastern Vancouver Island. Rescuers took about 30 people out by truck and inflatable boat Sunday but 62 others awaited rescue today by helicopter.

DOC.HEAD: Kitten Survives Being Sucked Into Leaf Collector Truck
DOC.TEXT: A kitten survived the hair-raising experience of being sucked up by the 175 mph force of a vacuum hose on a leaf-collector truck. Instead of being cut by the machinery, the homeless orange-and-white kitten landed safely in a pile of leaves inside the collection bin Friday. ``Usually anything that goes in there is pretty much history,'' said Robert Taylor of the highway department. Workers who realized the machine had sucked up a kitten, and petrified that they might have killed someone's beloved pet, decided to see how the animal had fared. They dug about 4 feet into the collection bin - and saw nothing. Then they dumped the leaves out and carefully poked around with a rake. Expecting to see a ghastly sight, they were relieved to find the kitten unharmed but visibly shaken. ``It looked like one of those Halloween cats with its hair standing straight up,'' Taylor said. ``It was so scared, but we couldn't believe he was alive.'' The kitten's owners couldn't be found, so Charles and Lucia Klemovich agreed to take it in. To distinguish the little one from their three other cats - Scratch, Itch and Blacky - the Klemovichs gave the kitten what they believed is a well-earned name - Hoover.

DOC.HEAD: Precede AGANA
Typhoon Mike Heads For Philippines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with storm approaching Philippines. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Mike, with winds of up to 150 mph, roared toward the central Philippines today after it left a trail of devastation in the western Pacific islands of Palau. The Manila weather bureau said the storm was located about 190 miles southeast of the town of Borongan on the central island of Samar early today. Borongan is 230 miles southeast of Manila. It was moving west-northwest at 15 mph with strongest sustained winds of 150 mph and gusts of up to 175 mph. It was expected to make landfall over the southern tip of Samar at dawn Tuesday and then hit Masbate island, 155 miles southeast of Manila, in the afternoon. Maximum storm warnings were raised in six provinces southeast of Manila, where forecasters said seas would be dangerous for all types of vessels. Lesser storm alerts were raised over most of the central Visayas islands. Authorities advised residents living in coastal areas on Samar and Leyte islands and the northern region of the southern island of Mindanao to move to higher ground. Classes were also canceled in most of northern Mindanao today. The state-own Philippine Airlines canceled 10 flights to central and southern cities today and 13 flights Tuesday to the same areas. The typhoon is the 14th to hit the Philippines this year. About 20 typhoons hit the country yearly. Over the weekend, the storm toppled trees, devastated crops and battered buildings in Palau. Electrical power was among the services knocked out Saturday when the typhoon, which then had winds of up to 172 mph, swept through Palau's northern islands. Only eight of 200 islands in the Palau island chain are inhabited; the population is about 15,000. No serious injuries were reported, but the typhoon dumped nearly 10 inches of rain in the U.S. trust's capital city, Koror, between Saturday afternoon and Sunday morning. Winds leveled up to 90 percent of the major crops of bananas and coconuts. A serious health problem could develop in Koror because sewer wastes were backing up into some homes, officials said. Before hitting Palau, the typhoon swept past Yap, in the Federated States of Micronesia, with winds gusting to 60 mph, causing minor damage to crops and homes.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Kills Seven Blacks, Thousands Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with ANC comment. Pickup 13th graf pvs, `In the...'
DOC.TEXT: Seven blacks died in violence near Johannesburg, and thousands of black workers in the capital, Pretoria, stayed home today to protest electricity cutoffs in the townships outside the city. Police said five men were killed in Katlehong, a township southeast of Johannesburg that has been wracked by black factional fighting for several months. A police spokeswoman, Lt. Ida van Zweel, said the battle with guns and knives was between Xhosa and Zulu tribal members at a squatter camp on the edge of the township. Also, a man was hacked to death and set on fire in Sebokeng, south of Johannesburg. In Jouberton, southwest of the city, a youth died when police fired on a group throwing gasoline bombs at a policeman's house. The police unrest report gave no additional details. Meanwhile, most black workers in Pretoria took part in a one-day stayaway organized by anti-apartheid groups aligned with the African National Congress, the leading black opposition group. There were few blacks on the streets and shops that employ blacks had to rely on their white staff. The stayaway was called to protest power cuts in the neighboring townships. Authorities shut off electricity last week because residents were not paying their bills in a protest against poor living conditions. Residents and police clashed Saturday in the Atteridgeville township, leaving two dead and 18 injured. The government on Sunday imposed a 9 p.m. to 4 a.m. curfew and gave police expanded powers in Atteridgeville and nearby Saulsville. Organizers said today's stayaway also was meant to express opposition to the government in the nearby black homeland of Bophuthatswana. Activists see the tribal territories as part of the apartheid system of racial segregation and have called for the four homelands with nominal independence to be reincorporated into South Africa. The president of Bophuthatswana, Lucas Mangope, has refused to consider rejoining South Africa despite mounting opposition to his rule. Today's stayaway also affected businesses in Bophuthatswana. Police in Bophuthatswana said today they had detained an unspecified number of ANC supporters allegedly plotting to kill Mangope and overthrow the homeland government. ``The arrest and detention of ANC members and other activists ... is but one more example of an unpopular regime trying to postpone its demise by repression,'' the ANC said in a statement. In the three other ``independent'' homelands - Transkei, Ciskei and Venda - army members have staged coups in recent years and developed good relations with the ANC. ANC leader Nelson Mandela told a rally in Venda on Sunday that the ANC and the homelands should ``forget about past differences and unite.'' ``The ANC has decided to call upon homeland leaders to rally behind it,'' Mandela told some 20,000 blacks at a sports stadium. He appeared with Venda's military ruler, Brig. Gabriel Ramushwana.

DOC.HEAD: No Motive Established in Car Bombings, Building Fire at Air Force Base
DOC.TEXT: Officials have ruled out terrorism in the bombings of two government-owned cars and a fire that charred a nearby building housing an Air Force investigation office. The fire did little damage to the Air Force Office of Special Investigations, and no one was injured in the bombings of the unoccupied cars early Sunday morning at the base adjoining the Army's Fort Lewis near Tacoma, said Master Sgt. Gloria Rayford. No arrests were made, nor were investigators immediately able to determine who might be responsible, Rayford said. But terrorism was not suspected because no note was left, nor did anyone call to claim responsibility, Sgt. Randy Mitchell said. Investigators would not comment on the type of bombs placed above the left rear wheel of each of the damaged cars, but said they did not believe military-type explosives were involved. The Office of Special Investigations handles cases involving security problems and serious crimes. ``They're sort of the FBI for the Air Force,'' Rayford said. Air Force Capt. John L. Litten said he did not know whether the office was involved in any unusual investigations. The McChord base employs about 4,800 people on active duty and 1,300 to 1,00 civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Vandals Damage Statue of Slain Polish Priest
DOC.TEXT: Vandals decapitated a recently dedicated statue of a slain Polish priest and scrawled a seemingly pro-Communist message on it. The granite head of the 9-foot statue of Jerzy Popieluszko was found in a nearby trash can, said Officer Scott Bloch, a police spokesman. Painted on the base were the Polish words, ``Za Lenina Za Stalina,'' which means, ``For Lenin For Stalin.'' The vandalism in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn was discovered Sunday - Independence Day in Poland. Popieluszko, whose sermons bolstered the then-outlawed Solidarity labor movement, was abducted Oct. 19, 1984. His beaten and bound body was pulled from a river 11 days later, galvanizing the anti-Communist movement. Four secret police were convicted of his slaying. The Rev. John Lazar said some parishioners at Our Lady of Consulation Roman Catholic Church wept when the vandalism was noted during Mass. ``Although the priest has been dead for six years, he stays very much alive in the hearts and memories of the Polish people,'' Lazar said. The statue, dedicated Oct. 28, is a blocklike structure with the upper torso of the priest emerging from the top.

DOC.HEAD: Mayors Say Cities Deserve More Federal Aid
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins told fellow big-city mayors that urban areas deserve federal funds in exchange for supplying a labor force and tax revenues. Dinkins and 33 other mayors, who met here Sunday to discuss the survival of their cities, said federal tax revenues generated by in them help fuel the nation's economic growth. ``Cities are our nation's marketplaces, not only for business but also for ideas,'' Dinkins said. ``If we choke off our cities by denying them the resources they need to function efficiently, the marketplaces will disappear.'' The mayoral summit meeting - which continues through Tuesday - is focusing on urban issues such as combating drug abuse, improving education and paying for costly building projects such as bridges and roads. Atlanta Mayor Maynard Jackson said property taxes alone won't pay the bills for solving such problems. Many of the mayors speaking Sunday, most of them Democrats, said the federal government was neglecting urban areas. For instance, in 1980, federal funds made up 19.4 percent of New York City's budget; currently that share is 9.7 percent, Dinkins said. Dinkins just last week announced that he had to cut 5,400 city jobs to close a $388 million municipal budget gap. Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn complained that cities aren't getting enough federal aid to support drug education. The mayors also got a look at a survey prepared for the urban summit that showed many non-urban Americans support efforts to help cities. The survey found that 74 percent of those living outside cities would be willing to pay higher taxes to provide housing for the poor; 71 percent of non-urban residents would be willing to pay higher taxes for AIDS treatment programs; 66 percent would be willing to pay higher taxes for better urban public schools; and 63 percent would be willing to pay higher taxes for drug rehabilitation programs in cities. The survey of a random sample of 1,199 Americans, made during early October, was done by the City University of New York's Office of Urban Affairs. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov, Karpov Arrive To Prepare For Chess Finale
DOC.TEXT: Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov arrived today to begin preparations for the second half of their deadlocked world championship. After 12 matches in New York, the two Soviet grand masters each have six points. The competition resumes in Lyon on Nov. 24, and could extend through 12 more matches if necessary. The first player to reach 12.5 points wins the title. Kasparov will retain the championship in the event of a draw. ``After New York, everything's still up in the air, and the two men will wage a fight to the death,'' said Bachar Kouatly, one of the organizers of the championship. It is the first time France has hosted a world chess championship, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Books by Soviet Leaders Not Bestsellers
DOC.TEXT: Books by Soviet leaders, including President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, are no longer guaranteed space on store shelves and those that don't sell are being shredded, a newspaper said today. However, books by the founder of the Soviet state, Vladimir I. Lenin, are still considered sacred and cannot be destroyed, the weekly Sobesednik said. The newspaper, aimed at Soviet youth, quoted a bookshop manager as saying works by Gorbachev, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov are not selling and have been written off. ``These books sell poorly, and to sell even one brochure is a victory,'' M. Chuchaikina, director of Bookstore Number 67 in Moscow, told the newspaper. She said a total of 17 books and publications by Gorbachev, Shevardnadze and Ryzhkov as well as pamphlets on the 28th Communist Party Congress and the 19th Communist Party Conference have been sent to the shredders on orders of the Moscow Directorate of Bookstores. The newspaper said it was the first time in Soviet history that works by active leaders had been written off as non-sellers and destroyed. ``Previously, such actions were equal to crimes against the state,'' it said. Sobesednik said Politizdat, publishers of works by Soviet leaders and other political books and pamphlets, used to routinely produce such works in lots of 200,000 copies. Now, the average number is between 15,000 and 20,000, it said. Chuchaikina was quoted as saying the works of Lenin were still considered sacrosanct. ``We are not allowed to write off Lenin, those books are sacred,'' she told the newspaper. Instead, she said, they are stored in basements where ``they rot, they grow moldy and fall apart.'' One method of getting rid of the unwanted books, she said, was making customers purchase several in order to buy popular bestsellers.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin: Russian Republic Won't Accept Central Control
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Tass report on other points of dispute. Pickup 8th graf pvs, `The Russian...' Subs last graf to CORRECT year of Yeltsin's ouster from Politburo from 1987 to 1988.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: Boris Yeltsin, the outspoken president of the Russian Federation, today accused rival Mikhail S. Gorbachev of trying to pressure his republic into ceding some economic powers to the central government. ``But we couldn't and will not go for that,'' Yeltsin told a legislative committee. Yeltsin and Gorbachev, the two most powerful Soviet politicians and frequent critics of each other's policies, met in the Kremlin on Sunday for four hours of what were intended as peacemaking talks. But Yeltsin came out with more criticism of Soviet authorities, especially over negotiations on a new treaty to group the 15 splintering Soviet republics. ``They pressed us yesterday and earlier to first sign a union treaty and then resolve remaining issues, in the meantime transferring everything to the authority of the center,'' Yeltsin told the Russian Federation's constitutional commission. His remarks were carried by the independent Interfax news agency. Yeltsin did not use Gorbachev's name, but the Soviet president appeared to be his target. In the end, an agreement was reached to resolve differences this year, before the treaty is signed, Yeltsin told the commission. Soviet authorities and Russian authorities will form parallel groups to work on issues, Interfax said, included banking, property and the money supply. Yeltsin also listed disputes over control of oil, gas, gold and other precious metals as among the issues the committees would try to resolve, the official news agency Tass reported. The Russian Federation and most other republics are at odds with the central Soviet government over who should control what. The Russian parliament has declared its laws take precedence over national legislation and has passed a plan for switching to a market economy in 500 days. Earlier today, the prime minister of Russia said he told Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov his republic wants to help strengthen the union, but also wants more powers itself. ``We understand this mission and intend to implement it, strengthening the union. But on new principles of economic cooperation, on principles of political interaction as a sovereign state in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics,'' Russian Prime Minister Ivan Silaev told defense plant managers, gathered in the Russian Federation's government headquarters. Silaev and Ryzhkov joined in the Kremlin session after Yeltsin and Gorbachev met alone. The popular Yeltsin, whom Gorbachev ousted from the Communist Party Politburo in 1988, has criticized the Soviet leader for not moving fast enough on reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Democracy Party Might Establish Provisional Government
DOC.TEXT: The largest guerrilla group fighting the government has invited the country's principal pro-democracy party to form a provisional government in rebel-held areas, an insurgent leader said today. Tin Maung Win, general secretary of the Democratic Alliance of Burma rebel group, spoke on the eve of a meeting between his group and members of the National League for Democracy, the nation's leading pro-democracy party. There was no immediate response from the League to the offer. ``The government has no intention of transferring power and continues to suppress any moves toward democracy and so we have an obligation to the Burmese people to take a definite course of action,'' Tin Maung Win said. The League easily won general elections in May, but the ruling military junta has refused to relinquish power. Instead, the party has been crippled in recent months by arrests of its leaders and organizers. Last month, the government arrested four of the few remaining League central committee members and raided the party's offices nationwide. The military also has moved against dissidents among the Buddhist clergy, raiding monasteries and arresting monks. Tin Maung Win said the League had been invited to form a national coalition government with the Democratic Alliance of Burma. He spoke at the rebel stronghold of Manerplaw, along the Thai-Burmese border. The Manerplaw-based alliance is the largest rebel group fighting the Rangoon government. It consists of 22 ethnic minority and dissident groups and controls about one-third of the country - mostly areas bordering Thailand, Bangladesh and China. Tin Maung Win said there was fear that the ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council would outlaw the League, and it therefore was being offered ``sanctuary in the liberated zone.'' ``The League cannot function in Rangoon any more, let alone form a government,'' he told reporters. Tin Maung Win said the new government would be temporary, ``until the League can stand on its own two feet and declare a legitimate government in Rangoon,'' It was not known how many League members had fled to Manerplaw or other rebel-held areas. But there have been scattered reports of both party members and monks fleeing the cities to avoid arrest. A dozen ethnic minority groups have waged a long, bloody war against the central government, demanding more autonomy. Since 1988, they have been joined by students and others fleeing repression in the interior. The military violently crushed a nationwide pro-democracy movement in September 1988. One of the major figures of that movement and a League leader - Aung San Suu Kyi - has been under house arrest in Rangoon since July 1989. Last week, the London-based Amnesty International said it had reports of widespread torture of political detainees in Burma. A team of U.N. human rights investigators left Burma on Sunday, but Rangoon-based diplomats said the military had severely restricted activities of the team.

DOC.HEAD: Students Take To The Streets To Demand Better Education
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with today's march. Pickup 16th graf pvs, `The protests...'
DOC.TEXT: Through a long history of revolt and protest, France has seen nothing like it. Day after day, students in the tens of thousands march arm-in-arm through French cities, praised by teachers and parents, demanding the government make their schools safer and better. In 1968, brigades of leftist university students fought with riot police in Paris, displaying contempt for all aspects of authority. This fall, teen-agers campaign peacefully for a fair chance to join the establishment. Their leaders confer with police commanders to negate the impact of troublemakers exploiting the protests. Marches and rallies began more than three weeks ago and intensified in the past week with daily protests across France. Today, in their biggest protest yet, tens of thousands of high school students, many from distant cities, marched through Paris with hundreds of supporters. The students' goals seem so reasonable that even pillars of the establishment are helping out. Officials of the national railroad, persuaded in part by student blockades of railway tracks, offered 60 percent fare discounts on special trains to Paris for today's protest. At least two local politicians - in the distant cities of Grenoble, on the edge of the Alps, and Pau, near the Spanish border - arranged travel for protesters from their cities. The students assembled at the Place de la Bastille, where revolutionaries stormed the Bastille prison 201 years ago and marched toward the Champs Elysees. Minimal violence has accompanied the protests. Youths described by student leaders as provocateurs have hurled stones at police and smashed store windows on a few occasions. Many sidewalk cafes along the march route were closed as a precaution, and police said two youths were arrested after some street vendors were robbed. Pierre Verbrugghe, the Paris police chief, had ordered his officers to avoid confrontation today, prompting allegations from police unions that he was turning the force into ``mere bystanders.'' Today, scores of off-duty members of a major police union, wearing civilian clothes, joined student leaders at the head of the march and offered to assist in any negotiations with uniformed police. Several major associations of teachers and parents have endorsed the student goals. Teachers' unions plan to send representatives to the march. ``We've accepted an invitation from the students,'' said Yannick Simbron, secretary-general of the Federation of National Education, one of the unions. ``The problems they are raising are those we've been raising for a long time.'' Surprising unity has developed between the two main student factions, one led by hard-line leftists and the other aligned with an anti-racism group. They decided to march together today rather than form two processions. The protests began with student strikes in the gritty northern suburbs of Paris after the gang rape of a girl in a school lavatory and assaults on several teachers. Protesters complained of drug trafficking, theft and extortion at schools. ``We're totally left to ourselves; it's the law of the jungle,'' a 16-year-old protester from Versailles told the magazine L'Evenement. Protesters want more government spending to improve security, replace substandard facilities, modernize curriculums and hire more teachers. Many high schools have more than 35 students per class. In negotiations with Education Minister Lionel Jospin, student leaders also have demanded greater freedom of expression and assembly. Jospin says the protesters gradually are complying with his request to be more specific in their demands. On Thursday, he promised to push for a swift reassessment of high school education and said: ``The students naturally must be heard and included in these discussions.'' Most protesters come from relatively low-income families, and many are children of immigrants. They view education as the key to advancement, and resent a seemingly second-class treatment of schools in the high-rise slums that ring many major cities. The government has proposed increasing the education budget by 9 percent in 1991, which would outpace an overall budget rise of 4.3 percent and mark the first time education has been given more money than defense. Students worry that improvements won't come quickly enough to help them win university admission or decent jobs. Their protests have posed a dilemma for the governing Socialist Party and particularly for President Francois Mitterrand, who has enjoyed strong support among youth since taking office in 1981. Mitterrand has stayed on the sidelines, but faces increasing pressure to intervene or risk alienating his young supporters. ``What have we done, in 10 years, with the immense hope the election of Francois Mitterrand raised?'' asked Jean Poperen, a Socialist leader. ``We haven't changed this society enough, and it is in the process of taking revenge.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Sets Conditons For Attending Proposed Peace Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Chinese official meeting with Saddam, EC calls for U.N. to negotiate hostage release, pessimism among leaders over gulf.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has said it might attend a proposed Arab summit aimed at avoiding war in the Persian Gulf, but only if the meeting also deals with the Arab-Israeli dispute. King Hassan of Morocco proposed the emergency summit on Sunday as a ``last chance'' for peace. There were new signs, meanwhile, of cracks in the alliance against Iraq. Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak was quoted today as saying that Egyptian soldiers will not enter Iraq even if U.S. and other troops attack. He said his troops could, however, enter Kuwait as a peacekeeping force. At the same time, the European Community said it would urge Baghdad to accept a U.N.-brokered solution concerning the hundreds of Westerners held by Iraq. The EC wants countries negotiating hostage deals with Iraq to work together and thereby prevent tensions among nations in the anti-Iraq alliance. Meanwhile, an Arab summit attended by Iraq appeared possible. On Sunday, Iraq's ruling Revolutionary Command Council said Iraq would attend the summit under three conditions. Those were that Baghdad be consulted in advance on the agenda, that the timing and location be chosen so Saddam could attend, and that the agenda include not just the gulf crisis but all Middle East issues - including the Palestinian question. The council, led by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, also suggested it would not allow certain topics to be discussed. It did not specify which ones. ``The proposed summit should not be part of efforts to prepare the political theater as a cover for American aggression against Iraq and the Arab nation,'' the statement said. In Tunis, the Palestine Liberation Organization issued a statement saying it agreed with King Hassan's initiaive. Saddam has long demanded that a solution to the crisis be linked to the Palestinian issue. He made the offer shortly after his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. King Hassan suggested that the summit be held in Rabat, the Morrocan capital, in a week. But he said he would attend a summit wherever it might be held. Morocco, outspoken among Arab nations in condemning the Iraqi invasion, has committed more than 1,200 soldiers to the U.S.-led multinational force based in Saudi Arabia. In an interview with British television, Saddam again urged dialogue on the crisis and said he did not believe the world was united against him. The major powers and ``a number of countries'' are lined up against Baghdad, Saddam acknowledged. ``But to say that the world is unified against Iraq is indeed not a correct thing to say. ``In the statements of the U.S. and Britain, they themselves are voicing their concern that the unity - so-called unity against Iraq - is perhaps ... suffering from a split,'' Saddam said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III received assurances from key allies last week that they will accept nothing short of an unconditional Iraqi pullout. However, officials said China, France and the Soviet Union reportedly expressed concern that Washington might attack Iraqi forces without giving the U.N.-ordered trade embargo enough of a chance. There were also signs of cracks in the Arab alliance against Iraq. When Baker visited Cairo last week, a senior U.S. official said the United States is confident that Egypt would fight alongside U.S. forces if war broke out. But asked by his party's newspaper, Mayo, whether Egypt would send troops to Iraq following a U.S.-led attack, Mubarak said: ``No, we have nothing to do with Iraq.'' But if the anti-Iraq allies invaded Kuwait, he said, ``We do not mind at all entering Kuwait as peacekeeping forces ... although I do not hope for this day at all.'' In Washington, the powerful chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said the Bush administration must have the support of the American people if the nation is to go to war with Iraq. ``The last thing we need is to have a war over there, a bloody war, and have American boys being sent and brought back in body bags and yet not have the American people behind them,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga. ``We've gone that route one time. We don't need to do it again.'' In Brussels, meanwhile, European Community foreign ministers said they would step up pressure on Iraq to open talks with a U.N. envoy on the fate of hundreds of Westerners that Baghdad is holding. They said they would encourage about 40 nations to pressure Sadam into accepting mediation by such an envoy. In other developments: -Foreign Minister Qian Qichen of China met today with Saddam in Baghdad. A Chinese diplomat said talks focused on how to achieve a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis. -In Tokyo, Foreign leaders gathered for Emperor Akihito's enthronement were pessimistic about a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis, an aide to Vice President Dan Quayle said on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Tracking Husband Killed by Homeowner at Wrong Address
DOC.TEXT: A woman who tracked her husband to a rendezvous with an alleged paramour was slain when she broke into the wrong house, officials said. Priscilla Brayboy was shot to death by a homeowner early Sunday when she forced her way into a house where she believed her husband was having an affair, said Harris County Sheriff's Department Sgt. Bruce Williams. Williams said Mrs. Brayboy, 32, and a friend drove down a northern Harris County street looking for her husband, Joe Brayboy. When the women spotted a gray Volvo parked in a driveway on the street, Mrs. Brayboy thought it belonged to her husband. When Mrs. Brayboy knocked on the door, a woman answered, Williams said. Mrs. Brayboy, believing her husband was inside, began to force her way into the house. A man inside the home heard the commotion and armed himself with a shotgun, Williams said. As Mrs. Brayboy lunged through the door, the man shot her, the officer said. When Mrs. Brayboy's friend saw what had happened, she ran down the street screaming and noticed another gray Volvo parked in another driveway a few houses away. The woman went to that house and found Joe Brayboy inside, Williams said. Mrs. Brayboy was taken by helicopter to Hermann Hospital, where she was pronounced dead. The homeowner who did the shooting was questioned and released, Williams said. The case will be referred to a grand jury.

DOC.HEAD: Marine Reported Shot in Sleep at Saudi Base Camp
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES throughout with victim ID, no suspicion of foul play; total of accidental deaths
DOC.TEXT: Military investigators have tentatively determined that the shooting death of a Marine in Saudi Arabia last Friday was accidental, a Marine Corps spokesman said today. The victim, identified as James B. Cunningham, 22, of Glendale, Ariz., was killed in his sleep by a single bullet fired from another Marine's M16 rifle at a rear-area tent camp in eastern Saudi Arabia, the Pentagon said. Cunningham was a member of the 3rd Marine Regiment deployed from Hawaii as part of Operation Desert Shield. A Marine Corps spokesman, Warrant Officer Randy Gaddo, said a preliminary investigation found no evidence of foul play. The investigation is continuing, he said. Gaddo said two other Marines were in the tent at the time of the shooting. He said the rifle of one Marine discharged as he was leaving the tent, striking the victim as he lay sleeping. It happened at 3:10 p.m. Saudi time last Friday. If the incident is officially declared an accident, it would bring to 44 the number of accidental deaths during Desert Shield, which began Aug. 7.

DOC.HEAD: TWA Offers To Buy Pan Am If UAL Deal Fails
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Pan Am's...', to UPDATE with Pan Am stock up in early trading. Subs penultimate graf to fix style errors. A version moved on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines Inc. has offered to buy Pan Am Corp. if Pan Am's deal to sell key New York-to-London routes to United Airlines' parent falls through. TWA chairman Carl Icahn said late Sunday he had proposed offering about $150 million in cash plus securities with a face value of $300 million for struggling Pan Am. Icahn said in a telephone interview that Pan Am Chairman Thomas Plaskett had asked him to make an offer in case Pan Am's talks with UAL Corp. fail. Pan Am has proposed selling UAL important routes between New York and London as part of a $400 million deal. Although TWA is considered healthier than Pan Am, both have been hurt by rising fuel prices since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and fewer passengers since the economy started weakening. If TWA buys Pan Am, duplicated routes like those to London's Heathrow airport would be sold, Pan Am said. TWA and Pan Am are the only two U.S. airlines flying into Heathrow. Icahn's proposal, contained in a letter delivered to Plaskett late Friday, proposed Pan Am shareholders receive $1 per share in cash and securities with a face value of $2 per share. The securities, either preferred stock or promissary notes, could bring different market prices. Pan Am's stock closed at $1.62{ Friday on the New York Stock Exchange; in early trading today, it rose 12{ cents to $1.75. Pan Am said in a statement it was still working on the route sale to United, but the deal could be called off if not completed by Wednesday. United spokesman Joe Hopkins wouldn't comment Sunday on the TWA proposal. Icahn's letter also proposed buying the Pan Am Shuttle, which flies between Boston, New York and Washington, by the end of the year. TWA's proposal to buy the rest of the company is open through Friday. The Wall Street Journal reported recently that Pan Am's pilots might be willing to pay $150 million to $200 million for the shuttle alone. Subtracting other elements of Pan Am's deal with United, the London routes would be worth about $290 million. TWA last month announced 430 layoffs from its work force of 33,000 to cope with rising jet fuel prices and the economic downturn. TWA also said it would stop hiring and training new pilots and flight attendants. TWA, based in Mount Kisco, N.Y., earned $103.4 million in the second quarter of the year, but that included one-time gains from the sales of assets totalling $160.2 million. In the second quarter of 1989, the airline lost $4.4 million. Earlier this month, Pan Am, based in New York, cited blamed rising jet fuel costs for a loss of $29.1 million, or 19 cents per share, during the third quarter. In the same period last year the airline lost $18 million, or 12 cents a share.

DOC.HEAD: Governing Party Claims Victory; Opposition Charges Fraud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with unofficial returns still trickling in; CORRECTS second reference to Salinas. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `The reforms...'
DOC.TEXT: The governing party today claimed overwhelming victories in two major state elections that tested the impact of reforms in the country and the long-dominant party itself. But the opposition charged that the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, resorted to old-fashioned fraud during Sunday's vote for state and local officials in Hidalgo and Mexico states. Unofficial results from party poll watchers continued to trickle in today but official results, by law, will not be released for a week. PRI has been scrambling to renovate itself since the 1988 elections, when President Carlos Salinas de Gortari won election with the narrowest margin in modern Mexican history. Salinas has pushed the country to sudden free-market reforms that have jolted the long-sluggish economy. He has overseen a new election law and party reforms billed as more democratic. The reforms included state primary elections to choose local candidates, doing away with the appointment of candidates by party leaders. PRI officials said they appeared to be even or ahead in all of the 121 municipalities of Mexico state. They also claimed victory in the 22 local Hidalgo races they said were decided. But the conservative National Action Party claimed it was leading in at least some parts of Mexico state. The leftist Party of the Democratic Revolution said it had won at least one victory in Hidalgo and had been robbed of others. ``It was a normal election, within the common and ongoing frauds, but normal,'' said Francisco Ortiz Mendoza, an election official of the Popular Socialist Party. He was quoted by the Excelsior news agency. The state of Mexico is the country's most populous, with more than 10 million people and 4.5 million voters. It borders Mexico City, but does not include it. Hidalgo, just northeast of Mexico state, is a mountainous zone with a few sizable cities and many small villages. Reporters touring Mexico state on Sunday found polling places generally orderly and peaceful, and often empty. Party estimates of turnout hovered around 30 percent. The election commission in Mexico state said it had received complaints of irregularities in only 84 voting places, 2.3 percent of the total. Javier Paz Zarza, spokesman for the National Action Party in Mexico state, alleged that armed men also seized ballot boxes in Chimalhuacan. In Hidalgo state, PRI spokesman Marco Antonio Gonzalez said the party was leading in the 22 results so far available. The state has 84 municipalities.

DOC.HEAD: Israel To Accept UN Envoy, Report Says Bush Warned Jewish Leaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with comment from government official; Edits to trim; No pickup.
