DOC.TEXT: Israeli leaders have agreed to hold talks with a U.N. envoy as a compromise with a Security Council demand for an investigation into last month's Temple Mount killings, Israel radio said today. The radio quoted Foreign Minister David Levy as announcing the decision during a closed-door session of Parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee. The ministry declined official comment on the report, but a government official confirmed Israel had worked out an understanding with the United States to accept the compromise. He spoke on condition of anonymity. The proposal called for a special U.N. envoy to visit Israel but not in connection with two Security Council resolutions censuring Israel and demanding a probe, the official said. The compromise was aimed at hading off threats by the U.N. Security Council to take further measures against Israel. Earlier, the Council criticized excessive force by police in the Oct. 8 riots on the Temple Mount. Twenty Palestinians were killed and more than 140 wounded when police opened fire on Arab stone-throwers at the site, which is holy to both Moslems and Jews. The United States, which refused to use its veto to block a resolution condemning Israel for the shootings, has been pushing Israel to accept a U.N. investigation into the slayings. Israel rejected such a probe, saying it could call into question its sovereignty over east Jerusalem, which it captured from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war and later annexed. Most Western countries do not recognize Israeli rule of the eastern sector, where the Temple Mount is located. Levy's reported statement came after a possible compromise was discussed at Sunday's weekly Cabinet meeting, but no decision was announced. The radio quoted Levy as saying today that Israel would accept a U.N. envoy in a compromise with the United States. The official said Israeli leaders would meet with Jean Claude Aimee, an envoy of U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who visited Israel in June to discuss the Palestinian issue. The official stressed that an ``understanding,'' rather than a formal agreement, was reached with Washington. He said Israel was still waiting to hear if Perez de Cuellar had accepted the compromise. ``We do hope that on their side the American administration will now work to remove the subject from the Security Council agenda,'' the official said. An Israeli daily newspaper reported, meanwhile, that President Bush warned American Jewish leaders last week to stop objecting to weapons sales to Saudi Arabia or he would tell the American people ``who is with us and who is against us.'' The Yedioth Ahronoth said Bush spoke out of concern that Jewish opposition to his proposal to sell the Saudis $20 billion worth of equipment and weapons could harm the multinational alliance in the Persian Gulf. The comments were contained in a report compiled by Israel's ambassador to Washington, Zalman Shoval, a copy of which was placed on Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's desk Sunday, the newspaper said. Israel has traditionally been outspoken in opposing American arms shipments to enemy Arab states, but has kept quiet over the latest proposed sale because of the gulf crisis. Jewish leaders in the United States, however, have quietly tried to persuade senators and congressmen to veto the deal. Bush, speaking in a closed-door meeting with Jewish leaders, expressed anger at their lobbying against his proposal, Yedioth Ahronoth said. ``The subject on the agenda is the security of American soldiers in Saudi Arabia,'' Bush reportedly told them. ``If you object to the weapons deal with Saudi Arabia, I will appeal directly to the American public and explain who is with us and who is against us.''

DOC.HEAD: Reform Party Said to Hold Slim Lead in Republic of Macedonia
DOC.TEXT: The party of Yugoslavia's reformist premier, Ante Markovic, held a slight lead over ruling Communists in unofficial returns from free elections in the Macedonian republic, officials said today. An official of the state electoral commission, speaking on condition of anonymity, said initial figures put Markovic's party just ahead of the Communists in Sunday's voting. He said he could not provide specific figures. Stojan Andov, the head of the Alliance of Reformist Forces in Macedonia, also said the party was doing well. Andov himself won a seat from the capital, Skopje, an aide said. The Alliance advocates market economics and keeping Yugoslavia united. The polling in the southern republic, Yugoslavia's poorest, was viewed as a crucial test for Markovic, whose party was competing in an election for the first time. A good showing in the ballot in Macedonia would significantly boost the party's chances in elections in the states of Bosnia-Hercegovina, Montenegro and Serbia in the next weeks. Markovic's popularity grew steadily after he became federal premier in March 1989. But his reforms and efforts to keep together Yugoslavia's fragile federation of six republics have been undermined by political squabbling and increasing ethnic tensions. Official results were not expected until Thursday. Runoff elections will be held Nov. 25 in districts where no one received 50 percent of the vote. Turnout was estimated at 75 percent of the 1.37 million eligible voters. Petar Gosev, the head of the former Communist Party, recently renamed the Party of Democratic Change, was reported by Skopje television to have won a majority in his Skopje district. Gosev strongly supports Markovic's policies and has said he would be prepared to form a coalition with Markovic's party. A coalition of nationalist, right-wing parties charged that there had been widespread electoral fraud during Sunday's voting, and demanded it be declared invalid. Public opinion polls had indicated that the four parties that make up the coalition were likely to do poorly in the balloting. Another contender in the elections was the mainly ethnic Albanian Party of Democratic Prosperity. People of Albanian origin account for more than 20 percent of Macedonia's population of 2.2 million.

DOC.HEAD: Former Rios Montt Adviser Claims Lead in Early Returns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with leaders with 21 percent of the vote counted. Pickup 15th pvs, `Arzu, 44...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto GUA1,2
DOC.TEXT: A conservative, born-again Christian jumped to an early lead in Guatemala's presidential election today, but it appeared that the contest would have to be decided by a runoff in January. Jorge Serrano Elias, 45, whose resume ranges from close collaboration with one of Guatemala's last dictators to a stint on a national commission promoting democracy and peace talks with leftist rebels, led with 28.09 percent of the vote with about 21 percent of the total counted. If none of the 12 candidates gets more than 50 percent of the vote, there will be a runoff Jan. 6. It would be the first time in Guatemala's history that one elected civilian has taken office from another. Results broadcast by the Supreme Electoral Tribunal gave newspaper publisher Jorge Carpio Nicolle 23.17 percent of the vote and former Guatemala Mayor Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen 22.37 percent. The candidate of the incumbent Christian Democrats, Alfonso Cabrera, had 13.68 percent. The other candidates shared the other 12 percent. The winner will inherit a 30-year-old civil war, a bankrupt government, 60 percent inflation and an epidemic of street crime and human rights abuse. The trend in Sunday's balloting represents a sharp repudiation of the corrupt and inept Christian Democractic administration of President Vinicio Cerezo, who was barred by the constitution from running for re-election. Election officials say the turnout appears to be about 60 percent of 3.3 million registered voters. That would be less than in 1985 but more than some observers had predicted. Guatemalans also were electing a vice president, 116 members of a new congress, 20 delegates to a new Central American parliament and 300 mayors. Carpio, who has been campaigning for years, positioned himself as the centrist and assembled a broad coalition ranging from an arch-right running mate to disaffected socialists. Arzu, 44, campaigned as a no-nonsense pragmatist who would run Guatemala like a business enterprise. He headed the national tourism agency at a time when Guatemala was facing international censure because of its human rights record. As mayor, he gained high marks for public works projects. He is from a wealthy old Guatemalan family and had the backing of some of the most conservative elements of the private sector. Serrano, a 45-year-old engineer, came in third in the 1985 presidential election and polls had suggested he would fare no better this time. But his old boss, retired Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, was forced to withdraw due to laws banning former coup instigators from running for election. That threw an important chunk of votes from the religious right into Serrano's lap. Rios Montt is an evangelical preacher who presided over some of the worst human rights abuses in Guatemala's bloody history until he was deposed in 1983. He had stormed to the head of the crowded field this year on a tough law-and-order platform that hit a hugely responsive chord in nation bowed by crime and government corruption. A televised debate with Cerezo also gave Serrano a boost in capital, political observers say. Cerezo debated on behalf of his party; by law, presidents here serve one five-year term. Serrano headed Rios Montt's advisory council in 1982 and 1983 and helped draft a set of electoral laws. His campaign literature says the job showed Serrano's ``faith in democracy.'' After the Rios Montt years, Serrano went on to carve out his own, more mainstream niche. He was an important member of the National Reconciliation Commission, created to work toward implementing the 1987 Central American accords on regional peace and democratization. The campaign was long and marred by violence and rumors of coups, but election day was calm. The federal human rights ombudsman, who has logged 264 killings and 176 disappearances this year, said the the country was ``totally normal,'' without violence or significant reports of electoral problems. Five years of democracy has done little to improve everday life in Guatemala, and the challenges that will face the winner are immense. Seven out of every 10 Guatemalans live in dire poverty and half cannot read or write. The new president also will have to contend with an immensely powerful military and one of the most conservative private sectors in the hemisphere. On the bright side, peace talks have recently begun in the 30-year-old civil war that has left 100,000 dead and more than 40,000 missing - almost all at the hands of the military or right-wing death squads. The election season brought an outbreak of assassinations, disappearances and death threats that put Guatemala back on the international human rights agenda. It has been an embarrassment for the United States, which helped provoke 30 years of brutal dictatorship and civil war with leftist rebels by backing a military coup against a liberal civilian government in 1954. The United States has poured nearly $1 billion in aid into Guatemala since civilian rule was restored in 1985, hoping to create a showcase for free-market democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Missing Girl Found Safe; Teen Charged With Kidnapping
DOC.NOTE: Eds; SUBS last graf to delete extraneous words `were distributed.'
DOC.TEXT: A mentally handicapped 11-year-old girl missing since October returned home safely this weekend, and a teen-ager living down the block from her home was charged, police said. Until April Hall came home Sunday, authorities did not know if she had run away or had been abducted. But police said they now believe she was being held just a block from her family's North Side home in the apartment of 17-year-old Francisco Flores. He was arrested Sunday and charged with kidnapping. The child, last seen by her family on Oct. 23, left Flores' apartment and went home while he was asleep, police said, adding she appeared to be in good condition. ``Her school said earlier they were afraid she would go with anyone who said, `Come in,' and they were 100 percent correct,'' said Lt. Edmund Beazley. The girl, described as having the mentality of a 5-year-old, provided a sketchy account of how she spent the time, Beazley said. The girl's disappearance prompted door-to-door searches and the distribution of numerous fliers bearing her photograph.

DOC.HEAD: Highways Blocked By Protesting Farmers
With AM-France-Students, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of angry farmers used tractors, bales of hay and barricades of burning tires to block traffic Monday on major highways near everal cities in central France. One group of farmers intercepted a Belgian truck carrying imported beef, and seized all of the eight-ton cargo except a portion destined for charity organizations. The protests were the latest in a six-month campaign by farmers who contend that the government is not protecting them against low-priced meat imports and the effects of drought. A decision last week by the European Community to reduce state subsidies to farmers also has drawn criticism. The blockades were mounted for four hours on several roads in the Limousin, Poitou-Charentes and Auvergne regions of west-central and central France. An estimated 2,000 farmers were involved.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Shakes Slovenia, No Damage Reported
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake rumbled through the northwestern Yugoslav republic of Slovenia, but there was no apparent damage, the Tanjug news agency reported Monday. The quake registered 4.2 on the Richter scale, and is believed to have been centered near Bohinjska Bistrica, in the northwest corner of the country near the Italian and Austrian borders. It struck late Sunday evening, and was followed by a serious of minor tremors, Tanjug said. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of 4 on the Richter scale can cause moderate damage.

DOC.HEAD: Historical Society Buys Theater Where JFK's Assassin Was Captured
DOC.TEXT: A Dallas historical society has closed a $175,000 deal to buy the 1931-vintage Texas Theatre, where presidential assassin Lee Harvey Oswald was captured. ``It is basically safe from being boarded up ...,'' Texas Theatre Historical Society spokesman Dennis Hamilton said at a news conference. Pamela Mount, vice president of the society, said Saturday that three last-minute contributors - recording artist Don Henley, film director Oliver Stone and another individual - helped seal the deal to purchase the building from United Artists. She would not say how much they contributed. Mount said the Italian Renaissance-style theater, closed in December 1989, will be renovated and converted into a performing arts center for film festivals, live performances and concerts. Dallas police arrested Oswald there on Nov. 22, 1963, after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

DOC.HEAD: Yannis Ritsos, Greek Poet, Dead at 81
DOC.TEXT: Yannis Ritsos, an internationally acclaimed poet and staunch Communist who had spent years in detention under right-wing governments, has died, his family said Monday. He was 81. Ritsos died at home late Sunday, a nephew said. No cause of death was given, but Ritsos had suffered from various ailments recently. Several Athens dailies reported that Ritsos had become despondent with the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe over the past year and had shut himself off from society. Ritsos was one of Greece's most prolific and popular poets. His work, ranging from long ideological pieces to personal lyricism, gained a wide following when it was set to music by composers such as Mikis Theodorakis. He was detained or sent into internal exile for many years under right-wing governments and the 1967-74 military dictatorship. He refused to compromise his beliefs for the sake of his personal freedom. Harilaos Florakis, president of the Greek Communist Party, of which Ritsos was a member, said Monday: ``We are filled with great sorrow. Yannis Ritsos identified himself with the best that modern Greece had to offer.'' Ritsos won the Soviet Union's Lenin Peace Prize in 1978 and numerous literary awards, many from Eastern bloc countries. He was nominated for the Nobel Prize for literature several times. His ``But imagine doing that in any other country at that time, or today in Nepal. The money would be gone in no time.'' One of Hagen's most treasured possessions is his trekking permit, a document now issued to tens of thousands of tourists every year. But Hagen's slip of paper carries a unique distinguishing mark - the numeral 1. It was the first ever issued.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Jam Capital Streets for King's Swearing-In
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of celebrants filled the streets of this African country on Monday for the crowning of the new king of Lesotho. Formerly known as Prince Mohato, the new king is the 27-year-old son of exiled King Moshoeshoe II, who was dethroned last week by the head of the country's ruling military council, Maj. Gen. Justin Lekhanya. Queen Regent Mamohato, the new king's mother, attended Monday's ceremony, held beneath a statue of King Moshoeshoe I, the new king's great-great-grandfather. No royal name has been given the new king, but he was expected to be called King Letsie III. He will be the constitutional monarch and head of state, but with no executive powers. Moshoeshoe was forced into exile in March following disagreements with Lekhanya, who seized power in a 1986 coup. Lekhanya gave the king some executive authority. But in February, he fired most of Moshoeshoe's supporters from the government and told the king to leave when he refused to approve replacements. Last month, Lekhanya invited Moshoeshoe back from exile in London. But he said last week the king had set unacceptable conditions for returning and therefore had been stripped of his title and powers. Lekhanya said one condition set by Moshoeshoe was dissolution of the government. It was not clear if Moshoeshoe would return to Lesotho. Lekhanya said the deposed king had been granted amnesty, and a government news release Monday said none of Moshoeshoe's property would be confiscated. Lesotho is a mountainous, land-locked country of about 1.5 million people completely surrounded by South Africa. Lesotho gained independence from Britain in 1966. Lekhanya has promised to return Lesotho to civilian rule in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Kermit Will Return, Henson Family Says
DOC.TEXT: Kermit the Frog, the fuzzy green alter ego of the late muppeteer Jim Henson, will live on with someone new supplying his voice. Kermit will be among the characters appearing in ``The Muppets Celebrate Jim Henson'' on CBS Nov. 21. The amiable amphibian has been a mainstay of the Muppets for 35 years. Henson, who directed his motions and supplied his voice, died of pneumonia in May. ``When Jim was alive, he said if anything happened to him, Kermit must go on right away,'' Henson's widow, Jane, told TV Guide, the magazine reports in its Nov. 17 issue. ``Because of Kermit's significant place, Jim had essentially chosen who he thought could do it. But we don't want to say who it is before the show. ``The performer needs time. Kermit won't come back so strong at first. Then little by little, he will get his whole personality back.'' Young viewers ensured Kermit's return. ``We found the kids really wanted to keep Kermit going,'' said Henson's daughter, Cheryl. ``It was a touchy thing. They were sorry Jim had died and wanted to know if the Muppets could die. ``We thought that the Muppets were characters, not people, and that it was much better to say that they don't die.''

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting a0524 to fix cycle designator
Bishops Voice Reservations About Military Force in Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with bishops calling for limitations of military force in Gulf. EDITS throughout. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops today called for sharp limitations on any use of military force by the United States in the Persian Gulf. They said church principles ruled out any tactics that would target civilian lives, adding that would mean any Gulf conflict would have to be a ``limited war.'' The bishops urged that the United States ``stay the course of persistent, peaceful and determined pressure against Iraq'' for a non-violent solution. The action came in the opening session of the annual fall meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops. After lengthy discussion, they voted 249-15 to endorse a letter about the Gulf crisis written by Los Angeles Archbishop Roger Mahony, head of the conference's international affairs committee. The letter was sent last week to Secretary of State James A. Baker III. It said resorting to war would violate principles set down in the church's ``just war'' theory by jeopardizing many lives, raising serious moral questions and undermining the international solidarity against Iraq. After affirming the letter's position, the bishops also voted 126-118 to modify their agenda to hold a special closed session later on the Gulf crisis. Earlier today, the president of the conference said the church is ``in a time of testing'' for the priesthood. Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati told about 300 bishops that the clergy seems to be in a ``period of special challenge.'' Seminary enrollments, down to about a fourth of their one-time level, have yet to begin climbing from the slump, he said. ``Our priests are fewer and more is being demanded of them than ever before,'' he said in his address opening the bishops' annual fall meeting. ``Suspicions have been raised about their faithfulness to their commitments. ``There have been sad lapses, publicly known, touching even our own bishops' conference. There are consequent morale problems among some of our priests, perhaps even among some of us.'' Pilarczyk appeared to be referring to sexual lapses among some priests, including a resigned Georgia bishop, but he did not cite specifics. He pointed out that a world synod of bishops, which met last month at the Vatican, strongly affirmed that the priesthood should go only to those committed to celibacy. That has been a church rule since the Middle Ages, but with the sharpening shortage of priests, many Catholics have pressed for a priestly option on celibacy. Despite studies finding serious morale problems among clergy, Pilarczyk told fellow prelates: ``We may be in a time of testing, a period of challenge, but I know that, by and large, our priests are happy in their ministry and are deeply appreciated by the people they serve.'' As the bishops began their four-day meeting, a demonstration ``celebrating women'' was held outside, pressing for admission of women to the priesthood. The Women's Ordination Conference said it and about 200 other groups were cosponsoring the ``block party,'' including dancing, singing, poetry reading and public speaking. The bishops' meeting faced a batch of touchy issues. But action has been postponed on the most volatile item - a proposed pastoral teaching document on the role of women. That was to be discussed Thursday, but no action was planned. A draft proposal, drawn up in about six years of work and hearings, was sharply criticized as contradictory and inconsistent when it was unveiled earlier this year. It advocates equality for women, but would continue their exclusion from ordination. Bishops decided to delay action on the issue after the Vatican suggested prior consultation with bishops of other countries.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Urges `Open Criticism' of Bush
DOC.TEXT: A leading conservative is urging Reagan Republicans to ``decide if they will stand against'' President Bush as Theodore Roosevelt's followers stood against William Howard Taft in the ``Bull Moose'' campaign of 1912. Bush has betrayed former President Reagan's principles just as Taft strayed from Roosevelt's, says Heritage Foundation Vice President Burton Yale Pines. ``As in 1912, the responsible response to a party leader who betrays the party cannot be silence; it must be open criticism, possibly opposition and maybe even rebellion,'' Pines writes in a forthcoming article in the foundation's magazine, Policy Review. Foundation President Edwin Fuelner Jr., in calling attention to the article, wrote, ``If history truly does repeat itself, then George Bush could become a general without an army in the fall of 1992.'' Pines put it this way: ``Bush's very poor showing in this November's congressional elections is merely the warning tremor of an approaching political earthquake. ... If Bush and his advisors keep to their current course, they are asking for the one-term presidency of William Howard Bush.'' Just as Reagan left the White House with high approval ratings in 1989 after two terms in office, Roosevelt enjoyed immense popularity when he stepped down in 1909 after nearly as long. He praised Taft lavishly, just as Reagan praised Bush. He split with Taft, however, as the new president moved away from Roosevelt's free trade policies toward protectionism. After a 1910 midterm election that was a disaster for the Republicans, Roosevelt unsuccessfully challenged Taft for the 1912 GOP nomination and then ran against Taft in a campaign that got its name when he told reporters he felt ``as strong as a bull moose.'' The split in Republican ranks thrust Democrat Woodrow Wilson into the White House. Pines equates the Taft-Roosevelt split over trade with what he calls ``the betrayals of the Bush administration'' and ``the economic and other disasters toward which Bush and his top advisers are driving the nation.'' Pines is not specific in his criticisms, but conservatives have generally lambasted Bush for abandoning his campaign pledge not to raise taxes. Pines concedes there are differences between 1912 and 1992. For one, even if he wanted to, Reagan is now prohibited by the Constitution from being elected president a third time. For another, Roosevelt was a progressive Republican, not a conservative. There are other differences the writer doesn't mention. For one, the Democrats picked up just one Senate seat and nine House seats last week. That was bad for the Republicans, but nothing like the debacle of 1910, when GOP House seats dropped from 219 to 161. For another, Reagan has voiced no criticism of his successor and recently said Bush ``is doing very well in what is needed.'' Despite the differences, Pines argues that the question, ``Do we bolt the party?'' must be faced. ``The time is at hand for conservatives to decide if they will stand against their party's leader,'' he wrote. ``Just as the legions of Roosevelt supporters turned on Taft for betraying Roosevelt's hard-won victories, so are Ronald Reagan's legions tempted to turn on Bush.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Chicago Mayor Jane Byrne Officially Launches Campaign for Old Job
DOC.TEXT: Jane Byrne today officially launched her campaign for mayor of Chicago, an office she occupied from 1979 until she was defeated in her 1983 re-election bid by the late Harold Washington. Byrne told reporters she was challenging incumbent Mayor Richard M. Daley, a Democrat. But she stopped short of saying she was running for the Democratic nomination. Political pundits, including outgoing Republican Gov. James R. Thompson, insist it will be difficult to unseat Daley whether she runs as a Democrat or as an independent. The mayor has not announced whether he'll run again but is expected to. Daley was out of town and unvailable for comment, and his office said no one else there was immediately available to give a reaction to Byrne's announcement. Byrne said she was running because Daley has not been effective in fighting crime and tackling public health issues. Byrne was elected mayor in 1979, defeating Michael Bilandic in a primary upset stemming in part from voter anger over delays in cleaning streets after a major snowstorm. She was defeated by Washington, the city's first black mayor, in 1983 and lost the nomination to Washington again in 1987. She also lost a bid to become the Democratic nominee for Cook County Clerk in 1988. Washington died in late 1987. Daley, son of the late mayor Richard J. Daley, was elected to fill his unexpired term last year.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
CNN, Noriega Lawyers Agree To Compromise On Tapes Pending High Court Review
Precede ATLANTA
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with compromise to head off showdown, contempt citation, pending Supreme Court action. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Noriega is...'. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for Manuel Noriega and Cable News Network agreed today to cool off their constitutional showdown, at least until the U.S. Supreme Court rules on the issue of tape-recorded conversations. Under the agreement, Noriega will not ask for contempt penalties as long as CNN continues to refrain from broadcasting tapes between the deposed Panamanian leader and his lawyers. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler endorsed the deal, but once again warned CNN, noting that over the weekend the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta had backed his original gag order. ``If you play any tapes in violation of my order, you are violating not only my order, but also the appeals court order,'' Hoeveler said. CNN's attorney Terry Bienstock said the network accepted the deal, but had the right to play other Noriega tapes as long as they did not include conversations with his lawyers. The judge agreed. In Atlanta, where the network is based, CNN spokesman Steve Haworth said that the network expects to file its appeal to the Supreme Court later in the week. Constitutional law experts said the confrontation could become a landmark case. CNN had defied an order Friday by Hoeveler by broadcasting an excerpt in which the deposed Panamanian dictator spoke in Spanish with a secretary for defense lawyer Frank Rubino. CNN decided for editorial reasons to stop broadcasting the excerpt early Saturday, Haworth said. Later Saturday, the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta upheld Hoeveler's ruling. The appeals court also told CNN to give the seven tapes to the Miami court so it could decide whether the broadcasts would endanger Noriega's right to a fair trial on drug-trafficking charges. That order was also stayed by today's agreement. Noriega is accused of accepting $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin cocaine cartel. He has been held at a federal prison outside Miami since his surrender to U.S. forces shortly after the invasion of Panama in December. Rubino asked Hoeveler to find the Atlanta-based network in direct civil contempt and fine the network $300,000 for each time it televised the tapes and each time it shows them in the future. CNN accused Hoeveler of bias and asked him to disqualify himself from the case. Floyd Abrams, a New York constitutional lawyer who served as co-counsel for The New York Times in the Pentagon Papers case, said the CNN case could set precedent because rules involving prior restraint have been very clear through the years. ``We've almost totally banned prior restraint,'' Abrams said. ``If the Supreme Court were to uphold the prior restraint order on CNN, this would be the first time in our country's history that any such court order had been affirmed by the court.'' In the 1971 Pentagon Papers case, the U.S. Supreme Court said the government could not bar publication of classified documents about U.S. involvement in Vietnam. The Times appealed rather than defy a lower court order. George Rahdert, a lawyer at the Poynter Institute of Media Studies, called the CNN case ``an astonishing illustration of censorship,'' but said the network was ``playing with blasting caps'' by defying the judge's order. ``It's rare in general that a news organization of any kind - broadcast, cable or print - would do such a thing,'' said Rahdert, who represents several newspapers. ``It really falls into the category of civil disobedience.'' CNN president Tom Johnson said the case is a classic confrontation between the news media and the government they cover. He said the district court and appeals court construed the case as a conflict between the Sixth Amendment, which provides a defendant a right to a fair trial, and the First Amendment, which provides for freedom of the press. ``There's a more fundamental issue here: reporting the news of possible governmental misconduct,'' Johnson said. ``If CNN can be restrained from airing news about the Noriega tapes, so can any news organization.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Says Human Rights Abuses Persist In Salvador Since Jesuit Slayings
DOC.TEXT: Death squad slayings, summary executions and torture have persisted in El Salvador since the massacre of six Jesuit priests by soldiers a year ago, a U.N. human rights report said Monday. The report blames both the U.S.-backed conservative government and the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front rebels for the continuation of violence. ``Thus far in 1990, government action against humanitarian, trade union, peasants and other organizations has continued,'' said Jose Antonio Pastor, a university professor from Spain who compiled the annual report. Pastor concluded the leftist rebels also executed suspected collaborators and used civilians as cover for their guerrilla attacks. Summary killings by the rightists decreased since the San Jose Agreement on Human Rights was signed July 26, Pastor said, and rebel assassinations of suspected government collaborators ceased after that date. Pastor's sharpest remarks were directed at the government, which has been criticized for the fatal shootings of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter by soldiers. They were killed Nov. 16, 1989, a day after a guerrilla offensive began. In that case, he said, ``there seems to be a lack of cooperation on the part of the armed forces, which has gone so far as the destruction of important evidence.'' Since the assassination of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero during Mass in 1980, rightist death squads have seen the clergy as fair game for attack. Right-wing elements of the military and government view the Roman Catholic Church's advocacy of human rights and social justice as a legal adjunct to the rebel effort to overthrow the system. ``It must be concluded that the practice of summary executions by elements of the state apparatus, in particular members of the armed forces, persisted in the first nine months of 1990,'' Pastor said. Pastor counted 40 politically motivated summary executions of civilians by security forces from January to August of 1990, compared with 51 in the same time span in 1989, according to figures from the Archdiocesan Legal Protection Office. The office also listed 46 assassinations by death squads in January through August 1990, compared with only 17 such slayings in the same months of 1989. The Salvadoran government's Human Rights Commission counted 42 summary killings by security forces in the first eight months of 1990, compared with 68 in the same months of 1989. The government did not keep figures on death squad activity. The church recorded 12 assassinations by the rebels in the first eight months of the year, compared with 30 during those months in 1989. The government counted 49 in the first eight months, compared to 173 from January to August 1989. ``Cases of politically motivated disappearances of individuals continue to be reported,'' he added, and said that rightist death squads were probably behind some of them, as well as the guerrillas. Torture of prisoners continued, Pastor found, with prisoners who belong to political organizations or unions receiving the worst treatment. ``Long periods of interrogation while being blindfolded and without being able to sit down or relieve themselves, extensive beatings, the occasional use of a hood which impedes breathing and causes fainting, immersion of the head in tanks of water, electric shocks, and threats to themselves or their families'' were common, he said. Pastor concluded both the right-wing government of President Alfredo Cristiani and the leftist rebels want to improve the human rights situation in the country, but that abuses continue as the war rages on. Rebels launched a civil war in 1979 that has killed at least 72,000 people, most of them civilians, claiming the government represents an oligarchy of landowners and businesses.

DOC.HEAD: People In The News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: A scene in ``Rocky V'' between Sylvester Stallone and his neophyte-actor son, 14-year-old Sage, may be left on the cutting-room floor because it came too close to real life, Stallone says. Stallone and his first wife, Sasha, divorced in 1985 and Sage and his brother Seargeoh, 11, remained with their mother. ``I'm sure there's a residue of anger in Sage from when my marriage broke up,'' Stallone told an interviewer in Redbook magazine. In filming the new movie, ``there was one scene in which we both became totally unglued,'' Stallone said. In the scene, Stallone's Rocky character told his son's character ``that no matter what, I'll never desert him,'' he said. ``I really lost it in that scene,'' Stallone said. ``Then Sage started to lose it because he'd never seen his father cry. ``It was all hitting too close to home, and I may take it out of the movie because it's just too emotional.''

--- CHICAGO (AP) - Playwright Arthur Miller says America's artists are censoring their own works for the sake of government grants. Such self-censorship allows freedom to be ``killed without a trace,'' Miller said Sunday at a daylong humanities festival called ``Expressions of Freedom,'' sponsored by the Illinois Humanities Council. Miller, 75, whose works include the plays ``Death of a Salesman'' and ``The Crucible,'' said the First Amendment is the artist's ultimate weapon against censorship. ``It simply cuts through all the arguments and prohibits Congress from infringing on our freedom of expression,'' said Mille. ``Censorship is fear, and fear spreads,'' he said in the keynote address. ``Censorship is the most futile of governmental exercises.'' ---

Actress Shelley Fabares says Alzheimer's disease stopped her mother from remembering that she would have preferred suicide to suffering from the affliction that deteriorates the brain. Fabares, currently appearing in the series ``Coach,'' said she learned of her mother's preoccupation with the disease after she had to take over her affairs. ``In taking over her papers, I discovered that she'd been making donations to an Alzheimer's association for years,'' Fabares told an interviewer for Redbook magazine. ``Mother once told my sister that if she ever found out she had Alzheimer's, she would kill herself,'' Fabares said. ``Fortunately, by the time she was diagnosed, she was too far gone to remember what she'd said.'' Her mother had lost the ability to speak lucidly before she deteriorated to the point where she had to be institutionalized in February, the actress said. ``One thing that was so painful for my sister and me was that mother would get very close to our faces, scream at the top of her lungs, then hit her cheeks and point inside her mouth and sob,'' Fabares said. ``You can't get a clearer communication than that of `Help! I'm trapped and dying inside!'''

--- OMAHA, Neb. (AP) - Best-selling author Tom Clancy, whose ``The Hunt for Red October'' and other thrillers are noted for their detail of military technology and combat maneuvers, says an end to war is desirable and possible. ``There's no law of God or nature that says we have to have a conflict anywhere,'' Clancy said Sunday. He is in Omaha through Tuesday to speak at a benefit for the Greater Omaha Chamber of Commerce and the Omaha Public Library Foundation. He also is scheduled to tour Strategic Air Command headquarters with Gen. John T. Chain, the SAC commander, as his guide. Known for being publicity-shy, he reportedly consented to the visit at the urging of Chamber of Commerce President Bob Bell, a retired Navy vice admiral he met at the Pentagon. ``I got hustled very skillfully,'' he said. ``I don't mean to seem ungracious but I have four kids. I'm just domestic, I'm sorry. I think there were two weeks in this year I didn't have to leave home for something.'' --- DETROIT (AP) - A teacher once told Bruce Joel Rubin he'd never cut it as a screenwriter. Now, the writer of ``Ghost,'' the year's top box office draw so far, and ``Jacob's Ladder,'' last week's top draw, is looking forward to his 30th Mumford High School reunion on Thanksgiving weekend. ``He was always interested in movies and he was always a storyteller. I think his real thrill will be meeting that teacher who told him he'd never succeed,'' said Rubin's brother, Gary Rubin, 44, a Detroit-area contractor. ``We are so excited. There's an article about him in our local paper and one in the LA Times calling him the best writer of the year, and I'm going broke buying newspapers,'' said his father, Jim Rubin, 75, who now lives in West Bloomfield Township, north of Detroit. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Singer-keyboardist Dr. John and the New Orleans music he treasures are gaining new audiences after their popularity waned since the 1970s. ``It's doing great with the Neville Brothers, Wynton and Branford Marsalis, Harry Connick Jr. and the Dirty Dozen Band,'' said Dr. John. New Orleans is ``still it's own original place.'' Although he had two hits in the early 1970s - ``Right Place, Wrong Time'' and ``Such a Night'' - he decided to lay low after being dropped by two record companies. Dr. John, born Mac Rebennack as the son of a New Orleans record store owner, saw his ``In a Sentimental Mood'' album snare a Grammy for a duet with singer Rickie Lee Jones on ``Makin' Whoopee.'' His distinctive vocals also can be heard on a number of movie soundtracks, including ``Bull Durham,'' and commercials.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis' Countdown Proceeding Smoothly
DOC.TEXT: The countdown toward this week's launch of the space shuttle Atlantis proceeded without mishap Monday after months of delays caused by fuel leaks and last-minute problems with a spy satellite. NASA plans to send up Atlantis sometime between 6:30 p.m. and 10:30 p.m. EST Thursday, its fifth nighttime shuttle launch. Because the Defense Department flight is secret, the exact time will not be announced until nine minutes before liftoff. NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone said the countdown, which began Sunday night, was proceeding smoothly. ``We don't have any problems,'' she said. Weather forecasts were less favorable. Air Force meteorologists predicted a 40 percent chance of good weather at launch time. As with the six previous Pentagon missions, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration refused to discuss the shuttle's cargo or provide any flight details. The mission is expected to last about four days, during which Atlantis' five astronauts are to deploy a satellite that reportedly will spy on Iraq and other areas. The mission originally was scheduled for July, but was delayed indefinitely after Atlantis sprang dangerous hydrogen leaks similar to those afflicting the shuttle Columbia. NASA temporarily grounded the entire fleet in June. NASA tried three times in late August and September to launch Columbia but it was forced to halt two countdowns because of leaking hydrogen and another because of problems with the astronomical observatory it was to carry. Fueling tests last month cleared both Columbia and Atlantis for flight. NASA set Nov. 9 as Atlantis' launch date, but on Oct. 31 the Air Force delayed the mission because of undisclosed trouble with the spy satellite. NASA plans to launch Columbia two to three weeks after Atlantis' flight. That will enable the space agency to close the year with six shuttle flights, three fewer than planned.

DOC.HEAD: Student March Halted Because of Vandalism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with more arrests reported, Mitterrand reportedly agreeing with students. Pickup 7th, `About two...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-France-Students
DOC.TEXT: An outbreak of violence today forced police to halt a march through Paris by more than 100,000 high school students, the largest protest yet in a campaign for better education. The main throng of marchers was orderly, but several hundred youths on the fringes of the crowd smashed windows, set fire to cars, looted a clothing store, stoned police and attacked journalists. Police made at least 20 arrests and used tear gas and a water cannon to repel troublemakers, many of them masking their faces with hoods or scarves. In dozens of smaller cities across France, more than 150,000 other students joined marches coinciding with the Paris protest. Most were peaceful, but a dozen youths were arrested after vandalism in the eastern city of Montbelaird. As the Paris marchers began to disperse at nightfall, Education Minister Lionel Jospin emerged from talks with student leaders to announce an ``emergency plan'' to improve France's high schools. He said details would be worked out in negotiations involving students and government officials. A separate delegation of 20 students met with President Francois Mitterrand. One of the youths said after the 45-minute meeting that Mitterrand agreed with their demands. Organizers claimed that 200,000 students joined the Paris march. Other observers estimated the turnout at closer to 100,000. About two hours after the march began, Paris Police Chief Pierre Verbrugghe demanded that student leaders order the protesters to disperse. He said the throng would not be allowed to cross from the Left Bank of the Seine River to the planned ending point on the Champs Elysees. Beneath banners demanding more government spending on their schools, the Paris marchers set out from the Place de la Bastille, where revolutionaries stormed the Bastille prison 201 years ago. Their destination was the Rond Point, a traffic circle four miles away on the Champs Elysees. Streets and subway stations along much of the route were closed by police, paralyzing transportation in a large section of central Paris. The dozens of previous student marches and rallies across France over the past four weeks have been peaceful, except for sporadic vandalism blamed by student leaders on provocateurs. Many sidewalk cafes along the march route were closed as a precaution, and police said two youths were arrested after some street vendors were robbed. Verbrugghe said he was deploying 5,000 officers to cope with the march, but they were ordered to avoid force against anyone demonstrating peacefully. Scores of off-duty members of a major police union, wearing civilian clothes, joined student leaders at the head of the march and offered to assist in any negotiations with uniformed police. Also among the marchers were officials of industrial trade unions and several national teachers' associations. Throughout the morning, hundreds of youths poured out of trains at Paris railway stations. In most cases, the out-of-town protesters had either forced their way onto the trains without paying or had obtained discounts of 60 to 70 percent after blockading tracks at provincial stations last week. In Caen, students were allowed to board a train after being asked to pay whatever they could afford. In Lyon, students rented an entire train with $480 raised through public donations during recent protests. And in Grenoble, a regional administrative council provided funds to carry about 1,000 students on a train to Paris. Students arriving in Paris found smiling policemen waiting for them at improvised information booths, telling them where to assemble for the march. The students want more government spending to improve security, upgrade substandard facilities, modernize curriculums and hire more teachers. Many high schools have more than 35 students per class. They have also have demanded greater freedom of expression and assembly.

DOC.HEAD: Monday Was 21st Birthday Of Boy Missing Eight Years
DOC.TEXT: Newspaper carrier Johnny Gosch, missing for more than eight years, would have been 21 Monday and his mother says the pain of not knowing what happened to him gets worse with time. Noreen Gosch's son disappeared Sept. 5, 1982, from a street near his home just as he was about to begin delivering Sunday newspapers. ``Most of the time, I'm really good. I distance myself from the pain, I put it on the shelf,'' said Mrs. Gosch, of suburban West Des Moines. ``But every so often, something will sneak in, a memory, a song. Without realizing it, you're reduced to tears in seconds, it hits so fast. ``I've been through a lot of losses, but it is different when you don't have an answer. ``The longer it goes, you'd think it would be further removed emotionally, but it kind of works the opposite.'' ``We've missed all the years of him growing up, it's painful. We were at a family gathering recently, and a lot of nieces and nephews were there. There are a lot of them Johnny's age. It's real hard going to someplace like that, you see everybody else's kid grew up,'' she said. The most devastating news, she said, was when investigators turned up a false alarm last spring - the body of a man bearing identification of John Gosch was found in Mexico. But it turned out the body was that of a man with the same name and age who had disappeared from Tacoma, Wash., three years earlier. ``We came close to an answer, even though it would have been a bad one. That was real tough. It was hard on us emotionally,'' she said. In the months following Johnny's disappearance, the Gosches raised tens of thousands of dollars to publicize the case and hire private investigators. Mrs. Gosch also renewed her appeal for a Michigan man, released from prison last year after serving time for defrauding the Gosches, to contact the family about possible clues in the case. Robert Herman Meier of Bay City, Mich., contacted them several years ago and asked for money in return for information on the abduction. The Gosches, convinced that Meier was credible, gave him $10,000. Meier later pleaded guilty to fraud and served about 18 months. He as released from an Iowa prison about a year and a half ago. No money was recovered. She said the state parole board will not give them information on Meier's whereabouts, agreeing only to send him a letter inviting him to contact the family.

DOC.HEAD: Mayors Say Cities Deserve More Federal Aid
DOC.TEXT: The nation's big cities need to organize their plea to Washington like a political campaign, a group of mayors said Monday at the start of Urban Summit 1990. ``It seems to us that we need to do a better job of packaging the nature of our problems,'' said Los Angeles Mayor Tom Bradley, one of more than 30 mayors attending the two-day summit in Manhattan. Bradley was joined at a media briefing by San Diego Mayor Maureen O'Connor and New York Mayor David Dinkins, who organized the meeting to help find ways to solve the nation's urban problems. The summit is focusing on issues such as housing, AIDS prevention and treatment, combating drug abuse, improving education and paying for costly projects such as bridges and roads. The mayors complained that the federal government has mandated programs at the local level without providing cities with the money to pay for them. ``Over the last decade, we have lost about 26 percent of the federal support which we once enjoyed,'' Bradley said. ``In addition, more programs have been dumped on the cities. More problems exist in those cities. ``So we've been hit with a double whammy.'' Dinkins just last week announced that he intended to cut 5,400 city jobs to close a $388 million municipal budget gap. Bradley said the mayors are working to package their ideas and present them in such a way that Congress and President Bush can't ignore them. ``We think that we have to run this like a political campaign,'' he said. ``It has to be said over and over again until they finally get the message.'' O'Connor said the cities are asking the federal government to pay their fair share. ``What we're all finding together is that one voice in Washington is not enough,'' she said. ``We need to stand together.''

DOC.HEAD: Letter Mailed During North Pole Sub Voyage Arrives 32 Years Later
DOC.TEXT: A letter sent by a sailor on the first submarine to sail under the ice of the North Pole arrived at his brother's home last week, 32 years after the historic voyage. Denny Breese, now a 56-year-old treasure hunter living in North Carolina, was a 25-year-old seaman when he wrote the letter aboard the world's first nuclear-powered submarine, the USS Nautilus. It was addressed to his younger brother Nick, who lived then at the family's home in Chula Vista, about 10 miles south of San Diego. The letter said, in part: ``This will be short. ... I just found out the mail is leaving the boat in about 15 minutes. I just want you to get this envelope that was stamped from the North Pole.'' Although the letter was sent with a sense of urgency, either rain, sleet, snow, an iceberg or some other force delayed its delivery. Neither Nick, now a 50-year-old salesman who lives in Fort Worth, Texas, nor his brother has lived at the Chula Vista home in more than 20 years. Kathy Atkinson, who lives at the Breese's old address, was surprised when she looked through the mail Thursday and found an envelope that was postmarked: ``USS Nautilus. North Pole. 11:15 p.m. Aug. 3, 1958.'' ``I've heard about this kind of thing happening,'' she said. ``But 32 years later?'' Atkinson and a roommate contacted Breese's father, who still leaves in Chula Vista, and the letter eventually found its way to its intended recipient. ``I'm glad (Nick) got the letter,'' Denny Breese said Sunday from his houseboat in Beaufort, N.C. ``He's certainly going to be surprised.'' The letter was sent with a seven-cent stamp depicting President Woodrow Wilson. It arrived open, but otherwise intact. ``It's impossible to tell where it's been,'' said Mike Cannone, a Postal Service spokesman in San Diego. ``This happens occasionally.'' The 323-foot-long Nautilus was launched in January 1955 and had a crew of more than 100. It made the first transpolar voyage beneath the North Pole on Aug. 3, 1958.

DOC.HEAD: White House Says Bush Might Order Military Action on His Own
DOC.TEXT: The White House pledged today President Bush will work closely with Congress on the Persian Gulf crisis but said he might be forced to order military action on his own in the event of ``unforeseen kinds of provocations.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, addressing concerns raised by Democratic lawmakers, said Bush will work with Congress ``every step of the way. We have no intention of leaving Congress out.'' Fitzwater added, ``He will follow the constitutional requirements, and we would want to consult with the Congress every step of the way. But there are always those unforeseen kinds of provocations that might result in having to move first.'' Congress needs to be involved in any decision to fight, several congressional Democrats said Sunday, several days after Bush announced plans to nearly double the 230,000 troops in the Persian Gulf to provide an ``adequate offensive option.'' ``The last thing we need is to have a war over there, a bloody war, and have American boys being sent and brought back in body bags and yet not have the American people behind them,'' said Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga. ``We've gone that route one time. We don't need to do it again.'' Without saying so directly, Fitzwater suggested the Democrats were overreacting. ``Not a shot's been fired. What are these guys talking about?'' he said. Fitzwater added, ``The Congress wants to be vigilant and on top of this - urge caution all the way, and that's appropriate.'' ``It's not for the president by himself to decide whether or not to go to war,'' Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y. said today. ``He has to have the Congress with him, that is the law.'' ``If George Bush wants his presidency to die in the Arabian desert, he's going at it very steadily and as if it were a plan,'' Moynihan said on ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' ``It's as if that great force that was created to fight the Cold War is at the president's own disposal for any diversion he may wish, no matter what it costs. He will wreck our military, he will wreck his administration and he'll spoil a chance to get a collective security system working. It breaks the heart,'' Moynihan said. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., said Bush ``ought to have the broadest possible achievable international consensus'' before launching an offensive. ``The decision to go to war ought to be a shared responsibility, it ought not to be made by one person, even if that person is the president of the United States,'' Hamilton, a key House Foreign Relations Committee member, said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, appearing on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley,'' said Congress must vote before America goes to war. And Senate Foreign Relations Chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., said the United Nations ``should have some input'' before U.S. troops go into combat. Nunn said Bush's new offensive posture was at sharp odds with the original objective of defending Saudi Arabia. ``It is something the military were not given to begin with and were not prepared for,'' Nunn said on the CBS-TV program ``Face the Nation.'' ``And I think the president has a real obligation here - perhaps he can do this, he should - to explain why liberating Kuwait is in our vital interest.'' Sen. Richard G. Lugar, R-Ind., said Congress should vote on a declaration of war before any substantial military conflict with Iraq. And Vietnam-era Secretary of State Henry Kissinger said lawmakers should not be allowed to claim they were kept ignorant as the nation became embroiled in war. Mitchell, reiterating recent statements, said ``Congress and only Congress can commit the nation to war. The president has no legal authority.'' He and House Armed Service Committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., said it was not time yet to call Congress into session for such a debate. They said it would only be ``hypothetical'' because Bush has not yet decided to launch combat operations in the gulf. Pell, also appearing on ``Meet the Press,'' said that unless U.S. lives were at stake, America should not launch a combat drive without congressional approval, ``if not a declaration of war, at least a resolution of authorization.'' Nunn renewed an earlier warning against American involvement in a ground war in the region. ``I think getting bogged down in a ground war there is the last thing we want and plays right into Saddam Hussein's hands and makes our logistics difficulties, which are already present, much more difficult,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Gulf War Could Hurt Bush's Re-Election Chances
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, There was, to include comments by pollster Neil Newhouse; picks up 4th graf pvs, White predicted.
DOC.TEXT: Political analysts assume the American people would rally behind President Bush if the United States went to war against Iraq. But they also predict a prolonged conflict with high casualties could hurt his chances for a second term. ``I think that's going to be the wild card in this next presidential election,'' said John White, a former Democratic Party chairman. ``If we have a war, if there are high casualties, it will be a referendum on George Bush.'' There was bipartisan agreement that if the president decides to go to war, he must do a better job telling the American people why that step is necessary. ``We learned from Vietnam that Americans have to be convinced and sold on a rationale for our involvement,'' said Neil Newhouse, a pollster with the Republican firm headed by Richard Wirthlin. Once involved in a conflict, he said, ``Don't overestimate the patience of the American people and don't underestimate the expectations.'' Newhouse said most Americans expect a war with Iraq would be won as quickly as the actions against Grenada and Panama, which ended within days. White predicted that in the event of war, the Democrats would have to nominate for president in 1992 ``someone who warned or tried to prevent this thing from happening.'' Democrats who fit that description are beginning to emerge, among them Sen. Sam Nunn of Georgia, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. On Sunday, Nunn said that ``the last thing we need is to have a war over there, a bloody war, and have American boys being sent and brought back in body bags and yet not have the American people behind them.'' Nunn frequently is mentioned as a likely contender for the 1992 Democratic presidential nomination. Sen. Robert Kerrey, D-Neb., a decorated veteran of the Vietnam War, also has been an early critic of the extent of the U.S. buildup in the Persian Gulf. ``There's not a lot of mileage in backing off Saddam Hussein,'' said Peter Teeley, a consultant and long-time adviser to Bush. ``Clearly, nobody wants to see American boys in a shooting war, but the fact of the matter is that Saddam's going to have to be dealt with at some point in time, one way or the other.'' After Bush announced last week that up to 200,000 more U.S. troops were being dispatched to the region, speculation intensified that the president was ready to go on the offensive to dislodge Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. Accompanying that was a flurry of discussion of what impact war would have on the next presidential election. Would the expected surge of support for American servicemen in combat be transferred to the president who ordered them there? ``We can say here's what we think will happen, or here's how the American people will react,'' said Democratic pollster Peter Hart. ``Nobody can know. You don't know how you would react; I don't know how I would react.'' Conservative David Keene said the impact of a war on the 1992 elections would ``depend on how the war goes and how well the president is able to articulate his reasons for taking that step. I think the public will support a winning military effort if it isn't too costly or too long if they undersand the reasons for it. ``The problem at this point is that we've gotten ourselves bogged down over there for a long period of time with the president issuing conflicting reasons and rationales for our being there. Sometimes it's to deter aggression; sometimes it's energy; sometimes it's democratic values.'' ``Even a victory with high casualties will probably destroy his presidency,'' said White, who had an insider's view of the devastating impact of the Middle East on Jimmy Carter's presidency. ``He can take some casualties if he's showing that we're winning and if there's a quick end to it,'' said White. ``But if it's a stalemate, he can't take casualties and if it's a loss, he can't take casualties.'' ``The world is going to hold its breath hoping that Saddam Hussein backs down,'' said Mike McCurry, a consutant and former communications director of the Democratic National Committee. ``If he doesn't, there is going to be a war and there are going to be U.S. casualties. ... Opposition will rise naturally to military action unless he's made a good case on why we're going to have make some supreme sacrifices.''

DOC.HEAD: British Diplomat Expelled from Baghdad
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A diplomat at the British Embassy in Baghdad has been expelled and Britain has retalitated by kicking out an Iraqi diplomat in London, the Foreign Office said Monday. The Iraqi government said James Tansley, a second secretary at the British Embassy used ``inappropriate language'' to demonstrators at the diplomatic compound in Baghdad. Tansley, 28, a second secretary at the embassy, was given 10 days to leave Iraq, the Foreign Office said. The Foreign Office said it notified the Iraqi Embassy in London that an official of comparable rank must leave witin 10 days, and that second secretary Wajdi Marjan was being expelled. A Foreign Office spokesman said Tansley, who has been in Baghdad since early last year, ``said something that for one reason or another the Iraqis felt was inappropriate'' Tansley was among diplomats who visited Kuwait in the early days of the invasion to try to assist British citizens. But the Foreign Office stressed this seemed to be unconnected with the decision. Demonstrations have been taking place regularly outside the British Embassy since shortly after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. British diplomats regularly receive petitions from demonstrators. Shortly after the invasion, Britain announced the expulsion of the Iraqi military attache staff in r. As director of operations at MCA Manufacturing Corp.'s record and tape plant in Gloversville, N.Y., Hornung runs one of handful of plants left in the country that still manufacturers vinyl records. Slug BC-Record Factory. By Business Writer Leslie Zganjar. Moving Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Nov. 19. With LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: A ZEN FOR BUSINESS: Monk Tycoon Builds Buddhist Empire
DOC.TEXT: TAIPEI, Taiwan - Hsing Yun fled China in 1949 with only his grey robe and cotton shoes. Today, he is a millionaire monk, praised by some as a philanthropist, reviled by others a mail-order preacher. He has more than 400,000 disciples in Taiwan, 27 monasteries around the world and assets valued at more than $400 million. Slug BC-Millionaire Monk. By Annie Huang. DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Protest Spreads, Report Shots Fired
DOC.TEXT: Former Contra rebels and supporters on Monday blocked roads to two more towns in a spreading protest of President Violeta Chamorro's administration. Riot police using tear gas tried to destroy one roadblock but were forced to withdraw when the people manning the barricades shot at them, the Roman Catholic Church's radio station Radio Catolica reported. The reported shooting took place near Boaco, 56 miles northeast of Managua, Protesters also blocked the road leading to San Rafael del Norte in northern Nicaragua. Presidential spokesman Danilo Lacayo said despite the breakdown of weekend negotiations between Mrs. Chamorro and mayors of 16 towns in southeastern Nicaragua who support the protest, the government is still willing to negotiate. ``Whenever they decide they want to talk, we're here,'' Lacayo said. The mayors had not yet responded to a proposal by Mrs. Chamorro to hold a meeting Wednesday in the southeastern town of Juigalpa to discuss their demands, Lacayo said. For the last 10 days, former Contra rebels and supporters have placed barricades along the Rama road, the only overland connection between the rich southeast agricultural region and the rest of the nation. The negotiations broke down early Sunday after 10 hours, when the mayors Wyss predicted that fixed-rate mortgages, which stand just above 10 percent nationally, could dip to 9.5 percent in coming weeks. Many economists believe that a recessionary economy would also help to push interest rates lower because of sluggish demand for loans. Michael Evans, head of a Washington forecasting company, said he expected the recession to last through most of 1991. ``The unemployment rate will keep rising all year long with the economic downturn lasting for four to five quarters,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives In Turmoil Over Potential Move To Oust Thatcher
DOC.TEXT: Michael Heseltine, a flamboyant former defense secretary, has two das left to decide whether to attempt the once-unthinkable: ousting Margaret Thatcher as Conservative Party leader and thus prime minister. The crisis has thrown the party's normally well-disciplined legislators into turmoil. And suddenly all bets are off. With a mixture of behind-the-scenes threats, promises and cajoling, Thatcher loyalists and Heseltine supporters are taking soundings, adding up pledges and consulting crystal balls. Some Heseltine supporters claim they are within sight of the 159 votes needed to force a second ballot among the 372 Conservative legislators in the House of Commons who elect the party leader. The leader of the party with a majority in the 650-member Commons is automatically the prime minister. Mrs. Thatcher's supporters are seizing on everything from the Persian Gulf crisis to the sheer dominance of the woman who has led the party for 15 years and put her stamp on the nation through 11 years in power. The nomination deadline is noon Thursday and if there's a challenger, a secret ballot will be held Nov. 20. Under the rules, Mrs. Thatcher must get 50 percent of the votes cast and be 15 percent clear of the next placed to avoid a runoff. If not, a second ballot with more newcomers would be held a week later. Whatever happens, it promises to be messy for the party. ``The problem is that in effect we have no agreed procedure for getting rid of the prime minister,'' said Denis Kavanagh, professor of politics at Nottingham University. ``It is like a presidential system without presidential elections.'' Heseltine, 57, has stalked Mrs. Thatcher skillfully since quitting her Cabinet in January 1986 in a dispute over his plan to resuce a helicopter-maker, Westland. A tall, handsome, self-made millionaire, he has toured the country addressing party meetings, opening fetes, assiduously avoiding direct criticism of Mrs. Thatcher - and biding his time for a challenge. The routine has kept him the most instantly recognized politician in Britain after Mrs. Thatcher - and also, polls suggest, the favorite to succeed her. The party leader is elected annually in November. Since Mrs. Thatcher ousted Edward Heath when her party was in opposition in 1975, she has been re-elected unopposed apart from a feeble challenge last year. Rebellious murmurs remained as the Conservative continued to trail the Labor Party for a dangerously long 16 months, mainly because of economic troubles. The latest spark was the Nov. 1 resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Sir Geoffrey Howe in protest of Mrs. Thatcher's combative stance with the rest of the 12-nation European Community. Then the pro-European Heseltine struck with a well-publicized letter obliquely criticizing Mrs. Thatcher. But he is wavering about a challenge. ``We have a remarkable leader, she goes through 10 remarkable years, she has a little bad patch and everyone wants her out of the way,'' complained best-selling novelist Jeffrey Archer, a former deputy chairman of the party. ``That, where I come from, is disloyalty and hypocrisy.'' Legislator Peter Temple-Morris, in the Heseltine camp, said the Tories were doomed under Mrs. Thatcher and claimed there were already 120 anti-Thatcher votes secured. ``Anything above 120 and obviously the prime minister's position becomes extremely difficult, to put it mildly,'' he added. Scores of the more discreet legislators are promising support to both sides or saying nothing, aware of the risk of being seen to back the wrong leader. Many believe that a challenge will merely wound Mrs. Thatcher and kill the Tories chances of re-election. However, there's a potential mine of anti-Thatcher votes. They include about 60 worried legislators with wafer-thin majorities in their constituencies and 35 more she has fired from her Cabinets or other government jobs during her 11 years in power.

DOC.HEAD: California Teacher Wins Geography Award
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Harven in last graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: A California kindergarten teacher who created a pen pal program to teach her pupils about the states was named outstanding geography educator Monday. Arlene Johnston of Solana Vista Elementary School in Solana Beach, Calif., was selected from 11 regional winners to receive $10,000 in cash, an inscribed geophysical plaque and geography teaching materials for her entire school. The Excellence in Geography Teaching Award program, established this year by Rand McNally and the National Council for Geographic Education, kicks off American Education Week being observed by schools across the nation and National Geography Awareness Week. Johnston attributed the enthusiasm of the youngsters and their parents for keeping up the momentum of her program, ``Our Friends Across America.'' Her 26 pupils became pen pals with friends or family members representing all 50 states. They hung their letters on the appropriate state on a giant map. To demonstrate the program's success, Johnston's kindergarteners challenged local high school seniors that they could identify the most states on a blank map. The youngsters won, 25 to 21. Officials said nearly 500 elementary and secondary teachers competed for the award. The finalists each received $500, a crystal globe award and Rand McNally teaching materials. They were: Virginia Tyler, Sarasota, Fla.; Mike Mower, American Fork, Utah; E. Harven Tewes, Fort Worth, Texas; William Herman, Noblesville, Ind.; Linda Poff, Princeton, W.Va.; June Ploen and Janet Kirch, Glenview, Ill.; Judy Pearce and Charlene Hamaguchi, Honolulu; Patricia Holmes Finlay, Jamestown, Ohio; June Switzer, Ontario, Canada; and Richard Fisher, Aviano, Italy.

DOC.HEAD: Bishops Urge Restraints On Any U.S. Military Action In Gulf
By GEORGE W. CORNELL
DOC.TEXT: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops on Monday urged restraint to minimize civilian casualties in any U.S. military action in the Persian Gulf crisis. Citing the church's longtime ``just war'' theory in regard to the Middle East situation, bishops from across the country declared: ``The military means used must be commensurate with the evil to be overcome and must be directed at the aggressors, not innocent people.'' This rules out tactics that ``could clearly target civilian lives'' and ``means this war would have to be a limited war,'' the bishops said. They urged that under those circumstances the United States ``stay the course of persistent, peaceful and determined pressure against Iraq,'' using military force as a last resort. The bishops' position was set forth in their affirming of a letter about the crisis sent last week by Archbishop Roger Mahony of Los Angeles to Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Mahony, head of the bishops' international policy committee, later told a news conference that the bishops' stand countenanced military force ``only after every other avenue has been explored and tried.'' ``The situation is fluid and changing daily,'' he said. ``It is our hope that no use of force will be attempted.'' As the bishops began their annual fall meeting, the subject highlighted their discussion and indications were they may have more to say about it. Although affirming the Mahony assessment by a 249 to 15 ballot, they also decided to modify their agenda to consider the issue further. But this was to be behind doors as moved by Cardinal Bernard Law of Boston and upheld by a 126 to 118 vote. In lengthy debate, several bishops argued for open discussion of the matter. ``It's important that we do more,'' said auxiliary Bishop Thomas Gumbleton of Detroit, adding that it was critical to Americans who ``need moral guidance.'' about it. The bishops' affirmed stand firmly condemns Iraq's aggression, the taking of civilian hostages and the ``brutal treatment'' of civilians in Kuwait. In church tradition, the ``use of force is not ruled out absolutely,'' but ``there is a clear presumption against war,'' the bishops said. On other matters at the start of a four-day meeting, the bishops gave preliminary consideration to policy statements on the priesthood, inclusive language in the liturgy and sex education in Catholic schools. Indications were that the latter would evoke considerable controversy. But action on another touchy subject - a proposed declaration on the role of women - was dropped from the agenda. Outside the hotel where the bishops were meeting, a throng of women demonstrated for the right to be admitted to the priesthood. ``Discipleship of Equals'' their black-and-gold banners proclaimed. ``Women Priests,'' ``New Women-New Church'' and ``Women Imaging Christ.'' Such ``imaging'' is what they can't do, says the Vatican in ruling they can't be priests.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Time Inspires Former Congressman To Help Inmates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `He spent...', to CORRECT name of base to Eglin sted Egland.
DOC.TEXT: From minister's son to congressman to prison inmate, Robert Garcia has followed the advice in one of his favorite hymns: ``In good times praise his name and in the bad times do the same.'' And that's the message he wants to share as he embarks on a new career in prison ministry, Garcia said. ``Nothing guarantees a smooth, easy life,'' the 57-year-old Garcia said in a recent interview. ``By knowing God, we have the ability to handle it and that's all we can ask for in life.'' Five months after an appeals court reversed his conviction in the Wedtech Corp. scandal, Garcia has joined Prison Fellowship Ministries, the organization founded by Chuck Colson of Watergate notoriety. ``In terms of their spiritual lives, it's important that inmates understand our relationships with God are the most important thing we have,'' he said. Garcia says his faith has carried him through since January 197 when several Wedtech officers pleaded guilty to paying bribes to obtain military contracts and gave prosecutors names of those they said were involved. The Democratic congressman, who represented the South Bronx neighborhood where Wedtech was located, was among several local politicians charged in the corruption scheme. Garcia and his wife, Jane, were accused of demanding payoffs from Wedtech in return for his influence in Washington. A jury convicted them last year of extortion and both were sentenced to three years in prison with the recommendation they be released on parole after serving six months. Garcia resigned his congressional seat on Jan. 19 after his conviction. He spent 104 days at the minimum-security federal prison at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida before the conviction was overturned in June. The appeals court, which found the jury had not been properly instructed on the law, left open the possibility of a new trial for Garcia and his wife, who remained free while their appeal was being heard. Federal prosecutors decided to continue the case and the Garcias will be retried beginning next month unless a judge accepts their argument that they can't be tried twice for the same offense. Garcia has a wide range of experience with prison life. As a young state senator from the Bronx, he was called on to serve as a negotiator during the bloody uprising at the Attica state prison in 1971. He also served as chairman of the state Senate's Crime and Correction Committee, which required his visiting many of the state's facilities. ``I've come full circle in this thing,'' Garcia said. As a paid consultant with Prison Fellowship, Garcia will help develop a program to match released inmates with churches in their communities and lobby his former colleagues on Capitol Hill on prison reform issues. Garcia said he first got the idea of working for Colson's organization when he attended a Bible study group run by Prison Fellowship. But prison ministry is something he would best like to do from the outside. ``If there was any one time in my life I wanted to yell and scream about how happy I was, that was it,'' Garcia said.

DOC.HEAD: Security Increased At U.S. Universities Following Threats
