Florida, with about 527,000 Vietnam veterans, is the first state to attempt such a project, according to Kaufman, chairman of the Agent Orange Committee of the Vietnam Veterans of Florida. The survey has the backing of national Vietnam veterans groups and individual scientists at the Department for Veterans Affairs, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Centers for Disease Control, Kaufman said. ``There are scientists and epidemiolgists who work for the VA and the EPA who are outraged at this latest CDC fiasco,'' Kaufman told reporters. A congressional study released last month charged that the CDC misspent $6.6 million while conducting a disputed study of the effects of Agent Orange. An estimated 12 million gallons of Agent Orange, composed primarily of cancer-causing dioxin, was sprayed over Vietnam by U.S. troops between 1965 and 1970 to destroy the jungle that hid the enemy. Veterans groups say exposure to Agent Orange has been linked to 19 types of cancer and other health problems, including birth defects. Earlier this year, the VA decided to award compensation to veterans with two rare cancers, soft-tissue sarcoma and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, linked to Agent Orange. Since 1981, some lower-income veterans who believe their health problems are caused by Agent Orange have received VA care, the VA said. But the veterans are a long way from getting the government to acknowledge that Agent Orange has caused lingering diseases in veterans and birth defects in their children, veterans groups say. The CDC has said that military records did not identify veterans who had been exposed to the chemical. ``We're going to provide them with information,'' Kaufman said. He said there are 116 scientists from the VA, CDC and EPA ``who have pledged that if we get them the surveys they will go through them.'' Those scientists, whom Kaufman would not name, also helped write the 116-question survey, he said. The organization has printed only 1,000 surveys thus far. It wants to get 500,000 distributed and returned within six months. Kaufman said it will cost about $3 million to conduct the survey, and that veterans would have to raise money as they go to pay for the project. About 200 surveys were handed out Monday to veterans gathered for Veterans Day ceremonies at the group's Tallahassee headquarters, Kaufman said.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Search For Cause of Stormie's Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 12th pvs, ``She went ...'' to UPDATE with stepfather's remark about Stormie's mother, schoolchildren renaming gym and planting tree. Picks up 13th graf ``Stormie was 6...'' Minor editing elsewhere. ADDS byline.
DOC.HEAD: By CATHERINE DRESSLER
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Doctors conducted lab tests Monday to determine what caused the sudden death of 13-year-old Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient. It will take one to two weeks to complete the tests, including organ tissue cultures to search for viruses or bacteria, said Lynn McMahon, a spokeswoman at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. Stormie went into cardiac arrest and died Sunday morning at the hospital after rapidly declining during the night. She endured organ rejection and hepatitis after her historic double transplant on Valentine's Day 1984 and a second liver transplant in February. ``We've been able to provide better quality of life and longer life for many people'' because of Stormie's ordeal, Dr. Jorge Reyes, staff physician at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh, said after she died. Preliminary autopsy results were inconclusive, but Reyes said that if Stormie had a flu virus, her death could have been caused by a rapid or irregular heartbeat. Transplant patients are susceptible to infection because anti-rejection drugs to protect the transplant weaken the immune system. Stormie was taken from her home in White Settlement, Texas - a Fort Worth suburb - to a Texas hospital Saturday night with a sore throat and fever. She then was flown to the Pittsburgh hospital, which had conducted the transplants. Her condition did not appear serious then, but it deteriorated rapidly, Ms. McMahon said. Stormie was known for her generosity to other patients at Children's Hospital, where Ms. McMahon said it was ``really very solemn'' Monday. ``There's still a great deal of shock,'' Ms. McMahon said. ``She went through a lot of pain, you know, as a guinea pig and as necessity,'' her stepfather, Alan Purcell, said at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport en route to Pittsburgh. ``The pain is over with. She doesn't hurt any more.'' Purcell told hospital officials Monday that Stormie's mother, Lois Purcell, was ``holding up'' despite her grief, said Sue Cardillo, another hospital spokeswoman. Ms. Cardillo said Stormie's body was not being held for further autopsy, but she did not know whether the body had been returned to Texas. Students at Brewer Middle School in White Settlement mourned their classmate, who had attended class there a few weeks in the fall before being forced home by medical problems. The students decided to rename the gymnasium the Stormie Jones Gym and to hang her portrait in the hallway. An oak tree was planted in front of the school Monday as a living memorial to the seventh-grader. Stormie was 6 when she became the first person to receive a transplanted heart and liver at the same time. Since then, University of Pittsburgh hospitals have performed at least 10 other transplants involving the liver and another organ. Most multiple-organ transplants in the United States have been performed at the university's hospitals, the only ones authorized to use FK-506, the experimental anti-rejection drug Stormie was taking. Stormie required the first multiple transplant because her own organs were harmed by familial hypercholesterolemia - a condition in which her body produced blood cholesterol at a rate 10 times higher than normal. Funeral arrangements were pending. A memorial service will be held at the hospital Nov. 21, Ms. McMahon said.

DOC.HEAD: World Leaders Urge Diplomacy; Arab Nations Work Toward Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with closing oil, gold, Dow prices, Fowler comment, New Zealand hostages to be freed. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2,3
DOC.TEXT: Demands grew Monday to let diplomacy rather than military force help solve the Persian Gulf crisis, and Arab nations discussed holding an Arab summit that Saddam Hussein has said he might attend. Oil prices fell $2.02 a barrel, closing in New York at $31.87, as traders decided that rising supplies posed a greater immediate threat than war. Gold fell $4.10 an ounce in New York, closing at $382.30, and the Dow Jones industrial average soared 51.74 points to close at 2,540.35. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said Egyptian soldiers would not enter Iraq, even if U.S. and other troops attacked. But he said his troops would enter Kuwait as a peacekeeping force. In Washington, lawmakers urged the U.S. administration to back away from its war rhetoric. ``If George Bush wants his presidency to die in the Arabian desert, he's going at it very steadily and as if it were a plan,'' said Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater complained, ``Not a shot's been fired. What are these guys talking about?'' Fitzwater said President Bush would work closely with Congress on the crisis, but might be forced to order military action on his own in case of ``unforeseen kinds of provocations.'' King Hassan II of Morocco on Sunday proposed he host an Arab summit within the next week as a ``last chance'' for peace. Some nations endorsed that call, and Saddam said he might attend if consulted on the timing and agenda. Saddam said the summit should discuss linking the Arab-Israeli dispute to any decision over Kuwait, which Iraq invaded and occupied on Aug. 2 in a dispute over land, oil and money. Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, meeting Monday in Baghdad, backed the call for an Arab summit. But several Arab leaders had not responded and prospects for an early summit seemed dim. The last Arab summit in August ended in disarray. Mubarak last week rejected a proposal by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for an Arab summit, saying the Arabs were too divided to hold a productive session. Also controversial was Saddam's insistence on tying his withdrawal from Kuwait to withdrawal of Israel from the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The United States and its allies have said Iraq must withdraw unconditionally from Kuwait and the issues must be dealt with separately. In Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, Secretary-General Abdullah Bishara of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council said Morocco's call for an emergency Arab summit came too late. Bishara, a Kuwaiti national, told a news conference war was inescapable because ``diplomacy alone will never achieve its objectives.'' He said war was the only language the Iraqis understood. The council groups Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates and Oman. New Zealand's former prime minister, David Lange, said Tuesday that all 16 New Zealand hostages in Iraq and Kuwait will be released, probably within two days. Lange spoke at a news conference in Wellington after returning from talks in Baghdad. He told Radio New Zealand on Monday that U.S. criticism of his trip was a ``great help'' in his negotiations in the Iraqi capital. Washington says the stream of senior statesmen pleading for the release of their citizens is a propaganda victory for Saddam. The United Nations imposed trade sanctions on Iraq to force its withdrawal from Kuwait, but two Middle East experts in Washington said it was unlikely sanctions alone would work. In a report for the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, Patrick Clawson said he believed Iraq could survive sanctions through late 1991. James A. Phillips of the Heritage Foundation said that for Saddam, withdrawal would mean ``a humiliating defeat that will threaten his personal power and perhaps survival.'' The United States has deployed 230,000 troops in Saudi Arabia as part of a more than 300,000-strong multinational force arrayed against Iraq, and Bush last week announced plans to send about 200,000 more soldiers. When Secretary of State James A. Baker III visited Cairo last week, a senior U.S. official said the United States was confident Egypt would fight alongside U.S. forces if war broke out. But asked by his party's newspaper, Mayo, if Egypt would send troops to Iraq following a U.S.-led attack, Mubarak said: ``No, we have nothing to do with Iraq.'' But if the anti-Iraq allies invaded Kuwait, he said, ``We do not mind at all entering Kuwait as peacekeeping forces ... although I do not hope for this day at all.'' Following Bush's announcement, the tone in Congress shifted from cautious support to apprehension. Democratic Sen. Wyche Fowler said Monday in Albany, Ga., that Congress should reconvene after Thanksgiving to debate the issue and to better define America's goals. Moynihan warned Bush against any U.S. attack on Iraq without Congress' sanction. ``He will wreck our military, he will wreck his administration and he'll spoil a chance to get a collective security system working,'' Moynihan said of Bush. America's Roman Catholic bishops, at the opening session of their annual fall meeting, also called for strong limitations on any use of military force.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Mike Weakens as It Hits Philippines
DOC.TEXT: The strongest typhoon of the year slammed the central Philippines with winds up to 150 miles per hour Tuesday. There were no immediate reports of casualties or damage, relief and rescue officers said. At 8 a.m. (7 p.m. Monday EST), Typhoon Mike was centered over the northern tip of Cebu island, about 320 miles southeast of Manila, the weather bureau said. Senior forecaster Daniel Dimagiba said the wind speed weakened to 125 mph as the storm passed over Leyte island, just east of Cebu, at about 2 a.m. The storm was moving west-northwest at 20 mph, Dimagiba said. Maximum storm alerts had been raised in five islands in the area and lower warnings in the southern tip of Luzon island, where Manila is located, he said. Seas were dangerous and Philippine Airlines canceled 54 domestic flights from Manila and Cebu. International flights were unaffected. Authorities advised residents the Samar and Leyte island coasts and the northern region of Mindanao to move to higher ground. Classes were canceled in most of northern Mindanao and the central Visayas region. The typhoon is the 14th and strongest to hit the Philippines this year. About 20typhoons hit the country yearly. Before striking the Philippines, Mike had left a large path of destruction on Palau island over the weekend. It toppled toppled trees, devastated crops and battered buildings in Palau over the weekend. Electrical power was among the services knocked out Saturday when winds up to 172 mph swept through Palau's northern islands. The typhoon caused no known serious injuries, but it dumped nearly 10 inches of rain in Koror between Saturday afternoon and Sunday morning. The winds leveled as much as 90 percent of the major crops of bananas and coconuts. A serious health problem could develop in Koror because sewers were backing up into some homes, an official said. Before hitting Palau, the typhoon caused minor damage on Yap, in the Federated States of Micronesia.

DOC.HEAD: King Holiday Opponents Predict More Votes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Two King ...' to include details on effect of ballot defeat on state's economy; picks up 3rd graf, `Democratic Gov. ...' SUBS 11th graf, `National Football ...' to include governor's estimate of lost revenue if Super Bowl is moved from Phoenix; picks up 12th graf, `Fiesta Bowl ...'
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of a paid Martin Luther King holiday for state employees promised Monday they would take out recall petitions against any lawmakers who try to pass a King holiday without submitting it to voters. Two King Day holiday measures were defeated in last week's election, and the state's pocketbook is already taking the strain. Tour groups have canceled reservations for conventions or stays at hotels in protest, and football authorities have recommended moving the 1993 Super Bowl to another state. Democratic Gov. Rose Mofford said through a spokesman that she would consider calling a special session of the lame-duck Legislature if lawmakers assure her they will pass the King holiday by a two-thirds vote and thereby block any chance at another public referendum. ``That is nothing more or less than the mentality of a banana republic,'' said Tempe architect Julian Sanders, a leading King Day opponent. ``The American democratic process is ... we go to the polls and accept the will of the majority.'' Other King Day opponents, calling themselves the ``No-No Committee'' said they were willing to support a Civil Rights Day if voters got the final say but would oppose any holiday with King's name attached to it. ``Anything short of a vote by the people is immoral and illegal,'' committee chairman Bob Rose said. Arizona law gives voters the right to gather signatures and demand a referendum on most bills that clear the Legislature. The Legislature can abridge that right if 20 members of the 30-member Senate and 40 members of the 60-member House agree that it is an emergency measure. Supporters of the paid holiday have never had two-thirds support for any of their proposals in the past, but Mofford press secretary Vada Manager said Monday that Mrs. Mofford believes lame duck lawmakers who have retired or been defeated might be more willing to vote for the holiday now, knowing that they no longer face the wrath of voters. Mrs. Mofford also believes that some lawmakers may change their minds and support the holiday because the economic effects of not having one are expected to be devastating, Manager added. ``There is now a domino effect of lost tourism, lost conventions and a lost Super Bowl,'' he said. ``We're taking a beating nationally image-wise.'' National Football League Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said Wednesday he will recommend that the league's owners move the 1993 Super Bowl from Phoenix because of the King vote. The governor has estimated that losing the Super Bowl would cost Arizona $200 million in lost revenue. Fiesta Bowl officials met Monday to decide which schools to invite to the Jan. 1 game at Tempe, Ariz., now that Virginia and Notre Dame have turned down invitations because of the state's stance on the civil rights leader. Arizona already has an unpaid holiday honoring King, but holiday supporters have said it is not enough. When King Day supporters got their first holiday through the Legislature, trading in the paid Columbus Day for a paid King Day, opponents gathered enough signatures to suspend the law until a vote could be taken this fall. Lawmakers then approved a second bill, canceling the first one and creating a paid King holiday while leaving Columbus Day in place. Opponents gathered enough signatures to place that bill on the ballot too. The King-for-Columbus swap was defeated 75-25 last week and the King-and-Columbus bill was defeated about 51-49. Sanders and Rose said they and other opponents of the holiday were motivated by specific disagreements with King, not by racial prejudice. Arizonans ``don't want a holiday in his honor,'' said Rose, who describes himself as Hispanic. ``I oppose a lot of the things that Martin Luther King did, but not concerning civil rights,'' Rose said. ``He was an immoral man.'' Rose and Sanders both cited disclosures that King may have plagiarized school work and longstanding complaints that FBI files on King remained under seal. New Hampshire and Montana are the only states without any kind of King holiday. Most other states have a paid holiday, although some don't celebrate it every year or make it one of several options from which state workers may choose.

DOC.HEAD: `Shadowlands,' Starring Nigel Hawthorne, Opens on Broadway
DOC.TEXT: ``Shadowlands,'' a new play by William Nicholson, is tasteful but not terribly exciting theater, an evening of intellectual soap opera saved by some superb acting. The expensive-looking British import, which opened over the weekend at Broadway's Brooks Atkinson Theater, started life as a television drama in England and later was expanded by Nicholson into a full-length play. Its broadcast roots show, particularly in its cuddly, almost cute treatment of Oxford dons, cantankerous yet ultimately lovable. The most appealing of all is C.S. Lewis, the shy, incredibly decent man who wrote the best-selling ``Chronicles of Narnia'' and ``The Screwtape Letters.'' ``Shadowlands'' tells the story of the tragic love affair between Lewis and American poet Joy Davidman, a straightforward, direct woman who was one of his biggest fans and eventually became his wife. They first meet at her request, and the acquaintance blossoms into friendship and finally, after she ends an unhappy marriage, romance. Tragedy, specifically bone cancer, strikes Joy just before the first act curtain. The rest of the play deals with the couple's attempt to reconcile their love with her pain. One of the play's main themes is exactly that - ``If God loves us, why does He allow us to suffer so much,'' Lewis asks in the opening scene which takes the form of a lecture by the famous author. Pain, according to Lewis, ``is God's megaphone to rouse a deaf world.'' Without suffering, there is no need for God, the man says. ``We're like blocks of stone, out of which the sculptor carves the forms of men. The blows of his chisel, which hurt us so much, are what makes us perfect,'' he adds. Pain pretty much fills Act 2 with Joy courageously battling the disease before finally succumbing. Her struggle gives Lewis a chance to practice what he preaches, a difficult assignment he accomplishes with remarkable, if predictable, grace. What validates ``Shadowlands'' are the performances of Nigel Hawthorne as the good-hearted Lewis and Jane Alexander as Joy, his late-in-life love. Hawthorne, clothed in rumpled corduroy, is a teddy bear of a man. His portrait of Lewis neatly juxtaposes the man's towering intellectual genius and his innate shyness. There's a joy in watching this retiring, almost life-long bachelor finally admit that he has found love. Alexander has an even harder task, but she manages to bring an edge to a series of dying and death-bed scenes that could be merely soggy and sentimental. Michael Allison gives a beautifully drawn performance as Warnie, Lewis' brother. It's a second-fiddle role but Allison plays it as if he were the leader of the band. The opulent scenery, designed by Mark Thompson, is annoyingly busy - a large translucent screen keeps dropping in front of the settings so scenes can be changed but you still can see the actors and stagehands working behind it. Director Elijah Moshinsky cranks the long play up slowly. The most cartoonish episodes, particularly Joy's dismissal by Lewis' skeptical colleagues, flounder, but by the time Joy dies, the play has achieved a certain amount of poignancy. After her death, Lewis finds solace in his belief in God and the knowledge that there is something beyond the here and now. ``This world that seems to us so substantial, is no more than the shadowlands. Real life has not begun yet,'' he says. And when Hawthorne says it, you really do believe him.

DOC.HEAD: Shining Path Leader Sentenced to 20 Years
DOC.TEXT: The second-ranking leader of the Maoist Shining Path guerrilla group was sentenced Monday night to 20 years in prison after an 18-month trial. Osman Morote, 44, was sentenced in a special tribunal in Lima for terrorism, murder and crimes against the public order. He also was ordered to pay about $4,500 in reparations. At the time of his capture in June 1988, Morote was considered Shining Path's top leader after Abimael Guzman, the group's founder, who has been in hiding since 1979. The special tribunal that sentenced Morote began weighing the evidence in April 1989 and the prosecution completed its case this month. More than 20,000 people have died in political violence since the Shining Path began its war against the government in 1980. The group has a messianic vision to transform Peru into a rural-based communist society.

DOC.HEAD: Emperor Akihito Formally Ascends to Throne
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with worse violence feared still to come. Picks up 5th graf, `Many Japanese...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TOK13,16,17,21,22,23,30,34,39,40,47; LaserColor TOK124
DOC.TEXT: Emperor Akihito formally became Japan's new monarch in all-day enthronement ceremonies that were marred by dozens of terrorist attacks, and national TV said Tuesday that police fear more radical violence is likely. The rites on Monday marked the beginning of nearly a month of festivities surrounding Japan's first coronation in 62 years. Akihito performs the most controversial ritual, a communion with the gods of Shinto, on the night of Nov. 22-23. Government-run television said police will review security measures before then because their great mobilization on Monday failed to stop numerous leftist attacks. The only police reaction was to note that Monday's ceremonies went off without disruption or delay. Just one injury was reported. The enthronement celebrations, featuring prayers to the sun goddess and other rituals dating to ancient times, have drawn criticism from groups that believe government funding for them is unconstitutional. Many Japanese ignored the ceremonies, taking advantage of the special enthronement day holiday to take weekend trips and crowd golf courses and driving ranges. One poll suggested nearly half of all Japanese were not interested in the enthronement. Foreign dignitaries traveled from 158 countries for the ceremony, which U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar called an event of ``great sobriety and dignity.'' The visitors included Vice President Dan Quayle and Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu led more than 2,000 guests in three cheers of ``Banzai!'' the traditional wish for longeviy. Kaifu said the guests were ``filled with a mood of celebration.'' For the enthronement, the 56-year-old Akihito wore an imperial silk kimono in a reddish-brown shade only he is allowed to wear, and a black crown of ancient design. He stood under the octagonal canopy of his black-lacquered throne, facing a palace courtyard filled with attendants carrying bows and swords. With him inside the palace's Hall of Pines were 12 princesses and princes. Empress Michiko, dressed in an multicolored court gown with her face painted white, stood motionless at her own throne, at Akihito's side. Crown Prince Naruhito, dressed in bright orange to indicate his status as royal heir, stood closest to his father's throne. The emperor solemnly held aloft the proclamation of his coronation and promised to ``discharge my duties as symbol of the state and of the unity of the people'' under Japan's postwar constitution. The constitution changed the imperial role to that of a national symbol, not sacred sovereign. Later, the imperial household gave a banquet for about 350 guests, most of them foreign royalty or government dignitaries. The menu featured Japanese delicacies. Critics say the coronation and its accompanying rites are based too closely on the traditional religious rituals used for Akihito's father, the late Emperor Hirohito, who presided during Japan's plunge into militarism and World War II. Ultra-leftist radicals on Monday set fires that damaged several Shinto shrines, stopped two train lines and launched mortar-style projectiles at five military bases. Radicals were suspected of involvement in a total of at least 35 incidents, the most ever recorded in a single day. Police said radicals launched 10 projectiles at the palace. All of them missed, and one instead crashed into a locker room at a women's university. One woman was injured while being evacuated from a train. About 37,000 police were mobilized for the ceremonies. Nearly 10,000 officers were on hand for a 30-minute, three-mile motorcade by the imperial couple. About 117,000 Japanese citizens lined the route. During the motorcade's journey, a string of firecrackers went off. Genshu Hanayagi, a dancer well-known for her anti-monarchist views, was arrested in a scuffle that followed. She faced charges of violating traffic laws. Shortly before the motorcade trip began, a 27-year-old man attempted ritual suicide by slitting his belly with a fruit knife in front of the palace. The man's motives were not known. He was admitted to a nearby hospital, but officials refused to comment on his condition.

DOC.HEAD: `Cop Rock' Gets Axed
DOC.TEXT: The warbling police officers on ABC's ``Cop Rock'' will sing their swan song on Dec. 26, the television network said Monday. Cancellation rumors for the highly touted, but little watched, series circulated for weeks. Until Monday, ABC had steadfastly denied it planned to ax the innovative program by ``Hill Street Blues'' and ``L.A. Law'' creator Steven Bochco. ABC issued a brief statement announcing the series' demise. Entertainment president Robert Iger said Bochco ``delivered a daring and brilliantly produced series, one all of us at ABC are proud to be associated with.'' ABC said it will announce a replacement later. The new fall show premiered with a bizarre blend of singing cops, a mayor on the take, an officer who dispensed with a cop killer by murdering him and a drug addict who sold her baby for a fix. Bochco called it the most brilliant thing he's ever done. ``I'm as proud of this as anything I've ever been involved in,'' Bochco said Monday in a telephone interview. ``It's tough to look at those kind of ratings and not be surprised when they call and say `Look, we hate this as much as you do, but move over.''' Since its Sept. 26 debut, the series dropped to the bottom third of A.C. Nielsen Co. rankings. Asked why viewers did not like his newest show, Bochco said, ``I don't know. It ain't medicine. If they don't like it, you can't force them to watch it.'' The executive producer, who also has the hit comedy series ``Doogie Howser, M.D.'' on ABC, has a development deal with the network for eight additional shows, including an animated, prime-time program for next year called ``Critters.'' ``I've never felt more supported by a network,'' Bochco said. ``The truth is, I'm not going to go off and pout. I'm not mad at anybody. We work and live in a very commercial and intensely competitive world.'' ``Cop Rock,'' with its live singing and ensemble cast, was an expensive show to produce. At a news conference a few weeks ago dominated by questions about ``Cop Rock,'' Iger said there were no imminent cancellation plans.

DOC.HEAD: Sergeant Who Killed Wife is Turned Over To U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Dutch authorities handed an Air Force sergeant over to U.S. military authorities Monday after they promised not to execute him for killing and dismembering his wife. Staff Sgt. Charles D. Short, 34, of Highwood, Ill., was delivered to the 32nd Tactical Air Force Squadron in Soesterberg, said JusticeMinistry spokesman Victor Holtus. That ended a two-year battle over which country had the right to try Short. In 1988, a Dutch court sentenced him to six years in jail for slaying his Turkish-born wife, dismembering her and dumping the remains in plastic bags. The Dutch High Court ultimately overturned the sentence, saying authorities here had no jurisdiction over the U.S. serviceman. But in a separate ruling in March, the High Court said Short could not be surrendered to the United States as long as he could face the death penalty. U.S. military authorities issued a written guarantee that Short would not be sentenced to death, Justice Ministry officials said. The Dutch have no capital punishment and refuse to extradite anyone who could be executed elsewhere. Holtus said it wasn't known where Short would ultimately stand trial.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Won't Discuss Distribution System, Strikers Hand Out `Real News'
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News intensified its efforts Monday to get the tabloid to readers while its striking employees counterattacked with a publication telling their side of the bitter dispute. The strikers created an 8-page paper called Real News using the out-of-work staff. The publication looks somewhat like the News and has columns, stories and analyses about the strike. Striking driver Don Robertson said 200,000 copies were distributed Sunday and 250,000 more would be on the streets by Tuesday morning. The unions planned to keep up their public relations blitz Tuesday with a breakfast with legislative leaders who support their strike. Meanwhile, the Daily News ran ads over the weekend calling for people willing to distribute the paper to come to the News Building on Monday. A spokeswoman for the paper would not discuss the distribution system. She also would not provide circulation figures, which Publisher James Hoge said last week was at 400,000 daily, compared to pre-strike levels of 1.09 million. Street hawkers, some of them hired from among the homeless, were seen around Manhattan Monday at sites where the paper has had trouble distributing during the strike. Many vendors have refused to sell it, while others claim they have received no deliveries. The strike began Oct. 25 after a dispute in which some drivers walked off the job. The News brought in replacement workers that night and said that 60 union drivers were out of a job. The shutdown spread to other unions, which have said the paper engaged in unfair labor practices, a charge the News denies. There are about 2,100 striking union employees. The paper has continued to be published by management, members of the Newspaper Guild who crossed the picket lines and replacement workers. Meanwhile, there were reports of violence and intimidation of news dealers and union charges that the paper has hired ``goons and thugs'' to attack them. As of Sunday, the police reported 151 incidents related to the strike, with 74 arrests and four police officers injured. While the News says it has held onto its advertisers, the city's other two daily tabloids have picked up significant amounts of advertising since the strike began.

DOC.HEAD: Flooding Eases, New Storm Worries Emergency Crews
DOC.TEXT: Rain-swollen rivers receded Monday but some of the hundreds of people chased from their homes by flooding last week were warned to wait before returning home. A new storm was on its way. Gov. Booth Gardner proclaimed a state of emergency for Whatcom, Skagit, Snohomish, King and Grays Harbor counties on Sunday. The proclamation directs state workers, equipment and money to local governments to help them cope with the flooding. Western Washington was drenched between Thursday and Saturday by a deluge that poured more than a foot of rain in some mountain places. The rains, riding on a subtropical storm track dubbed the ``Pineapple Express,'' filled and spilled over rivers with near-record flood levels. On Monday, floodwaters receded after two days of clear skies and warm temperatures. No injuries were reported in the floods, but more than 600 people were forced from their homes. Property damage was expected to reach tens of millions of dollars. Many evacuees were home again by Monday. But residents of Fir Island on the Skagit River delta, about four miles southwest of here and 40 miles north of Seattle, were warned to stay away a little longer, said Dave Brookings, Skagit County assistant flood control engineer. The National Weather Service predicted another inch or two of rain starting Monday night. ``We're saying, before you spend a lot of money going through cleanup operations and that sort of thing, let's ride out this next little storm,'' Brookings said. Crews were already at work sandbagging along the lower Skagit and Snohomish rivers Monday and repairing levees, said Mark Stewart of the state Department of Emergency Management.

DOC.HEAD: Jazz Choreographer Vic Upshaw Dead at 50
DOC.TEXT: American choreographer Vic Upshaw, who brought modern jazz styles to France in the mid-1960s, has died in Paris of a long illness, his family announced Monday. He was 50. Upshaw died of a serious stomach disorder Nov. 5, according to a spokeswoman for a dance society he worked with. Born in Birmingham, Ala., in 1940, Upshaw played minor roles in the 1958 film version of ``South Pacific'' and in actress Judy Garland's version of ``A Star is Born'' before moving to France in 1964. Upshaw designed new routines for the Blue Bell Girls at the famed Lido cabaret. His own dance group, the Vic Upshaw Six, was a staple for years on French television variety shows. He taught steps to some of France's best-known show business personalities, including Catherine Deneuve, Sylvie Vartan, Pierre Mondy and Jean-Claude Brialy. In recent years, Upshaw had brought French cabaret styles to the other side of the Atlantic, splitting his time between homes in Paris, Los Angeles and Hawaii. Upshaw was buried last week in Les Batignolles, a suburb of Paris, his family said. No other details about his illness or his survivors were disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Burmese Pro-Democracy Party May Form Provisional Government
DOC.TEXT: Rebel leader Tin Maung Win said Monday that his guerrilla organization has asked Burma's largest pro-democracy party - hard hit by arrests - to form a provisional government in rebel-held territory. Tin Maung Win is general secretary of the Democratic Alliance of Burma, composed of 22 ethnic minority and dissident groups and the biggest rebel organization fighting the Rangoon government. He spoke on the eve of a meeting between his alliance and members of the National League for Democracy. The League won a big victory in general elections in May but the ruling military junta refused to relinquish power. Last month the military arrested four of the League's few remaining Central Committee members and raided League offices throughout the country. The military also moved against dissidents among Buddhist clergy, raiding monasteries and arresting monks. The rebel organization controls about one-third of Burma, mostly areas bordering Thailand, Bangladesh and China. Speaking at the major rebel stronghold of Manerplaw, along the Thai-Burmese border, Tin Maung Win said of his proposal: ``This government would only be a temporary one, until the NLD can stand on its own two feet and declare a legitimate government in Rangoon.'' A nationwide pro-democracy movement in Burma was bloodily crushed by the military in September 1988. Aung San Suu Kyi, a major figure of that movement and a leader of the League, has been under house arrest in Rangoon since July 1989. Amnesty International, the world human rights organization with headquarters in London, said last week it had reports of widespread torture of political detainees in Burma. A team of U.N. human rights investigators left Burma on Sunday, but diplomats stationed in Rangoon said its activities here were severely restricted by the military. The alliance chief fear exists that the ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council would totally outlaw the League, and so it was being offered ``sanctuary in the liberated zone.'' ``The NLD cannot function in Rangoon any more, let alone form a government,'' he told reporters. ``The ... (state council) has no intention of transferring power and continues to suppress any moves toward democracy and so we have an obligation to the Burmese people to take a definite course of action.'' How many League members had fled to rebel-held areas was not known, but scattered reports said both party members and monks had fled the cities to avoid arrest. A dozen ethnic minority groups long have fought the central government, demanding more autonomy. Since 1988, students and others fleeing repression have joined them in the interior.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Circus Performs New Act: Baby Born in the United States
DOC.TEXT: The newest member of the Moscow Circus is being treated by the rest of the troupe as another symbol of newfound Soviet freedom. Katia Stepanov, born Nov. 3 in Houston, is believed to be the first child born to members of a Soviet circus touring the United States. She has dual citizenship in the Soviet Union and the United States and has 18 years to decide which one she prefers. ``I am proud my daughter gave birth to her daughter in America - in a free country. I would like to see my granddaughter grow up in the country where she was born,'' said grandmother Olaih Abakarov, who first entered the circus ring at age 5 and is still with the troupe. Katia's mother, high-wire performer Malvina Stepanov, and her father, Sasha Stepanov, a member of the Chernyefskys' tumblers, married last year while on tour in Texas. Stepanov was back in the ring when the circus performed through Sunday at The Palace of Auburn Hills, north of Detroit, but his wife and their daughter will rest before rejoining the troupe. The Moscow Circus is a collectively owned circus not under government control and was allowed to leave the Soviet Union to tour on its own. Mrs. Stepanov's father, Akhmed Abakarov, joked through interpreter Marina Mirnaya that he might need an interpreter one day to talk to Katia. ``I'm very happy to have a granddaughter born here,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Guerrillas Kill Five Children in Ambush
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas killed five children and two policemen Monday when they ambushed a police vehicle, authorities said. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, ambushed the police vehicle on a bridge near the southern town of Algeciras, according to a police statement. The rebels apparently thought the vehicle was carrying policemen. Instead it was being used to transport boys and girls who were receiving instruction under a youth auxilary police program. Four children also were wounded. On Saturday, the FARC joined another guerrilla group, the National Liberation Army, or ELN, in carrying out the biggest rebel offensive so far this year. The army announced Monday that the rebel death toll from the fighting in two northern Colombian towns had risen to 26 after four more bodies of guerrillas were found in a common grave. Rebels retreating Saturday from the towns of Taraza and Caceres were carrying several more dead and wounded with them, according to official statements. Nine soldiers and a police officer also died in the battle, which took place days after the two guerrilla groups offered to enter peace talks with the government of President Cesar Gaviria. A government statement said the attack had convinced it that such talks were impossible until the rebels demonstrated their desire for peace through action. The FARC and the ELN are the country's oldest and most active guerrilla groups. Another rebel group, the National People's Army, has maintained a cease-fire while talking peace with the government. Leaders of the group have said it will disarm in December.

DOC.HEAD: Poland, Germany to Sign Border Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Germany and Poland announced they will sign a treaty Wednesday affirming their border on the Oder and Neisse rivers, laying to rest one of the most intractable disputes of the post-World War II epoch. German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki met last Thursday on the banks of the Oder and agreed to settle the issue quickly, to begin forging friendly ties between Poland and the newly reunited German state. Foreign ministers Hans-Dietrich Genscher of Germany and Krzysztof Skubiszewski of Poland are to sign the treaty in a ceremony still being arranged in Warsaw. ``This is a historic event, closing a certain chapter,'' government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska told the state news agency PAP on Monday. ``Only a border which is finally confirmed can become a border that unites, not divides.'' She said that ``as of Wednesday, in planning Polish-German cooperation, we will look only to the future.'' In the treaty, Germany abandons claim to 40,000 square miles of its former territory in East Prussia, Pomerania and Silesia that was added to western Poland after the war - making up for a greater expanse of land in the east ceded by Poland to the Soviet Union. Further details were being kept private until after the treaty is signed, Wladyslaw Klaczynski, spokesman for the Polish Foreign Ministry, said. The acquired lands make up about one-third of today's Poland, including such major cities as Wroclaw, Szczecin and Gdansk, which was the German-speaking free city of Dantzig between the world wars. By insisting the Polish border be moved so deeply into former German territory, Soviet dictator Josef Stalin compensated for his own seizure of Polish lands, punished Germany for World War II and helped bind Poland to Moscow as the ultimate guarantor of its western frontier.

DOC.HEAD: Precede SINGAPORE
U.S., Singapore Agree on Use of Military Bases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with TOKYO date, ADD Philippines background. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle and Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore signed an agreement Tuesday under which U.S. armed forces will have increased use of military bases in Singapore. ``The agreement will permit the U.S. Air Force to send aircraft to Singapore several times each year on training deployments of several weeks each,'' a U.S. Embassy statement said. More U.S. Navy vessels will also visit. The statement said the increase will start in three to six months. The agreement was signed four days after the latest round of talks between U.S. and Philippine officials on the future of major U.S. military facilities in the Philippines. Many Philipine politicians have called for phasing out those six bases, the lease on which expires Sept. 16, 1991. U.S. officials say they want a ``residual'' U.S. military presence in the Philippines in the future. State Department officials have stressed that the planned expanded American use of military bases in Singapore is intended to complement rather than substitute for the continued use of the Philippine facilities, which are among the oldest and largest U.S. bases on foreign soil. Singapore is a small island-state about 1,450 miles southwest of Manila, the Philippine capital. The U.S.-Singapore agreement was described as ``concrete evidence of the determination of the United States to retain a military presence in Southeast Asia for the foreseeable future,'' the embassy statement said. About 95 Navy and Air Force personnel will be assigned to Singapore on a year-round basis and about 75 additional Air Force personnel will rotate through Singapore with each training deployment, the statement said. Negotiations on increased American use of military facilities have been under way for more than a year in Washington and Singapore. Quayle and Lee are in Tokyo for the enthronement of Emperor Akihito.

DOC.HEAD: Baylor President Says He's Ready for Battle With Baptist Fundamentalists
DOC.TEXT: The head of the nation's largest Baptist university said Monday he's tired of being monitored and second-guessed by fundamentalist extremists and he's going to fight to keep the school independent. Control of Baylor University will be the focal topic when the Baptist General Convention of Texas kicks off Tuesday, said university President Herbert H. Reynolds. ``As I understand the Bible, one day I am going to face the Lord. I'm not going to meet 13 other people standing around to take authority. Therefore, I don't need them down here,'' Reynolds said. ``For the first time in 12 years, as far as I'm concerned, on Sept. 21, action was taken to thwart the juggernaut that we have seen in the Southern Baptist Convention,'' Reynolds said. On Sept. 21, Baylor's board of trustees voted 30-7 with one abstention to revise the school's charter, establishing a new board of regents to govern the school. The new board, which evetually will have 24 members, will be elected primarily by the board members themselves with a quarter of the members coming from the board of trustees, which would continue to be elected by the Baptist General Convention. At a news conference Monday, Reynolds said the decision came as a result of continued friction from overzealous conservatives who were threatening to take control of Baylor, the nation's largest and oldest Baptist university. ``We did not seek in any way whatsoever to remove ourselves from the lives of Texas Baptists,'' Reynolds said. ``We have been disenchanted and unhappy with those in this extremist movement and we definitely have sought to distance ourselves from them,'' Reynolds said. ``We simply came to the point that we thought the danger was too great that we might lose our opportunity to exercise the kind of religious freedom that we want as an institution.'' A 25-member committee reviewing the relationship between the Baptist General Convention of Texas and Baylor met for several hours Monday to assemble a report to the convention. ``We're simply trying to get our minds together,'' said Robert Naylor, chairman of the panel and retired president of the Southwest Seminary in Fort Worth. ``I think we'll come out of this beyond our crisis. ``Baylor and the Convention of Texas have existed for 100 years in a bilateral relationship,'' he said. ``Our people support Baylor through the Baptist General Convention of Texas. The relationship has been as identical as family.'' Naylor said the school's action in turning its board of trustees into a self-perpetuating panel, rather than one which had been controlled by the convention, was done unilaterally. ``And that has created much of the chaos,'' he said. ``We were not notified and it was in direct contradiction to the constitution of the Texas Convention, which provides specifically that no agency of the Convention shall change its charter without the prior approval of the Convention. Naylor said the convention over the past 40 years has given the school some $78 million. He said many of the endowments given to the school were made under the belief that the convention would continue to control the school. Reynolds said the school was not going to be bullied over funding to rescind the charter change. ``There's about $6 million a year we have been getting from the Texas Baptists, which is about 5 percent of the money we've been getting from all sources,'' Reynolds said. ``We have been extremely grateful to the Texas Baptist for this money. But we will not subject ourselves to the kind of focus that exists today just to save the money,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Notebook: Chemical Warfare, Labored Greeting, Love That Hot Sauce
DOC.TEXT: The threat of chemical warfare in the Persian Gulf presents special problems for the doctors and nurses assigned to treat those casualties, surgeons general of the Army, Air Force and Navy said Monday. One concern is the contamination of the medical personnel treating the wounded soldiers, the military doctors said in an interview at a meeting of the Association of Military Surgeons of the United States. ``Anytime you treat a patient who is contaminated, more people run the risk of being exposed,'' said Lt. Gen. Monte B. Miller, the Air Force surgeon general. Miller said medical personnel who will be in the field in the Persian Gulf are trained to work wearing the same protective equipment as soldiers in danger of exposure to chemical or biological weapons. Also addressing the convention were Lt. Gen. Frank Ledford Jr., the Army surgeon general, and Vice Admiral James A. Zimble, the Navy surgeon general. Military doctors and nurses have trained for the likelihood that the Iraqis will use germ warfare against Operation Desert Shield troops, the doctors said. ``It isn't something we haven't trained to defend against,'' Miller said. ``It does added a frightening dimension, but we feel like we are well-prepared to handle it.'' He refused to provide many details, but said troops have chemical protective suits and instant injection kits with drugs that block or reverse the effects of nerve gas. For all the dangers faced by the U.S. troops military deployed in the Persian Gulf, maladies like malaria and scorpion stings have not taken the toll feared, the doctors said. ---= ARLINGTON, Texas (AP) - Military food tastes a lot better with hot sauce, a soldier told his mother in a call home to thank her for the care package she'd sent. Taking a cue from Army Pfc. Adam Rochelle, the Persian Gulf Support Group began including several bottles of the Mexican-style sauce in every Christmas box, Rebecca Rochelle said. ``He told me, `Mom, that picante sauce makes those (rations) taste so much better,'' said Mrs. Rochelle. ``They must be dousing everything with picante sauce.'' Twenty packages for soldiers who are miles from major cities were assembled Sunday by members of the support group for Mideast troops who have families in Dallas and Tarrant counties, and more shipments were planned. ``We really want them (the packages) to go to the front-line troops because they don't receive gift boxes unless it is specifically addressed to them,'' said Mrs. Tinker, whose son Grady left with the 82nd Airborne Division for Saudi Arabia. ---= HINESVILLE, Ga. (AP) - Amanda Figueroa's contractions were 12 minutes apart, but she didn't want to miss sending a voice-card recording to her husband, who is stationed in Saudi Arabia. ``Hurry home, honey, I'm in labor,'' she said in the message recorded Friday at Fort Stewart Army Base at Hinesville. On Sunday, with newborn son, Pedro Angel Figueroa Jr., at her side, she recorded another message to let her husband know they were doing fine at Winn Army Community Hospital. Nearly 3,000 people stood in line at Fort Stewart Saturday to record brief holiday messages to family members who are in the Gulf. Some 80,000 U.S. soldiers stationed in the Middle East during the holidays will have the opportunity to hear personal voice messages from family and friends back home. The voice-chip greeting cards are being provided by Marlboro at no charge. ---= SHERWOOD, Ark. (AP) - Some military wives have created a support group called Wives Against Saddam Hussein, or WASH, while they await word of their husbands in the Persian Gulf. WASH consists of women whose husbands are Army reservists from the 321st Material Management Center at El Dorado. The unit specializes in tracking troop supplies. It was deployed to the gulf Oct. 7 and is expected to remain at least six months. ``It's really amazing the closeness that you feel with each other during this situation,'' said Sharon Burnett, who organized WASH. Her husband, Lt. Col. John Burnett, is the commander of the 321st, which includes 200 reservists from Arkansas, eastern Texas and northern Louisiana. WASH meets every two weeks at different locations. About 30 wives attended the most recent meeting at a Camden church, Mrs. Burnett said. The women share the latest news from their husbands and try to ``put the bits and pieces together,'' she said. A potluck meal follows.

DOC.HEAD: Hand-Painted Yarmulkes a Hit
DOC.TEXT: Claire Tannenbaum's hand-painted yarmulkes are a big hit with many Jewish youngsters. Some even sport Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and sports emblems on their skullcaps. Ms. Tannenbaum, a retired bookeeper from Tamarac, personalizes the yarmulkes using acrylic paint and glitter. They sell for $18 in the gift shop of Temple Beth Am's gift shop in Margate, and are being offered in catalogs and many Judaica stores. ``Nobody's asked for Dick Tracy, but somebody did ask for a Bart Simpson,'' she said. ``If you give them something they're interested in, they'll wear it.'' Jewish males wear skullcaps for worship and prayer although they can also be worn outside the synagogue. The typical yarmulke is made of unadorned white or black fabric. Yarmulkes with designs and depictions have grown in popularity in the past five years, said Temple Beth Am's rabbi, Paul Plotkin. Plotkin's son wears one, while the temple's youth director often dons a Ninja Turtle cap or another inscribed with ``Just Do It.'' ``I'm a big FSU fan,'' said 15-year-old Matt Sandak of Coral Springs, whose yarmulke sports a Florida State University Seminole. ``One of my friends has the Chicago Bulls. (These yarmulkes) are a lot better than the plain ones.'' Ms. Tannenbaum, who began dabbling in yarmulke art almost three years ago, initially put the Hebrew alphabet on the caps. Holiday symbols, dancing children and biblical themes soon followed. Now the artwork includes everything from Batman to the Miami Dolphins. ``It's like designer jeans,'' Ms. Tannenbaum said. ``When one person has it, everyone else wants one.''

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of Nov. 5-12:
DOC.HEAD: CNN To Appeal Noriega Tapes Order to Supreme Court
DOC.TEXT: CNN will ask the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn a ban on broadcasting tapes of Manuel Noriega's telephone conversations with his legal team. Constitutional law experts said it could become a landmark case. CNN spokesman Steve Haworth said Nov. 11 that the appeal was being prepared, but he didn't know when it would be filed. CNN had defied an order Nov. 9 by U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler of Miami by broadcasting an excerpt in which the deposed Panamanian dictator spoke in Spanish with a secretary for defense lawyer Frank Rubino. CNN decided for editorial reasons to stop broadcasting the excerpt early Nov. 10, Haworth said. Later that day, the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta upheld Hoeveler's ruling. The appeals court also told CNN to give the seven tapes to the Miami court so it could decide whether the broadcasts would endanger Noriega's right to a fair trial on drug-trafficking charges. Noriega is accused of accepting $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin cocaine cartel. He has been held at a federal prison outside Miami since his surrender to U.S. forces shortly after the invasion of Panama in December. Rubino asked Hoeveler to find CNN in direct civil contempt and fine the network $300,000 for each time it televised the tapes and each time it showed them in the future. CNN accused Hoeveler of bias and asked him to disqualify himself from the case. Floyd Abrams, a New York constitutional lawyer who served as co-counsel for The New York Times in the Pentagon Papers case, said the CNN case could set precedent because rules involving prior restraint have been very clear through the years. ``We've almost totally banned prior restraint,'' Abrams said. ``If the Supreme Court were to uphold the prior-restraint order on CNN, this would be the first time in our country's history that any such court order had been affirmed by the court.'' In the 1971 Pentagon Papers case, the U.S. Supreme Court said the government could not bar publication of classified documents about U.S. involvement in Vietnam. The Times appealed rather than defy a lower court order. George Rahdert, a lawyer at the Poynter Institute of Media Studies in St. Petersburg, Fla., called the CNN case ``an astonishing illustration of censorship,'' but said the network was ``playing with blasting caps'' by defying the judge's order. ``It's rare in general that a news organization of any kind - broadcast, cable or print - would do such a thing,'' said Rahdert, who represents several newspapers. ``It really falls into the category of civil disobedience.'' CNN President Tom Johnson said the case is a classic confrontation between the news media and the government they cover. He said the district court and appeals court construed the case as a conflict between the Sixth Amendment, which provides a defendant a right to a fair trial, and the First Amendment, which provides for freedom of the press. ``There's a more fundamental issue here: reporting the news of possible governmental misconduct,'' Johnson said. ``If CNN can be restrained from airing news about the Noriega tapes, so can any news organization.'' Attorney General Richard Thornburgh said U.S. officials wanted to find out how the tapes were leaked to CNN. ``It concerns us greatly that an apparent unauthorized use was made of these tapes,'' he said. Hoeveler said he had to weigh Noriega's right to a fair trial against CNN's right to freedom of the press. ``It's becoming more and more difficult in this case to assure that both parties get a fair trial,'' he said. CNN's broadcast marked the first time the tapes themselves had been made public, but not the first time their contents were reported. New York Newsday published a story last month based on summaries of the tapes in which unidentified federal sources said it appeared the former Panamanian leader was attempting to organize resistance to the U.S.-supported government of President Guillermo Endara, which replaced his regime.
DOC.HEAD: Newspapers Ask Appeals Court To Publish Restraint Ruling
DOC.TEXT: The Rock Hill Herald and The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer want an appeals court to publish its opinion overruling a federal judge's prior-restraint order so it can serve as a legal precedent. ``The opinion in this case, if published, will provide substantial guidance to lower courts in this circuit, in the event they are requested, or otherwise inclined, to prohibit the news media from publishing information properly obtained during open court proceedings,'' papers filed by the newspapers' lawyers said. If the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals does publish its opinion, it would mean the case could be cited as a precedent in future prior-restraint cases, said David Robinson II, a lawyer for The Herald. ``There's nothing published of recent vintage that deals with open court statements and prior restraint,'' Robinson said Nov. 9. ``We think this would be helpful in the future.'' Unpublished opinions made by the appeals court cannot be cited in legal proceedings, Robinson said. The case began Oct. 31 when U.S. District Judge Charles E. Simons Jr. inadvertently said in open court in Columbia, S.C., that Rock Hill attorney Mitchell K. Byrd was a ``target'' of a drug investigation. When Simons was told that reporters from The Herald and the Observer were in the courtroom, he ordered them not to print his remark. Both newspapers appealed the order and neither printed the name the following morning. The Herald printed the judge's statement about Byrd on Nov. 2 and was later called to court to defend that action. On Nov. 6, the appeals court declared the judge's original order invalid, and Simons dropped his case against The Herald and canceled the ordered court appearance. John Buchan, a lawyer for the Observer, said federal trial judges are bound by precedents in their circuits and therefore would be required to follow this order, if published. ``Having such a precedent will resolve such issues before they reach the appellate court, because the laws will be very clear,'' Buchan said.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Unions Say They're Willing To Accept Pay Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Striking Daily News workers are ready to take the same pay cuts that their colleagues at the New York Post accepted two months ago, the newspaper unions' leader said. George McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, made the comment Nov. 8 after News Publisher James Hoge said union negotiators had offered only small concessions during the 10 months of negotiations that preceded the strike. McDonald, head of the 10-union coalition of workers at both the News and the Post, responded, ``Go back and say to Hoge that McDonald said at a press conference: `We'll match what we gave the Post.''' News spokeswoman Lisa Robinson said McDonald ``should learn that the place for negotiations is at the bargaining table, not at a news conference.'' In September, nine of the 10 unions agreed to nearly $20 million in wage cuts at the Post after owner Peter Kalikow said the only alternative was to close the paper. Many employees agreed to a 20 percent pay cut by switching to a four-day work week. The News' executives say that they are trying to regain lost management control and that the main issues are union overstaffing, featherbedding and other labor abuses that continue to escalate operating costs. The News, meanwhile, stepped up efforts to create a network of people across the city to sell the newspaper despite an aggressive boycott campaign by striking workers. The paper ran a full-page ad Nov. 11 saying it had ``immediate needs for individuals who want to own, operate, and direct their own work force selling newspapers.'' The ad said in large letters: ``UNLIMITED INCOME.'' The poor and homeless have been recruited by the News as sales people. One recruit, Eddy Nadreau, said the News had called the Brooklyn shelter where he lives, offering $6 an hour and a percentage of sales. Strikers fanned out over the city Nov. 12 to start distributing what union officials said were a million copies of an eight-page, free newspaper titled ``Real News.'' All the stories in ``Real News'' were written by writers who have been on strike since Oct. 25. The paper is aimed at giving the strikers' version of the labor dispute. The News has published each day during the strike, but circulation has been a major problem. Some vendors have refused to sell it and others claim they get no deliveries. Some vendors say they have been threatened by striking drivers. Hoge said last week that 600,000 papers were printed each day. Pre-strike circulation was about 1.09 million copies daily, making the News the nation's third-largest metropolitan daily. Strikers, in turn, have reported violence by security forces hired by the News. The chairman of the state Assembly's labor committee said Nov. 9 that he would conduct hearings into the allegations of violence. Assemblyman Frank Barbaro centered his remarks on reports of violence against strikers and did not mention the allegations of threats against vendors or the damage done to trucks and other Daily News property. A group of clergymen went to the News Building on Nov. 7 to urge the paper to return to negotiations with the strikers and to express concern over the economic and social damage of the strike. Speaking for a clerical ``Coalition of Conscience,'' the Rev. James A. Forbes Jr., senior minister of Riverside Church, said the tactic of hiring permanent replacements for striking employees ``seriously undercuts management's claim to be bargaining in good faith.'' The News' spokeswoman said: ``This company is not anti-union. We have negotiated for the better part of this year and continue to be open to the bargaining process.'' Earlier in the week, the National Association of Black Journalists canceled an agreement to sell its membership list to the News after being pressured by the striking unions. The News wanted to use the list to contact potential replacement workers. ``There was a perception that this was seen as furthering management's position. That was never our intention,'' said Thomas Morgan, president of the association. ``We still feel our members have the right to make up their minds about this issue.'' The News also sought to buy membership lists from the National Association of Hispanic Journalists and the Asian-American Journalists Association, but those two groups said they refused. A star Daily News columnist, Mike McAlary, bolted to the rival New York Post on Nov. 10. He said he decided to go ``because of the way the Daily News treated their employees.'' The strike began Oct. 25 with a dispute at the paper's Brooklyn plant. Some deliverers walked off the job; the News responded by bringing in replacement workers. The walkout spread to eight of nine other unions at the paper. The unions, representing 2,100 workers, had been working without contracts since March 30. Labor leaders have charged that the News' owner, the Tribune Co., provoked the strike to try to break the unions or, failing that, close the paper. Charles Brumback, president and chief executive officer of Tribune, denied the parent company is calling the shots in the News' handling of the strike. ``This is a New York situation and it will be solved by the Daily News management in New York,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Murdoch Decries New York Violence and Newspaper Unions
DOC.TEXT: Rupert Murdoch says he's horrified by the rising violence in New York and he partly blames what he calls the shortcomings of the city's union-controlled newspapers. Murdoch said the New York newspaper unions, currently on strike against the Daily News, have been the ``world's worst'' since his company broke the British unions in a bitter labor struggle in the mid-1980s. Calling crime in New York ``quite simply horrible'' and ``unprecedented,'' Murdoch said in a speech Nov. 8 that the city's press was to some extent responsible because ``the media's inhibitions about reporting the crime wave resulted in a sort of false consciousness among the public.'' Murdoch, who has a penthouse overlooking Manhattan's Central Park, owned the New York Post from 1976 to 1988 and still owns WNYW-TV, a local Fox channel. When Murdoch ran the Post he was regularly denounced for what critics called overly sensational coverage of brutal crimes that appealed to the public's ``base passion.'' ``I don't agree that I took it too far downmarket,'' Murdoch said. ``I think I didn't take it downmarket far enough.'' Regarding the city's powerful newspaper unions, Murdoch called them one of the obstacles to better newspaper operations and journalism in the city. ``As you will know, in 1986 I took on the printing unions in Britain, the world's worst, and broke them,'' he said. ``The result has been a silver age for British journalism: newly prosperous papers and wholly new papers.'' With the demise of those unions, he said, ``the New York City unions have succeeded to the distinction of being the world's worst.''

DOC.HEAD: UPI Says It Will Liquidate If Union Rejects Pay Cut
DOC.TEXT: The 83-year-old news service United Press International will be liquidated Nov. 16 if members of the Wire Service Guild reject a 90-day pay cut of 35 percent as the union's leaders are recommending, UPI says. ``At this point we see no real alternative if the vote is against the proposal,'' UPI spokesman Milt Capps said. Pieter VanBennekom, UPI executive vice president, told employees that without approval of the pay cut, ``we cannot ensure that we will have enough cash on hand to meet the payroll and other life-or-death obligations for the next two weeks. Therefore, we will have to take the once-unthinkable step of putting UPI into liquidation.'' Chris Dahl, secretary-treasurer of the guild, said from the union's headquarters in New York: ``There is little doubt in our minds that the company needs a lot of money and it needs a lot of money fast. We are simply saying that they are coming to the wrong people to get that kind of money.'' He said officers of the union were sticking to their recommendation that the contract be rejected, but would submit it to the full membership for a vote. UPI, which has changed ownership three times in eight years, announced Nov. 2 that it had cut management salaries by 35 percent for 90 days and would seek similar concessions from employees represented by the guild as it seeks a buyer. UPI announced in September that it would close bureaus in five states and said Oct. 12 it was dismissing an unspecified number of employees. The company said more employees were laid off Nov. 6 but declined to say how many. VanBennekom said several companies had expressed interest in the news service, which is owned by Infotechnology Inc. along with an interest in Financial News Network. The new heads of Infotechnology said Nov. 7 that they would recommend selling all the company's principal operations. Alan J. Hirschfield and Allan R. Tessler, appointed co-chief executives in a management shakeup Oct. 24, said they had retained the investment banking firm Wertheim Schroder and Co. to seek buyers.
DOC.HEAD: The National Dropping Sunday Edition; Price Relinquishes Control
DOC.TEXT: The National will drop its Sunday issue next month and the publisher of the 9-month-old sports daily has been relieved of day-to-day duties. Steve Hammond, a spokesman for the paper, said Nov. 12 that Peter Price would continue to hold the titles of president and publisher but would be involved with broader issues such as entering new markets. Hammond said Jaime Davila had been brought in to assume Price's operating responsibilities. Davila is a top executive at Univisa Inc., the U.S. subsidiary of Mexico's Televisa entertainment and publishing concern headed by Emilio Azcarraga, the media baron who is The National's biggest shareholder. Hammond also said Diane Morgenthaler, circulation director; Timothy Lasker, assistant publisher; and Daniel W. Correa, finance and administration director, had been dismissed. He said none had yet been replaced but declined to elaborate. Price was unavailable for comment. The development came three days after Editor in Chief Frank Deford said The National would end the Sunday edition and publish five rather than six days a week. He said there might be ``a handful'' of jobs cut but that he hoped the number could be absorbed through attrition to avoid layoffs. ``There is a feeling that as in practically every other business in America we should tighten our belts,'' Deford saidin a telephone interview. He denied the newspaper was in serious financial trouble as it tries to become the first national sports daily in America. ``It's just a matter of belt-tightening,'' he repeated. A day earlier, a source familiar with the newspaper who spoke on condition of anonymity said the Sunday issue was being discontinued because circulation on Sundays had amounted to only about 80 percent of that on weekdays and it had proven harder to distribute the paper on Sundays than on weekdays. The National has been published six days a week, Sunday through Friday, since it was launched Jan. 31. Deford said the last Sunday issue would be published Nov. 25. The newspaper is owned by a partnership led by Mexican media baron Emilio Azcarraga. The paper started with distribution in three markets - New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. Additional editions have been added in San Diego, San Francisco, Dallas, Detroit, Boston and Miami and the paper has announced plans to begin a 10th edition in the Baltimore-Washington area in early December.
DOC.HEAD: L.A. Daily News To Lay Off 4 Percent of Work Force
DOC.TEXT: The Los Angeles Daily News will lay off 4 percent of its workers in a cost-cutting restructuring, Publisher David J. Auger said. The San Fernando Valley-based daily employs about 1,200 people. Four percent of the work force is 48 employees. As part of the restructuring, the Daily News has offered a voluntary early retirement plan to some employees, Auger said Nov. 7. He blamed the layoffs on an economic downturn that has affected newspapers across the country.
DOC.HEAD: Oakland Tribune Seeks 20 Percent Cut in Employment Costs
DOC.TEXT: The Oakland Tribune wants to reduce employment costs by 20 percent as part of a plan to restore the newspaper's financial health. The newspaper said in a statement Nov. 9 that the decrease would be gained ``through a combination of wage and benefit reductions among the company's 600-plus employees.'' The Tribune began presenting the proposal to labor negotiators for 11 bargaining units whose contracts expire on Dec. 31 and to other affected employees. The plan will not affect any workers who earn less than $25,000 a year or earn less than $13 an hour, the statement said. ``The newspaper advertising market is in a national downturn,'' said Robert Maynard, editor and publisher. ``It's now even more critical that we accelerate our plan swiftly and successfully in order to remain competitive.'' The proposal is the second part of a restructuring plan. The first phase, which was announced in June, involved a reduction in force, streamlining management and operational changes.
DOC.HEAD: Strike Deadline Set for San Francisco, San Jose Papers
DOC.TEXT: Union newspaper workers set a strike deadline of 5 p.m., Nov. 16, against the San Francisco Chronicle, the San Francisco Examiner and the San Jose Mercury News. The Conference of Newspaper Unions, which represents 10 unions and 4,500 employees, announced the deadline Nov. 9. The unions have been working without a contract since Feb. 2 and the action was taken in an effort to move talks from non-economic to economic concerns, union officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian Journalists Protest Press Laws
DOC.TEXT: About 300 journalists marched silently down the city's main street Nov. 8 and picketed the presidential palace to protest press laws carried over from the deposed regime of Manuel Antonio Noriega. President Guillermo Endara, who sued a newspaper columnist earlier in the week, met the journalists outside the palace and angrily defended a law under which slander is heavily penalized. ``The president of the republic is a person and is going to demand reponsibility when there is an attempt to damage his honor,'' Endara said. ``That is what I will do in each and every one of the cases, and there is no persecution.'' Then he turned his back and refused to accept a protest letter the journalists had signed. The next day, Endara told reporters he was shocked by the behavior of the journalists in the march. ``... The things they shouted at me were really outrageous.'' He said he refused to receive the marchers in his office because ``they wanted to enter just because they were reporters, as if they were the sacred cows of this republic, and they aren't.'' Endara, installed after the American invasion that overthrew Noriega, filed a slander and damage complaint against Dagoberto Franco of the daily El Siglo. Franco was detained for two days and released on $5,000 bond. Franco had written a column titled ``Endara: The Great Swindle.'' At least 60 formal complaints have been filed against journalists this year, mostly by government officials, the protesters said. Journalists are asking that slander be changed from a criminal to a civil violation. The current penalty is two to five years in jail. In their letter, the journalists said, ``We are here because 21 years of castrated journalism has left us a bitter taste of exiles, threats, pressures and fears that we never want to repeat.'' Panama's constitution provides for freedom of expression but says there are ``legal responsibilities when by any of these media one attacks the reputation or honor of the persons in violation of the social security or public order.''
DOC.HEAD: Jerusalem Post Launches French-Language Weekly
DOC.TEXT: The Jerusalem Post, Israel's only English-language daily, announced Nov. 5 it is launching a French version of its weekly international edition. The 16-page compendium of news and opinion will go on sale Nov. 14 aimed primarily at the 650,000-strong Jewish community of France, Jerusalem Post publisher Yehuda Levy told a news conference. He said he hoped to sell 25,000 copies a week in France within two years, 5,000 to 7,000 in Israel and an unspecified number in Switzerland, Belgium, and French-speaking Canada and Africa. Levy said about 85 percent of the new paper's content would be translated from the English-language Post and the rest would be original material of interest to French-speaking Jews abroad. The English-language international edition sells 60,000 copies a week, 46,000 of them in North America, Levy said. The French edition, like the weekly English international, will be printed at the Jerusalem headquarters of the 60-year-old daily.
DOC.HEAD: First Private Yugoslav Daily Goes to Press
DOC.TEXT: A privately owned daily newspaper, the first of the post-World War II period in Yugoslavia, is to be launched Nov. 13, the state news agency Tanjug reported. The Orient Express will publish in the central city of Sarajevo, capital of the republic of Bosnia-Hercegovina, and will cost the equivalent of 40 cents, or 10 cents less than state-run dailies, Tanjug said Nov. 11. Tanjug quoted managing editor Enver Causevic, a veteran journalist from a dissident student newspaper, as saying the Orient Express will be politically independent and will employ young journalists from the city. More than 200 private periodicals have been launched in Yugoslavia in recent months.
DOC.HEAD: Philippine Radio Program Airs Real-Life Drama: Overseas Calls
DOC.TEXT: Lita Belga had not heard from her husband for months. When she learned he died in a car accident in Saudi Arabia, she wept. Millions of other Filipinos wept, too. Mrs. Belga received news of her husband Benjamin's death during a telephone call to his Saudi employers - paid for and broadcast by private radio station DZRH. The program, called ``Around The World, With Love,'' features telephone conversations between Filipinos and their relatives working abroad. The calls are free - on condition they can be used on the show. The highly popular broadcast has become a real-life soap opera, a daily litany of money troubles, loneliness, death and other family crises. ``The beauty of the program is the spontaneity of it,'' said the program's host, Rey Langit. ``It is true-to-life drama unfolding right before you. It is both entertaining and educational.'' There is no shortage of people wanting to use the program to contact relatives overseas, even though the price is having personal conversations broadcast nationwide.
