DOC.TEXT: Salman Rushdie and his ``Satanic Verses'' aside, literature in India is venturing into new territory, crossing international boundaries. Here's a look at a group of young Indian writers attracting a lot of attention with their irreverent style. ---

A new generation of Indian writers has burst forth, winning acclaim at home and abroad for everything from sonnets to satire. Inspired by Salman Rushdie and others, they are irreverently testing the limits of language and venturing into styles rarely seen in their homeland. While some critics say it smacks of elitism, most write in English, the language foisted on India by colonial rulers but is now at least as indigenous to India's upper crust as Hindi, Bengali, Urdu and Tamil. ``I learned to read in English, to curse in English, to make love in English,'' says Shashi Tharoor, author of ``The Great Indian Novel,'' which is scheduled for release in the United States this winter. ``I don't think any of my other languages is good enough to express the ideas.'' Some, such as Rushdie and Bharati Mukherjee, have left their homeland, changed their citizenship, and found audiences in their adopted lands more receptive than those in India. Meenakshi Mukherjee, one of India's leading literary critics, credits Rushdie with breaking international barriers with ``Midnight's Children,'' which won Britain's Booker Award in 1981. Rushdie is now a citizen of Britain, where he went into hiding in February 1989 because of death threats from Moslems enraged by what they considered the blasphemy of his novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' ``Salman Rushdie showed that you can do anything you want,'' says Ms. Mukherjee, a professor at Jawaharlal Nehru University. ``In `Midnight's Children' he uses Bombay as anybody would use London or New York. He's the first one who didn't have a glossary to explain Indian terms. If you don't understand, that's your problem, not my problem.'' Tharoor and several others, including Amitav Ghosh, Upamanyu Chatterjee and I. Allan Sealy, stick to their Indian roots in themes but transcend national boundaries in their literary migrations, whether geographical, cultural or psychological. A few, such as Vikram Seth, tackle the literary world on universal terms. Seth, author of ``The Golden Gate,'' a 300-page sonnet of entangled San Francisco loves and lovers, is known in his hometown of New Delhi as ``the Indian who wrote the great California novel.'' Seth, who also wrote a China-Tibet travel book called ``From Heaven Lake'' and recently published a volume of poems called ``All You Who Sleep Tonight,'' travels around the world but spends much of the year in India. ``There is a resurgence in India-ness, people being proud of being Indian,'' says David Davidar, publisher of Penguin Books (India) Ltd. ``I think the colonial thing is finally being put to rest. All the younger writers are under 50.'' Davidar's publishing house has issued more than 40 books of fiction by Indian writers since its presses started rolling in 1988. Forty percent of Penguin India is owned by the British-based Penguin company, which means Indian writers picked up by Penguin at home get an automatic chance at option by Penguin affiliates in London and New York. Indian books have improved technically in the last few years. Fewer paperbacks fall apart in a shower of pages the first time you crack the spine. But it's the content that's so markedly improved. Tharoor purloined the names of characters from the epic Hindu poem ``Mahabharata'' (``Great India'') to irreverently populate the political landscape of 20th century India in ``The Great Indian Novel.'' Tharoor's novel, like 18th century Anglo-Irish satirist Jonathan Swift's ``Gulliver's Travels,'' succeeds on seveal levels. At face value, ``The Great Indian Novel'' is an amusing bit of fantasy. On a general political plane, it pokes fun at the ambitions and foibles of presumably fictitious politicians. But to the reader armed with knowledge of India's modern and mythical heroes and anti-heroes, the analogies are devastating.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
NEW DELHI, India: are devastating.
DOC.TEXT: Dhritarashtra, the blind and ineffectual king in ``Mahabharata,'' is the name Tharoor chooses for his parody of Jawaharlal Nehru, the first prime minister of independent India. ``He had the blind man's gift of seeing the world not as it was, but as he wanted it to be,'' remarks Ved Vyas, Tharoor's narrator. ``Even better, he was able to convince everyone around him that his vision was superior to theirs.'' The fictional Vyas, at the age of 88, is dictating his memoirs, full of barbs, as future Prime Minister Dhritarashtra embarks on the path that leads to the bloody partition of India and Pakistan, their still-unresolved dispute over Kashmir and his own pre-eminence as a founder of modern India and the Third World non-aligned movement. Tharoor, 33, who works for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva, speaks Hindi, French and ``a bit of Bengali.'' But he says his novel is ``a book that could only have been written in English. The kind of people who speak English in my book would normally speak English.'' Ms. Mukherjee says the new novelists seem to have ``an idiom that's almost international - irreverent, playful, you make fun of serious things.'' But she's troubled by their elitism in a country where only 44 percent of the 880 million people are literate in any language and only an estimated 4 percent read English. ``All of them come through the conduit of the same small institution,'' she says, referring to Delhi University's St. Stephen's College. ``I don't feel all that wonderful about it. It brings home to you the social reality of the books. They're all really upper class.'' India's earlier generations of novelists, such as R.K. Narayan, whose first books were published in the 1930s, were more self-conscious about writing in English, Ms. Mukherjee says. And India's only Nobel Prize winner for literature (1913) was Rabindranath Tagore, who wrote poetry in Bengali. The ``elite'' crowd of young novelists, all in their 30s, includes: -Ghosh, who used his native Bengal as the embarkation point for his ponderous first novel, ``A Circle of Reason,'' and again for the more delicately crafted ``The Shadow Lines.'' -Sealy, whose Anglo-Indian ancestry inspired ``The Trotter-Nama'' and who uses a crazy quilt of literary devices for a family saga that starts in the late 18th century with the arrival of Justin Aloysius Trotter in fictional Nakhlau, which resembles Lucknow during the British Raj. -Chatterjee, whose ``English, August: An Indian Story,'' traces a young Bengali civil servant's search for identity during his posting to a remote village. Less precocious - and less Indian, at least to Indian readers - is Bharati Mukherjee, 49, who left India to study at the University of Iowa nearly three decades ago and married a Canadian. She became a U.S. citizen in 1980. Bharati Mukherjee, whose novels and short stories have been published in the United States for the past 18 years, won America's National Book Critics Circle Award in 1988 for ``The Middleman and Other Stories.'' The central thread in ``Middleman'' is immigrants, and not just Indians who come to the United States. Her characters include an Iraqi Jew involved in Central American intrigues, a second generation Italian-American with an Afghan refugee lover, a Vietnam War veteran coming to terms with the child he fathered in Saigon. ``I like to think I'm writing from the inside about white America,'' she says. ``For me, America is an idea, an abstract entity. America is a frontier that needs constant pushing.''

DOC.TEXT: The televised images of oil-blackened beaches and dead wildlife dealt a severe blow to tourism in Alaska, the state's third-largest industry. But now the tourists are beginning to return and officials hope to lure them off the cruise ships and railroad cars and into the countryside. ---

To try to lure back tourists lost after the Exxon Valdez oil spill, the Alaska Visitors Association put out an ad featuring a close-up of Marilyn Monroe's face. Without the mole. The famous beauty mark on Marilyn's face was missing. The ad explained that she was beautiful even without her mole, just as oil spilled in one part of Alaska did not diminish all of the state's natural wonders. Whether that ad deserves the credit or not, tourism officials say business is on the upswing again, after a sharp drop following the oil spill in March 1989. Tourism is Alaska's third-biggest industry, behind oil and fishing. Last summer, 560,000 visitors spent more than $300 million in Alaska, state officials say. Tourism fell off following the oil spill, when pictures of blackened beaches and dead sea otters were televised worldwide. The spill took an estimated $20 million bite out of Alaska visitor spending in 1989, says Eric McDowell, a Juneau consultant. But tourism rebounded last summer, except at some fishing lodges, which still suffer from lingering concerns about tainted fish, McDowell says. Stan Stephens, a Valdez tour-boat operator, says his business this summer was back to pre-spill levels. While some people may be avoiding the sound, Stephens says about a third of his customers ask to see Bligh Reef, the submerged rock that ripped open the Exxon Valdez's hull. Diversifying the tourism industry has been a goal of outgoing Gov. Steve Cowper and many of the small business owners who cater to Alaska visitors. McDowell and others say that most Alaska visitors still arrive on cruise ships. Even among visitors classified as ``independent'' travelers, many spend part of their Alaska vacation on packaged tours. ``When a destination first develops, people are cautious and they tend to go in for packaged tours,'' McDowell says. ``But as information gets out, through word of mouth, independent travel to Alaska has grown faster than other segments.'' Advertisers selling Alaska's scenic splendor to tourists in the 1980s usually appealed to retired-age travelers who could see the wilderness from comfortable cruise ships or railroad viewing cars. This fall, however, a nationwide cable television advertising campaign targeted the independent travelers. ``Adventurers Wanted,'' one commercial proclaims. Independent travelers aren't content to watch a glacier from behind a cruise ship window, says Rod Bradley of Anchorage-based Bradley Advertising, producer of the new ads. ``People want the scenic wonders of Alaska to be the backdrop to their activities: picnicking on a beach, buying items, going to dinner, fishing,'' Bradley says. ``Everyone thinks of himself as an adventurer and the ads play on the subjective image people have of themselves as participants.'' Independent travelers plan their own itineraries instead of letting a tour company do it, says Dana Brockway, the state director of tourism. They take shorter, more frequent trips, spend more money than other travelers and spread it among a wider range of businesses. Additionally, independents provide the tourism industry with its best chance to extend tourism into more remote parts of the state and into the winter months. ``Independent travelers are where our real market growth has been this year,'' says Steve Hites of the White Pass and Yukon Railroad. Tourists riding the narrow-gauge railroad out of Skagway arrive on cruise ships and the Alaska ferry or drive the Alaska-Canada Highway in recreation vehicles, he says. Increasing the ``rubber-tire traffic'' into Alaska is a big part of the state's strategy to capitalize on the growth of independent travel, says Bob Miller, director of the Alaska Tourism Marketing Council. State officials in 1992 will use the 50th anniversary of the building of the Alaska Highway to promote independent travel to Alaska. ``We need to soften the harsh image of the Alaska Highway,'' Brockway says. ``Few people know it's virtually all paved and there's more to do along the way.'' Although independent travelers are being wooed with images of adventure, they are not coming to Alaska to rough it. ``They want rustic charm, they want to sink their teeth into it and they want a bath at night,'' Hites says. Even the cruise ship operators are starting to emphasize adventure in their marketing of Alaska. ``People want to get out and be a little more active. They're younger. They go on raft trips, ride helicopters,'' says Howard Clifford of Princess Tours. ``It's a little more daring.'' Cowper says he's trying attract investment, particularly Japanese, in winter recreation and tourism facilities, such as a northern lights viewing center. ``We need to increase the tourist season from three months to seven months,'' he says. ``To do that, we need more facilities.''

DOC.TEXT: At an age when most of their peers are knitting sweaters or puttering around in the garden, thousands of older citizens are trying to catch up with their kids and grandkids on the keyboards of their computers. Computer training centers for people 55 and older are springing up across the country. ---

At age 69, Joanna Goodblood joined the revolution, the telecommunications revolution. ``I want to know as much about computers as my daughter knows,'' says Mrs. Goodblood, one of the newest recruits in SeniorNet, a non-profit organization that teaches fundamental computer skills to people 55 and older. SeniorNet, based at the University of San Francisco, runs 35 computer training centers in 17 states and Canada. The newest center is at Johnson County Community College in this Kansas City suburb, where Goodblood and 35 others are enrolled in three computer classes. Thirty others are on a waiting list. ``A lot of time people when they get old are intimidated by technology,'' Mrs. Goodblood says as her classmates peck away on their keyboards during their second day of class. ``But this is a way to get into it without your feeling like a dodo.'' Since it started in 1986, SeniorNet has trained more than 4,000 older adults to use computers. About 1,100 have signed up for a SeniorNet network that allows them to send and receive messages to one another using personal computers linked to a telephone system. ``The people in our classes aren't in there for their resumes,'' says Mary Furlong, an education professor at the University of San Francisco and a founder of SeniorNet. ``The majority want to keep learning. They want to keep up with their children and grandchildren.'' Furlong and a colleague began SeniorNet in 1983 as a research project. They wanted to find out whether older people would be willing to learn about computers and use them. Industry surveys have found that only 9 percent of adults 60 to 69 years old own computers, and only 3 percent of those older than 70. By contrast, about 20 percent of all U.S. households have computers. ``What we discovered was older adults were very interested and very capable ... largely because they had more time to learn,'' says Furlong, who co-authored a book titled ``Computers for Kids over 60.'' ``Seniors bring patience and expertise to their computer learning,'' she says. ``They find that using computers can open new doors for them, once they overcome their initial fear of the technology.'' For a $25 fee, members receive a two-month, hands-on training course and a quarterly newsletter. They also can make a $15 membership payment for access to the network that connects them with each others' computers. They are charged $5.70 an hour for their on-line time. The computer curriculum includes, among other things, training on how to write letters, do newsletters and run budgets, Furlong says. On the network, members go on line every Wednesday night to correspond and debate issues, such as the Persian Gulf situation and the stock market. Many of the students, who have ranged in age from 55 to 95, have used their computer training for such things as cataloging collections and tracking investment portfolios. ``I'm in a lot of groups and a computer would be a convenient way of helping me with file-keeping and my records,'' says 65-year-old Lee Fisher, another SeniorNet student. The John and Mary R. Markle Foundation of New York is the chief financial supporter of SeniorNet, which is the first nationwide effort to help older adults participate in the telecommunications revolution. Computer centers are located in schools, community centers, nursing homes and eye-care centers. The college was chosen as the site because of its willingness to provide its computer education resources, says Cathie Peterson, a college spokeswoman. The college has provided the computers, computer labs and instructor. Some critics contend that working on computers will contribute to the isolation of senior citizens. But those involved with SeniorNet disagree. ``The communication we're trying to establish is like that of a park in the 1990s,'' Furlong said. ``You may not be able to walk across town, but if you go on line everybody is right there.''

DOC.TEXT: She was one of the most celebrated opera singers of all time. Joan Sutherland retired last month after a career that spanned almost 40 years, but hers is a voice that won't soon be forgotten. Her colleagues remember her as a true prima donna who worked hard at her craft and didn't put on airs. ---

When Joan Sutherland made her Italian debut in 1960 in Handel's ``Alcina,'' the tough Venice audience rose and shouted ``La Stupenda.'' Fans have been calling the Australian diva that ever since. Dame Joan, who recently retired after nearly 40 years, has had one of the most significant careers in the history of opera. One of her fans is tenor Luciano Pavarotti, who knows stupendous singing when he hears it. ``I think to the world of opera she has meant the greatest coloratura soprano of all time,'' he says. ``We do not know what Giuditta Pasta (for whom Bellini wrote ``Norma'' in 1831) and others sounded like, but I don't think they can be vocally better than Joan Sutherland.'' Lotfi Mansouri, general director of the San Francisco Opera, has directed Dame Joan in more operas than any other director. ``Joan is one of the absolutely greatest in the field of opera in the last 30 years,'' he says. ``I had the great fortune of working with her the first time I directed, in 1963. It was a production of `Sonnambula' by Bellini.'' Mansouri's production of ``The Merry Widow'' was Dame Joan's last American performance. That was a year ago in Dallas, the same city where she first sang opera in the United States. Dame Joan retired, at 63, in October at the Sydney Opera House, less than half a mile from the Sydney Conservatorium of Music where she began her career in 1951. Tickets for the final performance, Mansouri's production of Meyerbeer's ``The Huguenots,'' cost up to $415. ``She was a unique artist,'' Mansouri says. ``She had a very extreme vocal range. Most of the time coloraturas are smaller, lighter voices. Joan had a lush middle register. She always had a very good ear. Her pitch was always accurate. ``Maria Callas revived the bel canto and the mantle was passed to Joan. She had more vocal flexibility than Callas.'' Dame Joan's colleagues note that she brought unfamiliar operas into the repertoire, giving operagoers more variety. They talk of her as a prima donna who didn't put on airs, worked hard and was an inspiration. ``The only thing she would ever argue about,'' Mansouri says, ``is, she would say, `You're overestimating my ability.' ``I asked her in the second act of `Die Fledermaus' to dance part of the czardas. She said, `Are you crazy? Dancing it and singing it at the same time? You must be joking.' Then she'd go ahead and do it. She was very game. ``The last time I directed her was in Toronto in `Hamlet.' She said, `I'm a grandmother. You don't want me to do Ophelia.' Finally I convinced her. She was absolutely wonderful. Her mad scene was something I'll never forget. It was the last new role she ever learned.'' Some critics point out that Dame Joan didn't always articulate consonants. Her voice was silver, like a flute, while some preferred warmer sounds, and her acting sometimes seemed detached. ``I don't believe that business that she was not a good actress,'' Mansouri says. ``She was not an intellectual type actress. She was very honest, sincere. She would bring a lot from herself.'' While Dame Joan sang operas that other sopranos sing, such as ``La Traviata,'' she also sang the early 19th-century operas of Rossini, Bellini and Donizetti that most others couldn't sing. The primary interest in those bel canto operas is melody and voice. The verismo school, where realism and big orchestras reign, began at the end of the 19th century. Tenor Alfredo Kraus, who sang often with Dame Joan, says, ``At the same time we are artists, we are teachers. It is easy to give audiences what they know. If you give them what they don't know, you are giving them education.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
NEW YORK: them education.''
DOC.TEXT: Dame Joan never tried to hold a throne alone. The reigning Norma of her day, she suggested to soprano Montserrat Caballe that she sing ``Norma.'' Caballe was afraid to try but Dame Joan was persuasive. Then there were two highly successful Normas. When Dame Joan sang Norma, the mezzo-soprano was usually Marilyn Horne. Horne, a one-time soprano, was inspired by Sutherland to take up the coloratura mezzo and contralto roles in which she had made her fame. ``The world was ready for this stuff again,'' says Horne. ``Along came this unbelievable singer who could do these things. Joan is really the best. ``I think there aren't a lot of singers who do something original, something that really contributes to the history of the world of music and Joan is one of those people. She not only sang gloriously but she has revived all these fabulous things. ``And we must also talk about Joan's revivals of French music and contribution to the Baroque. She has been a major Handel singer and done Baroque opera. This has been a significant vocal lady.'' The 1955 premiere of Sir Michael Tippett's ``The Midsummer Marriage'' also had Sutherland in the cast. Maria Callas' career was winding down when Sutherland ``hit'' in 1959. One of Sutherland's first roles at Covent Garden was as Callas' maid in ``Norma.'' ``If you study Callas' repertoire, it was not so vast,'' Horne says. ``Joan did many operas Callas didn't do; she's been in there slugging it out for many years.'' Whether bel canto operas will continue to be sung after Dame Joan depends on whether somebody comes along who can sing them. Horne believes that, thanks to Dame Joan's bringing those operas back into favor, voice students increasingly will study bel canto technique. ``It has opened up a whole repertoire for young singers.'' Dame Joan's husband since 1954 is conductor Richard Bonynge. ``Hand in hand, Rick goes with Joan,'' Horne says. ``She was the great voice. He was really the guiding light. He has nurtured and protected that voice. He has been devoted to her and that instrument.'' Mansouri says, ``She's fortunate her husband is such a good musician. She was offered an enormous variety of roles. He advised her not to accept things not good for her voice. Some singers say yes to everything and pretty soon the voice is gone.'' Sutherland took Pavarotti with her on his first major tour, through Australia, soon after his first American appearance. That was with her in 1965 in Miami in ``Lucia di Lammermoor.'' ``She was a great inspiration,'' Pavarotti says. ``She was always there ready to sing, never late to a performance and always giving suggestions.'' Mansouri says, ``A Joan Sutherland doesn't come along every day. She's once in a lifetime. It was an honor to work with her.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.)
DOC.TEXT: Actress Deborah Raffin got the idea for turning Jack Higgins' World War II thriller ``Night of the Fox'' into a miniseries while producing the story as an audio tape. ``After reading it I thought it would make a good miniseries,'' says Raffin, who runs Dove Books on Tape with her husband, Michael Viner. Dove also publishes books and produces movies and miniseries. Raffin says at first she didn't intend to be in the miniseries herself. ``I thought I'd co-produce, as I've done occasionally in the past,'' she says. ``But after we developed the script, Michael and Charles Jarrott, the director, asked me to be in it. I'm glad I did.'' ``Night of the Fox,'' also starring George Peppard, Michael York, David Birney, John Mills and John Standing, will be televised in national syndication. The two parts will be shown in the coming week, with the day and time of the broadcasts left to individual stations. Raffin plays a British nurse who is drafted into a mission to rescue an American colonel seeking refuge on the German-occupied English Channel island of Jersey after his ship is sunk. The colonel knows the plans for the D-day invasion and must be rescued - or silenced - before the Nazis find him. Birney is the American colonel, Peppard is a mysterious intelligence agent and York has a double role as German Field Marshal Erwin Rommel and his official impostor. It was directed on location in Yugoslavia by Jarrott, who also directed Raffin in one of her first films, ``The Dove.'' ``My character, Sara, is a very practical-minded and good human being who's recently widowed,'' Raffin says in an interview at her home. ``Birney is kept hidden at her aunt's house. Peppard masquerades as a Nazi officer and she as his French mistress. ``That means she has to change her looks, demeanor and attitude. The fun of the piece is that everyone is impersonating someone else. We're all fakes and making believe.'' The miniseries also calls for Raffin to play Sara at age 70 and that led to an accident removing makeup that injured her eyes. ``It was a fluke,'' she says. ``We had a wonderful makeup man. He was using some kind of linseed oil to remove the acrylic makeup from my face. Some of the oil got into my eyes. The next day by noon the pain was excruciating. ``Dissolved pieces of acrylic in the oil had rubbed off a protective area of the cornea. I couldn't read or do anything for five or six days. I was very lucky. I was able to go back to work.'' Raffin made her film debut in ``Forty Carats'' in 1973 as Liv Ullmann's teen-age daughter. Since then she has been in several movies, including ``The Dove,'' ``Once Is Not Enough,'' and ``Touched By Love,'' and such TV movies as ``Willa'' and ``Haywire.'' Her most recent miniseries was ``Noble House'' and she just finished a horror movie called ``Scanners II.'' She co-produced the miniseries ``Windmills of the Gods'' with Michael Viner. ``When I'm an actress I don't want to have anything to do with producing,'' she says. ``But I really enjoy the producing end. Acting's my first choice, but being able to produce is a great luxury for an actress. I don't have to do scripts I'm not enamored with. I can develop and produce projects. I'm also very involved with Dove Books.'' Raffin and her husband are also developing another Higgins' World War II thriller, ``Cold Harbor,'' as a miniseries. Her next acting assignment will be in ``Morning Glory,'' a feature film from Dove based on a 1940s period novel by LaVeryle Spencer. ``I was doing `Social Security' on stage in Florida and Michael sent me some books to abridge for audio tapes,'' she says. ```Morning Glory' was one of the books and I fell in love with it. I want to do it as a film.'' Raffin's large hillside home is filled with Oriental and Hindu artifacts that reflect her interest in mysticism. She has traveled frequently in the East and spent a number of months in Hong Kong while filming ``Noble House.'' ``I love that part of the world,'' she says. ``I'm attracted to art, literature, artifacts and handicrafts that have a mystical quality. Fortunately I'm in a profession where you get to travel and benefit from many cultures.'' Her first book, ``Sharing Christmas,'' was edited from contributions she sought from 100 celebrities. It has just been published by Dove and Warner Books. She said all of the book profits will go to the homeless. ``I wrote, called people, stood on my head, whatever I could do to get people to share their Christmas memories,'' she says. ``The first people I heard from were Richard Nixon and Margaret Thatcher. We`re talking about making it into a television special.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Sunday, Nov. 18, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Big Question in Hong Kong: How To Deal With The Communists?
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Philip Kwok was a boy when the Chinese Communists broke their promise 40 years ago and seized his family's industrial empire in Shanghai. Now he's a leading businessman in Hong Kong and has founded a pro-China political party. Kwok assures the people of this British colony that what happened to his family won't happen to them when Beijing takes over in 1997. ``Times have changed,'' said Kwok, 52. ``We can't let history weigh us down.'' Tell that to Jimmy McGregor. In 1967, the hard-headed Scot, then a top colonial official, braved nail bombs and death threats to help quell Communist-inspired riots in which scores of people were killed. Today, McGregor leads a party that demands more democracy in Hong Kong and greater protection from China. ``I've seen what the Communists can do,'' the 66-year-old lawyer said. ``They haven't changed a bit.'' Differences between McGregor and Kwok cut to the heart of Hong Kong's big question about the future: How should you deal with the Communists? With great deference, members of Kwok's Liberal Democratic Foundation believe. Party members say they are willing to accept limits on freedom after 1997 so long as they can maintain Hong Kong's economic might. A per capita annual gross national product of $9,230 gives the 5.7 million people on this collection of rocks the second highest living standard in Asia after Japan. ``You can't avoid China,'' Kwok said. ``It has to have a say.'' To men like McGregor, the economy of Hong Kong rests on its liberties. Restrict the free exchange of ideas, tamper with the independent judicial system and the economy will tremble, they say. Debate will accelerate as 1997 approaches. First under the microscope will be China's promise, in a 1984 treaty with Britain, to maintain the laissez-faire economic and social system for 50 years and allow Hong Kong to govern itself. Some analysts fear China will try to manipulate the 1991 election, in which fledgling political parties will have their first chance at seats on the Legislative Council. Eighteen of the 60 seats will be filled by direct vote. The other members will be chosen as all the seats were in the past - either by government appointment or through elections by special interest groups, such as teachers and businessmen. China-watching Contemporary magazine recently reported that Beijing will donate about $50,000 to pro-China candidates. Zhou Nan, China's highest-ranking representative in Hong Kong, has said it will give ``moral support'' to friends. Zhou expressed support for Kwok's party in September and encouraged cooperation among the numerous pro-China groups in Hong Kong. An unusual alliance between business and labor resulted. Kwok and his party cemented ties with the pro-Beijing Hong Kong Federation of Trade Unions, which instigated the 1967 riots McGregor helped crush. ``You'd be surprised about what we have in common with those businessmen,'' said Leung Hon Hoi, a trade union boss. ``For one, we are both very patriotic.'' McGregor views such alliances with great suspicion. He likens trusting the Communists in Hong Kong to trusting ``an untrained mechanic with a Rolex watch.'' His party, the Hong Kong Democratic Foundation, wants to insulate the territory from Chinese influence. It says more legislative seats should be elected by direct vote and laws should be passed to guarantee basic liberties. In McGregor's view, China understands only confrontation. During the 1967 crisis, McGregor, then an official in the Department of Commerce and Industry, violated protocol by closing the territory's pro-Communist schools. He believed bombs were being made in chemistry labs. What saved him from losing his job, McGregor said, was a laboratory explosion that blew off a student's arm. ``The way to beat these men is to fight them tooth and nail,'' he said. Kwok contends McGregor's pugnacious attitude could hurt the territory. ``If you make the Chinese lose face by forcing them into a corner, they will never forget it,'' he said. ``We must cooperate.'' According to Kwok, the territory's relationship to China is like a bridge game in which Beijing holds the best hand. ``We've got one trump card - money,'' he said. ``They hold everything else. If they get really mad, they can turn off the water and the lights. Then where would we be?'' Kwok recalls growing up with stories about Communist authorities promising his relatives they wouldn't touch the factories, warehouses and department store in Shanghai. In the end, an empire of nine textile mills, one of the biggest department stores in Shanghai and 20,000 employees disappeared. Shrewd business deals in Hong Kong propelled the family back to prosperity, and their Wing On Co. is worth more than $100 million. Kwok was educated at Harvard and MIT, where he received a doctorate in computer science. The Shanghai experience did not turn the family against China, and Kwok noted: ``Hong Kong is different than Shanghai. It's protected by an international agreement.'' He and his party colleagues also have their own interests to protect. Many members are leading businessmen with substantial stakes in China's development, like the Kwok family's company. In early 1988, Wing On completed renovating Shanghai's first great department store, which opened in September 1918. The Kwok family once owned it.

DOC.NOTE: For release Sunday, Nov. 18, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Politicians Fight, But People Are Apathetic
DOC.BYLINE: With BC-Hong Kong-Future, b0568 ^By WONG SAU-YING
DOC.TEXT: While Hong Kong's politicians argue about the future, most people in Hong Kong take little interest in politics. The educated and well-off are worried about getting out or getting rich. Laborers and clerks are too busy working seven days a week, trying to squeak by. A government voter-registration drive highlighted the apathy many people feel about the British colony's fate after it is returned to China in 1997. More than $700,000 was spent on the voter registration campaign, to pay for television ads, a poster campaign and even a rock concert. The government has held registration drives before, but this was by far the biggest. Response was so low that the government extended the registration deadline by one month to Nov. 1. The number registering totaled 225,000, bringing to just over 1.8 million the number of people registered, less than half the territory's 3.7 million eligible voters. Registering to vote pales before Hong Kong's burning issues: emigration and whether lottery tickets should be sold in supermarkets. ``Becoming a voter? I don't even know whether I'm qualified,' said Lam Cho-fai, a 24-year-old university graduate. A voter has to be 21 years old and a resident of the territory for seven years. ``I can't see the point in becoming a voter,'' said Danny Yam, a 24-year-old television producer. ``It won't make any difference. Everybody here knows China is the boss, and it's so pointless to go the opposite way your boss wants.'' Britain's last great colony passes to China in 1997. Like Lam, many in the territory think China already calls the shots in Hong Kong. Many doubt China's promise to maintain the colony's capitalist economic system for 50 years after it resumes control. Those doubts increased after the military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in China last year. Instead of registering to vote, many people are voting with their feet. More than 1,150 emigrate every week. This year, an estimated 62,000 people will flee Hong Kong, up 47.6 percent from last year. Analysts say Britain's colonial tradition is partly to blame for the indifference to politics. ``After nearly 150 years of colonial rule, people in Hong Kong know very little about politics because we have been discouraged to educate students on that subject,'' said Robert Au, vice chairman of the Hong Kong Professional Teachers' Union. Only recently have high school textbooks mentioned China-Hong Kong relations, Au said. Teachers say instruction on the issue still emphasizes memorizing information, not critical thinking. Another problem is that Hong Kong's political system gives little power to elected officials. Most poer lies with the governor, now appointed by Britain and to be chosen by China after 1997. Hosts of radio talk shows, quite popular in Hong Kong, say few of their listeners bring up politics. ``We have a lot more other calls debating whether making lottery tickets available for sale in supermarkets would encourage gambling among the younger generation,'' said Lee Luen-fai, who has a morning call-in program. Lau Chi-man, another host, said people tend to care more about their own futures than the territory's future. ``Many people here reckon their future lies somewhere outside Hong Kong and are trying their best to find ways to emigrate,'' Lau said. Lately, Lau said, his show has been overwhelmed by callers asking whether they qualify to emigrate. In August, the government lined up the territory's leading singers to encourage people to vote. Rock star Anita Mui told a packed house: ``I hope you'll join me in becoming a voter to demonstrate our support for Hong Kong's future.'' One fan's response: ``That's easy for her to say. She can leave whenever she likes.''

DOC.HEAD: Democracy Means Less Representation for Women in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Ranks of women members were a showpiece in the sham parliaments of Communist regimes. Then democracy came to Eastern Europe, and most of the women were gone. A survey by the Inter-Parliamentary Council in Geneva found that all parliaments in the former Soviet bloc have fewer women members than before Communist parties fell from power last year. The sharpest decline was in Romania, where women made up 34 percent of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's rubber-stamp assembly. After the May elections, only 4 percent of the legislators are women. ``While, under Ceausescu, there were quotas for skirts in the parliament ... that didn't reflect political reality,'' said Cristina Popescu, a feminist and editor of the newspaper Romania Libera newspaper. ``Now, what you see is what you've got.'' New issues may galvanize women - Poland is on the verge of outlawing abortion, legal since 1956 - but there is virtually no tradition of real power for them in either the Communist system or the former opposition movements. Strong forces are holding women back. To them falls most of the exhausting daily grind of finding a family's food, clothing and small pleasures in shortage-plagued economies. Social custom causes women to marry early, have children immediately and dote on them. The Roman Catholic Church, predominant in Poland and strong elsewhere, encourages a traditional family model and has considerable political influence. Women have virtually no organizations they can use as a basis for political power. The search for equality on which Western women, men and institutions embarked 25 years ago found no mirror in the Communist world. Communist leaders often dismissed ``women's lib'' as a foible of indulged, immoral capitalists. Opposition groups did not welcome women to their leaderships or pursue women's issues in the battle against communism. Little sensitivity to women's equality is evident in the new democracies. Government commissions and public forums usually are men-only, and assumptions about women are rampant. A Western diplomat recalls repeatedly explaining that she was not making an error in Polish when she identified herself as a ``secretarz'' of her embassy, not a ``secretarka'' on the clerical staff. Those few women in the East who would call themselves feminists are only beginning to look at the way schoolbooks stereotype male and female roles. Suggestions that advertisements seeking Western investors should be addressed to ``executives'' and not ``businessmen'' are greeted with blank stares. ``The word `feminist' was ridiculed, the media made fun of Western women and I didn't believe there were other women who believed as I did,'' said Hanna Jankowska, who helped found Poland's fledgling ProFemina group after meeting like-minded women at a small rally against the anti-abortion law. Ms. Jankowska and others blame the fake equality of the Communist system. Now that it has crumbled, women are likely to retreat rather than jump at new possibilities, they predict. ``Women did not fight for emancipation; it was given to them with the new socialist system,'' she said. ``Many people connect the two. ``For many women, the practical effect of this emancipation is they have to go to work. They have two shifts, at work and then for the home. They are very tired and would prefer to stay home.'' After Bulgaria's elections in June, women made up 3.5 percent of the parliament, down from 21 percent. The Hungarian parliament is 7 percent female, down from 21 percent before free elections. Poland's parliament, chosen partly by democratic elections, is 12 percent women, compared with 20 percent when the Communist Party picked all candidates. ``The situation in most of the post-Communist countries is more or less the same,'' said Izabela Nowacka of the Polish League of Women, a Communist-aligned organization now seeking an independent identity. ``A certain number of seats were allotted to women in Parliament and it was due to this (Communist) system that women were allowed to enter government institutions, but not the women who had something to say.'' The Communists also had quotas for farmers, steel workers and miners. Their elimination in Poland also reduced working-class participation in Parliament, where 83 percent of members now have university educations, compared with 60 percent previously. No women have positions of power in Solidarity, which was born in 1980 during a Gdansk shipyard strike that started over the firing of a female crane operator. Even in the textile center of Lodz, where the vast majority of mill workers are women, Solidarity always has been led by men. When Solidarity was banned in 1981 and thousands of members were interned under martial law, women played important, but supporting, roles. They helped activist husbands, made placards and distributed literature. Their highest representation was in the underground press, where many wrote under male pseudonyms. Only two women were among the 57 participants in talks between Solidarity and the Communists that laid the groundwork for the transfer of power in 1989. Just one woman minister, in charge of culture, serves in the new government. The anti-abortion campaign, a product of Solidarity's close alignment with the church, conservative nationalism and all things anti-Communist, has roused some women. ``For the first time in postwar Poland, women became aware that their rights are in danger,'' Ms. Jankowska said. ``We are at the very beginning of organizing women in this country. It is a difficult task, but this abortion issue has awakened women.'' Generally, however, there is little optimism for substantially increased involvement or professional advancement by this generation of women in Eastern Europe. Winners of Polish parliament seats ``were very much connected with the church and the traditional model of family,'' said Dr. Zofia Kuratowska, deputy Senate speaker and one of the few ranking women in Solidarity. She said the spring elections probably will produce an even more conservative assembly after a battle among fledgling parties in which women have little place. Ms. Kuratowska noted that women comprised only about 10 percent of candidates in the May local elections. Municipal contests often are a starting point for political activists. Worn down by work, shopping and child care, women appear likely to succumb to the widespread Eastern European attitude that the authorities will do whatever they want in the end. Activists say many women already have retreated into their private lives, tuning out the political system. ``A woman can only influence public life after she has done the shopping, the laundry, put the children to bed,'' Eva Uhrova said. ``In the meantime, men, who have this time to themselves, can devote it to politics,'' said Ms. Uhrova, editor of a women's magazine in Czechoslovakia, where women hold 6 percent of the parliament seats, compared with 29 percent under the Communists. Women who were asked whether they wanted to advance professionally were ``terrified'' of taking on another obligation, according to a Polish survey. ``Due to exhaustion, women are reluctant to learn something new, such as a computer,'' said Ms. Nowacka of the women's league. ``We want to tell them they should take fate in their own hands, because now there are great opportunities.''

DOC.HEAD: PARIS: darkest moments.
DOC.TEXT: Jean Kahn, president of the Representative Council of Jewish Institutions in France, issued a statement in August saying, ``Manifestations of anti-Semitism in France have sometimes been over-dramatized in other countries.'' ``We feel this is not justified, because it does not reflect French reality,'' the statement added. ``Except for the tragic period of 1939-45...the Jews of France for the last 200 years have been completely integrated into the national community.'' Crozier says, ``The Jewish element is part of the French identity, as it is part of the American identity. We can accept anyone, provided he accepts our culture. That's why the Moslems are such a problem. They have a culture of their own which we do not recognize.'' Some sociologists and others say this sense of insecurity explains the rise of the extreme-right National Front party of Jean-Marie Le Pen. Le Pen contends that traditional French values are being corrupted by foreign influences. Le Pen, who wants to deport North African immigrants, says France risks becoming an Arabic-speaking, Moslem nation if immigration is not stemmed. The National Front, the most powerful far-right group in Europe, consistently holds about 15 percent of the electorate. France inherited its Moslem population, mainly North African, from its disintegrating colonial empire. Thousands were lured across the Mediterranean from 1960 to 1975 to man the factories during an economic boom. Tin-roofed shantytowns that sprung up around major cities to house the workers eventually were razed to make way for concrete apartment buildings. Cut off from city life, ill-managed and deteriorating, these high-rise complexes remain the principal source of housing for immigrant families. ``This is a basic problem which will weigh for years on our society,'' said President Francois Mitterrand in response to October riots in a low-cost housing complex outside Lyon. The projects ``provoke rejection, despair and make dialogue difficult.'' ``At the moment, it's hard to find a real Frenchman,'' said a 35-year-old Algerian. ``They're all rich and removed.'' The Algerian, who refused to give his name, owns the Cafe Balzac at the corner of two housing complexes near Vitry, south of Paris. He has lived in France since he was a baby but refuses to exercise his right to become a French citizen. ``They exploited my parents, they have done nothing for me,'' he said. ``We are badly viewed, so why accept something they don't really want to give you? I have my pride.'' Many Algerians feel they are an unwanted reminder of the inglorious eight-year war France vainly waged to keep Algeria a colony. France tried early on to rid itself of what clearly was becoming the immigrant burden, arranging to pay off workers and their families willing to return to their homeland. The program largely failed and officials now grope for ways to promote cultural integration. The immigrant question shares the political agenda with the ``new Europe,'' an interloper of another sort. France has been a driving force toward unity, challenging the European Community to go beyond the open frontiers of 1992 toward political union. But the bravado masks worries that are particularly French - how to remain rigorously independent in an interdependent community of nations and retain the national identity that is, it often seems, France's ``raison d'etre.'' ``France currently is facing its most profound identity crisis since the advent of the Fifth Republic (in 1958),'' according to Gregory Flynn, a European affairs specialist with the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington. The French, he wrote in The Wall Street Journal, ``fear for identity more than security'' and worry about losing all traces of their status as a world power. France appears well-placed to assume a leadership role in a united Europe, but questions arise about its willingness to suppress its nationalistic instincts. ``Everything is happening as though the French, no longer able to change the world or protect themselves from it, persuaded themselves that as a nation they can do nothing at all,'' says the government-ordered report on the state of the nation. The French have long sought to protect their national identity, politically and culturally, the report says. ``From now on, they will have to choose other criteria for success.'' Many experts are optimistic. Todd, a member of the government panel, says France has far more confidence now than a few decades ago, when the folly of grandeur - ``a perverse national obsession'' - bolstered a humiliated nation. ``France is one of the European countries changing most quickly,'' Todd says, ``so it's normal that some people have doubts, nostalgia, dream of a peaceful and tranquil France.'' Crozier says, ``You don't redefine what is French. It's not an intellectual operation. It's something that just happens.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Sunday, Nov. 18, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Saturday School Teaches Youngsters To Think
DOC.TEXT: When other children across America are sleeping late, 48 kids from Baltimore and surrounding counties are in ``Saturday School,'' dissecting coconuts and scrutinizing current events. The goal: to teach them how to think. Nine-year-old Ayanna Harrison reasoned that the swimming death of a 15-year-old boy with asthma could have been avoided had he been honest with his mother. ``She might have kept him home or sent a note to school to excuse him from swimming if she had known there would be a swimming test that day,'' Ayanna told her classmates as they closely examined a newspaper article about the accident. ``That mother didn't think much about him and made him go,'' said Paul Weinberg, 10, fingering a paragraph saying the youth ``begged his mother to let him stay home but - unaware that he faced a swimming test - she told him to go to school and get good grades.'' The mother, in fact, has said she sent a note to school asking that the child be excused from swimming that day. In two nearby classrooms, teachers Linda McClelland and Sally Duff used coconuts to guide sixth and seventh graders in the art of observing. The biggest problem for the youngsters was finding the patience to completely examine the outside before smashing the coconut to get the juice and meat. Discussing the best possible way to open the coconut took time, too. And teacher Thomas Payne explored genetic engineering with his eighth and ninth graders to help them formulate meaningful questions, identify pertinent data and determine fallacies and biases. These youngsters are participating in the Saturday School program twice a month at Coppin State College, home of the Maryland Center for Thinking Studies. Considered the first of its kind in the country, the program teaches students ``how'' to think in a variety of ways, not ``what'' to think. ``We do not teach math or engineering or science or social studies,'' said director Toni Worsham. ``We teach children how to solve problems, how to make decisions, how to become less impulsive, how not to jump to conclusions and how to be creative and look for other possibilities. And, we deal with real issues.'' The national education goals developed by President Bush and the nation's governors stress the importance that students, particularly college graduates, ``demonstrate an advanced ability to think critically, communicate effectively and solve problems.'' After a year of planning and writing curriculum, the Saturday School opened in September 1989, with about 43 students from Baltimore and surrounding counties. Some traveled from as far as 75 miles to participate. This year, 48 students are participating. The goal is to gradually expand to 200 youngsters from kindergartenthrough 12th grade, grouped into classes of 10 to 12 students. Diversity is a priority. There are wealthy students and poor students, blacks and whites, Hispanics and Asians, kids from both urban and rural backgrounds. The students are not necessarily gifted. Tuition is $200 a year but scholarships are offered to eligible students unable to pay. The center has a $100,000 state grant and a federal grant that varies each year but was approved for $100,000 this year. On a recent Saturday, the fourth and fifth graders worked in teams - ``pairs and squares'' - to solve problems and make predictions. Teacher Mary Ellen Beaty-O'Ferrall coached the groups through the frustrating moments that came when each person's opinion had to be repeated and considered. The sixth and seventh graders had to overcome their impatience to get done with the outside examination of the coconut and to smash it to get at the insides. They also took a lot of time discussing how best to open it up. ``I will NEVER think of a coconut the same way again,'' declared 12-year-old Tatiana Bareis. Worsham said the most critical issue facing educators today is students' lack of adequate thinking skills to solve problems or make decisions. Although research has shown that nearly all students beyond the age of 12 should be able to reason at the formal operational level, less than 40 percent of high school graduates are able to demonstrate higher-level thinking skills. At the center, active, cooperative learning is stressed. Students are encouraged to reflect on their own thinking and to learn to manage how they think. ``I like being able to teach things that don't necessarily fall under the category of a particular discipline,'' said Payne, who works for Howard County public schools. ``I like most being able to create our own curriculum. To have that flexibility is really a treat.'' Duff, an instructional specialist in health and science for Baltimore City Public Schools, said she also enjoys writing curriculum and was tickled about the success of the coconut curriculum she developed. ``School ought to be fun and thinking ought to be fun,'' said Duff. ``It's very exciting to me to think what our kids can do when they become thoughtful and aware of themselves as thinkers. It enhances their self-esteem. They feel competent. They're willing to be critical - politely we hope - but still to think independently. I've seen it happen with my students. It makes all the difference.' Anita Stockton, curriculum director, said parents receive progress reports twice a year, but the focus is on the progression and growth of the students. ``Nobody can fail,'' explained Stockton, a science specialist for the Maryland State Department of Education. ``All of our students make progress. Some make greater progress than others.'' The students arrive at the Saturday School as early as 9:15 a.m. to participate in enrichment activities 30 minutes before class. There is the ``weird facts'' room where youngsters search through books that describe unusual phenomena, the writing lab or the computer rooms where 12 machines are available for students interested in solving logic problems. The three-hour class sessions end with a ``debriefing'' period where students analyze the day's activities while completing specially designed charts. The teachers, part of a part-time staff that work only on Saturdays, spend 30 minutes after class writing in journals during a ``structured think time'' before joining together for their own ``debriefing and curriculum review. The drawback to the program? After a long pause, Sin Kei Yeung, 13, blurted, ``Why do you have to come here so early? It's Saturday, you like to sleep late.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: The Power of Art for Art's Sake
DOC.TEXT: Neither Nadine Gordimer nor J.M. Coetzee spent much time researching their new novels. They are South Africans, and the setting of their books - the world of apartheid, police raids and rebellion - is right in front of them. To write in South Africa means to have your subjects chosen for you, Gordimer notes, the problems are simply too great to avoid. But she and Coetzee differed greatly in recent interviews on what a writer could, and should, do about them. It's a matter of personalities as well as philosophies, the contrast between the outgoing, committed Gordimer and the shy, more skeptical Coetzee, a debate on the power of art for art's sake between two of South Africa's most acclaimed white writers. ``The creative act is not pure,'' Gordimer once wrote. ``History evidences it. Ideology demands it. Society exacts it. ... One thing is clear: Ours is a period when few can claim the absolute value of a writer without reference to a context of responsibilities.'' Just 5-foot-1, she has high cheekbones, playful eyes and a long, thin nose. Her voice is small, her diction precise. The 67-year-old author works in the tradition of such politically minded South African writers as Alan Paton and Athol Fugard. Her characters are adventurers, travelers, participants - people forced to make difficul choices between political commitment and personal responsibilties. In her new novel, ``My Son's Story'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95), Sonny is a married black man who falls in love with a fellow activist, a white woman. Hillela, the hero of her 1987 novel ``A Sport of Nature,'' leaves family and friends behind as she comes of age emotionally and politically.``Burger's Daughter,'' banned for three months in South Africa upon its release in 1979, details the struggles of the daughter of the late South African Communist party leader. ``These are searing experiences,'' Gordimer said, ``and all sorts of things can happen. ``We tend to look down on people who are not like us, especially in revolutionary situations. I think sometimes you have people, good people trying to do the right thing but not having the courage to go far enough. On the other side, we have people who tried to ignore what's going on.'' While Gordimer writes of collaboration, Coetzee is obsessed with solitude. He is quiet, with a gray goatee and soft eyes. He waits several seconds before answering, his responses coming in full, well-constructed sentences, as if the delay was necessary for last-minute editing. His books are brief - usually under 200 pages - and intense; the author knows it takes less time to prepare a meal if you turn up the heat. In ``The Life and Times of Michael K,'' ``Waiting for the Barbarians'' and others, he writes of innocents, outcasts and guilt-ridden government officials, men and women doing their best to duck under history or simply float above it. ``Age of Iron'' (Random House, $18.95) reads like a single, sustained thought. The book is narrated by Mrs. Curren, a classics professor dying of cancer. Her husband is dead, her daughter has moved away and her closest companion is a homeless man she brings in from the street. Tragedy pushes Gordimer's characters into action, but Coetzee's people become more withdrawn. Mrs. Curren does not initiate events, she reacts to them. The author writes of Mrs. Curren standing over the bleeding body of her servant's son, who has been shot by police: ``It was blood, nothing more, blood like yours and mine. Yet never before had I seen anything so scarlet and so black. Perhaps it was an effect of the skin, youthful, supple, velvet dark, over which it ran; but on my hands it seemed both darker and more glaring than blood ought to be. I stared at it, fascinated, afraid, drawn into a veritable stupor of staring.'' Says the 50-year-old Coetzee, ``Our history is such that all of a sudden ordinary people are confronted with major decisions in a way that ordinary people are usually not faced by. I think South Africa in the past 40 years has been a place where people have been faced with really huge, moral debts.'' But what is the value of fiction in South Africa, a country where political responsiblities make introspection seem self-indulgent, almost treasonous? Gordimer, a member of the African National Congress, believes fiction has subversive power, that imagining a revolution can make it more likely to happen. In ``A Sport of Nature,'' she concludes with Hillela and others attending a joyous ceremony proclaiming the birth of a new African state. The book was written before the release of Nelson Mandela and many other political prisoners. ``It's strange because when all of those prisoners came out in October of last year, for the first time in many, many years there was this enormous rally,'' Gordimer said. ``It was somehow a dress rehearsal for what was in `Sport of Nature.' There were our leaders parading around in this tremendous surge of exhilaration.'' Coetzee is more cautious, wary of predicting any post-apartheid utopia and unsure novels can keep up with current events. He closely follows politics, but does not see fiction as the ideal way to write about it. ``I don't think the novel is the most effective way to intervene in the daily processes of political life,'' he said. ``Writing a novel takes too long. Publishing a novel takes too long. Novels are read by too few people. They don't have that direct kind of involvement with political reality that newspapers have.'' Gordimer sees fiction writers as the best kind of reporters, combining technical skills with political and psychological insight, taking an interest in the news of the day and conducting exhaustive research of their characters' inner lives. ``The writers' powers of observation are more acute. The writers of fiction often see in the behavior of people which way they're probably going to go,'' she said. ``This applies to all societies. If you live there all the time you can see what might happen, and sometimes you're right.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Nashville Sound: Bathroom Graffiti Inspires K.T. Oslin
DOC.TEXT: The graffiti was printed neatly in black ink on a bathroom stall in a cafe in Due West, S.C. ``I ain't never gonna love nobody but Cornell Crawford,'' it declared. When K.T. Oslin read it, she chuckled. Then, pondering its directness and determination, she knew she had a song. The result is ``Cornell Crawford,'' one of Oslin's songs in her third country music album, ``Love in a Small Town.'' Cut after cut, the themes and emotions are from everyday, ordinary life and hit special chords within the listener. It is her first LP in two years, a rather long hiatus for country music. So this normally gutsy singer-songwriter confesses to a touch of trepidation. ``If you don't put out an album every year, you can be dead meat,'' the 48-year-old performer said in an interview as she munched on bread and Brie. ``We'll see. But I don't think you become dead meat until you are doing inferior work. Or mediocre work.'' Based on her previous records, Oslin has little reason to worry. Her albums, ``80's Ladies'' and ``This Woman,'' both sold more than 1 million copies. She won three Grammy awards during a meteoric rise in country music. In 1988, she unseated Reba McEntire as the Country Music Association's female vocalist of the year. McEntire had won the honor four straight years. Now Oslin offers ``Love in a Small Town,'' an album weaving songs of wry amusement, emotional strength, nostalgia and loneliness. The LP's cut ``Come Next Monday'' is about a woman vowing to end a relationship. ``Oo-Wee'' is about staying home from work and frolicking. ``Mary and Willie'' is about two people with no love interests in their life. ``Love Is Strange'' is Oslin's remake of a 1956 rhythm and blues hit by Mickey & Sylvia. Kenny Rogers and Dolly Parton also recently recorded it. Oslin's crooning ``... My sweet babe, you're the one'' has almost as much feeling as an embrace. And ``Cornell Crawford,'' inspired by the writing on a toilet wall, tells of dedication for the man who makes sparks fly. ``We all wish we had a Cornell Crawford,'' Oslin mused about the song. ``I've been doing it in the live show for two years and it gets some of the best response of anything. People are intrigued about someone that emphatic. The sincerity of it struck me.'' She wrote or co-wrote seven of the nine cuts and plays keyboard on every song. Kay Toinette Oslin was born in Crossitt, Ark., but spent most of her early years in Mobile, Ala. As a teen-ager, she settled in Houston. Ending up in New York, she was a chorus girl in theatrical productions and then turned to work as a studio backup vocalist and ad jingle singer. She also showed a flair for songwriting. An aunt lent her $7,000 to finance a Nashville showcase performance, which caught the attention of RCA Records. She signed an RCA recording contract in 1986 at a time when most record companies were looking for singers almost half her age. Oslin became one of Nashville's most intriguing personalities, launching a new career in her mid-40s and writing songs from the perspective of a strong woman. Her hit singles included ``Do Ya,'' ``Two Hearts,'' ``Hey Bobby,'' ``Didn't Expect It to Go Down This Way'' and ``This Woman.'' ``I was different,'' she said. She also was outspoken. She has said candidly that she hated country music when she grew up. ``When I listened to country music in the '50s, it was almost all males who seemed very old and sang about drinking and cheating on their wives or girlfriends. A 15-year-old does not relate to that,'' Oslin said. ``Fortunately, it has changed, and people who say today that they don't like country music probably haven't listened to it. ``Some of it I like today, some of it I don't. I don't like the real twangy, hard core, straight ahead, old style country music. I like some of it, but on a steady diet, no.'' Her current album is not her only new project. She just recorded a duet with Barry Manilow, ``Baby It's Cold Outside,'' which will be on his next album. Oslin also has received considerable attention for her music video of ``Come Next Monday.'' In it, she portrays the bride of Frankenstein. ``It has nothing at all to do with the song,'' she explained. ``I thought it was time to show that I had a sense of humor. My videos have all been great but rather serious. We just went the crazy route. It's hilarious.''

Video View: Home Video News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' will carry the new NC-17 rating when it is released by RCA-Columbia Pictures Home Video on Dec. 12. The provocative comedy by Spanish filmmaker Pedro Almodovar was given an X rating by the ratings board of the Motion Picture Association of America when it was released theatrically earlier this year because of the film's sexual content. However, the X rating was replaced by the new NC-17 (no one under 17 admitted) in September when Philip Kaufman appealed the X-rating for his movie ``Henry & June.'' Most theaters refused to show movies with X ratings, regardless of artistic merits, because they were associated with hard-core pornography. Vidmark's ``The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover'' was the first video to be released with the new rating when it hit stores on Oct. 17. It had been slated for an R-rated version and an unrated version. ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!,'' Almodovar's seventh film, tells the story of a former mental patient who kidnaps a pornographic film star and ex-addict, who eventually falls in love with him. His ``Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown'' has grossed nearly $30 million in worldwide sales and is the biggest box-office hit in Spanish history. RCA-Columbia will release the video in VHS and Beta format at a suggested retail price of $89.95. It will have subtitles. In other video news, A-Vision Entertainment, Atlantic Records' new home video subsidiary, will release ``Mandela in America'' on Nov. 20. The video is a montage of the South African leader's journey across the United States and has interviews with such celebrities as Jane Fonda, Spike Lee, Sen. Edward Kennedy and New York Gov. Mario Cuomo. --- ``Gremlins 2: The New Batch'' (Warner Home Video. $92.95. Rated PG-13).
A successful sequel usually requires strong and interesting characters or unique and compelling situations. Or, the sequel simply has to be better than the original. With ``Gremlins 2: The New Batch,'' the most exciting characters aren't human, and the situation would be compelling and scary if it weren't so silly. This time around, the mutant Mogwai trash a computerized office building in New York, gulp down vials of experimental genetic drugs and leave a trail of green slime, garbage and confusion. Gizmo has been living peacefully with his keeper, Mr. Wing (Keye Luke), the wise and mysterious man who first introduced the little critter in ``Gremlins.'' Daniel Clamp, a send-up of Donald Trump, is a greedy developer who wants Wing's little curiosity shop in Chinatown so he can build yet another sprawling steel and cement monstrosity. But Wing won't sell. When Wing dies, Clamp sends in the wrecker's ball. Gizmo flees, only to be scooped up by one of Clamp's reseachers from the company's genetics lab. Billy Peltzer (Zach Galligan) also works for Clamp. He's the naive, trusting lad whose father gave him Gizmo as a cute present. Billy's true love, Kate (Phoebe Cates), is a tour guide in the building. Billy rescues Gizmo just as the deranged Dr. Catheter (Christopher Lee) is about to dissect him. But Billy, who knows how Mogwais can dangerously mutate, goes out to dinner with his pushy boss, Marla, and stupidly leaves Gizmo alone in his desk drawer telling the creature that someone will pick him up. Gizmo, of course, doesn't stay put. He gets splashed by water, which triggers the birth of mutations who take things a step further and become those obnoxious and evil little uglies who just about did in Billy's hometown. This time, they take over Clamp Center and threaten to take Manhattan. Clamp's empire is shredded - from his ``Microwave Marge'' TV show to the genetics lab. The microwave is a campy allusion to the original movie in which Billy's mom nuked a bad gremlin. There are other campy nuggets as well: Gizmo as Rambo; Clamp and Marla (as in Marla Maples, Trump's amour); vampire bats and Christopher Lee, one of cinema's most famous Count Draculas. Billy, Kate and their visiting neighbors from Kingston Falls put an end to a gremlin takeover. Don't look for chills and thrills, though. The bad Mogwais are more comic than evil. There's a hyper, bug-eyed critter, a ruby-lipped vamp and an intellectual who plans to lead his brethern to Broadway shows and the best restaurants in towns (gremlins love to eat). ``Gremlins 2'' is big on frenzy and mess. It's also good for a sincere laugh or two. But the uniqueness of the creatures is gone. Even Gizmo is no longer precious, but simply ordinary. The ``Snow White'' scene in the original movie was priceless. So was the constant ``yum-yum.'' The sequel has none of those quirky inventions. The creature crew is to be commended for the special effects and for the Mogwai manipulation. And the support cast adds a much needed luster, especially Lee, Dick Miller and Jackie Joseph as Mr. and Mrs. Futterman and Robert Prosky as Grandpa Fred, a TV personality who is host of a late-night horror movie show. Cates and Galligan merely lend a bland sweetness. If it's a rainy Saturday, get this one for the kids - they'll love it. --- Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G - General aS ANGELES=

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: Back on the Block
DOC.TEXT: The years between his landmark movie, ``Easy Rider,'' and his recent return to film prominence were a waste, says Dennis Hopper. ``The drugs and alcohol that I was involved with stopped me from working, stopped me from being creative. The problem with being an alcoholic and a drug addict is that you don't think it's happening. You don't know that you're addicted and don't admit that you're addicted. It's always somebody else's fault that you're not working,'' he said. ``Those were wasted years. I've directed six movies now. I should have directed 20. It's unfortunate, because all that was ever important to me was the work. I justified my own addictions because I was an `artist,' and all the great artists, of course, were drug addicts and alcoholics. Because of that stupidity, I don't yet have a body of work that I consider important.'' Hopper is striving to make up for lost time. His sixth film as a director, ``The Hot Spot,'' starring Don Johnson, has been released to hot and cold reviews and so-so business. While not in the Scorsese-Spielberg-Pollack range of directors, he has no trouble finding employment, particularly for hard-textured works such as his sensation-causing ``Colors'' (which was blamed for scattered theater violence) and the current film, a study of sex and crime in a small Texas town. ``This is a departure for me,'' he said. ``I actually used a novel by Charles Williams. You might say we were of like mind. He wrote the book in 1951, it was published in 1952. Then in 1962, he wrote a screenplay with Nona Tyson; it was intended for Robert Mitchum. ``I found that script and updated it to now. It's about an amoral drifter (Johnson) who comes to a small town in Texas and sells cars. ... It's a throwback to the film-noir dark movie, a pulp novel. It's fun. I like it.'' Johnson finds himself caught between two women, an oversexed schemer (Virginia Madsen) and an innocent young beauty (Jennifer Connelly) who is also manipulative. He also gets involved in bankrobbing, blackmail and murder - ``all the good stuff.'' Hopper considered other stars before deciding on Johnson, late of ``Miami Vice.'' ``I edited the movie for a year, and now I can't imagine anyone else playing the role,'' said the director. ``People should really look at him as a force to be dealt with in movies. He could be a major star. There's a place there for him.'' Hopper found Madsen while watching television via a satellite dish during the filming of ``Flashback,'' in which he acted but did not direct. He saw her as a throwback to Lana Turner, perfect for the femme fatale role. He remembered Connelly from her role as a 12-year-old ballet dancer in ``Once Upon a Time in America.'' He considers her ``more beautiful than Elizabeth Taylor and a better actress.'' Hopper talked about the notices for ``The Hot Spot'' and said: ``It's getting some good stuff and some bad stuff. But I think that runs with the territory. It's a hot movie. But then, I've always gotten widely divergent reviews, starting with `Easy Rider.' `Colors,' `Out of the Blue,' also. It sort of follows me around like a pet snake.'' Nothing in Hopper's background provided any hint of his later notoriety. He was born in Kansas in 1936 and spent much of his youth on his grandparents' farm five miles from Dodge City. His parents moved to San Diego, where Hopper won a scholarship to the Old Globe theater. A taste of Shakespeare emboldened him to try Hollywood, and he landed a seven-year contract at Warner Bros. Hopper appeared in some impressive films: ``Rebel Without a Cause,'' ``Giant,'' ``True Grit'' and ``The Sons of Katie Elder.'' After a few low-budget biker films with Peter Fonda, the pair combined their forces in ``Easy Rider.'' The film's gritty realism revolutionized the industry. Its success also contributed to Hopper's 15-year tailspin. Hopper savors his new life: ``I'm married (to dancer Katherine LaNasa, 31 years his junior), I have a new son, Henry Lee, born in September. I have two daughters. The 17-year-old just entered college; my 28-year-old is involved in film development here. I couldn't be happier. The work is good, and I just want to keep working. Those are the important things.'' Hopper probably will never shed his reputation as a world-class hellraiser of the '60s and '70s. Just recently a New York tabloid captioned a photograph ``Bad boy actor-director Dennis Hopper .. .'' Is he a bad boy? ``No, I don't think so,'' said the filmmaker, who resembled a stockbroker in his expensively tailored suit. ``Maybe a bad gentleman.'' He shrugged off such references to his past: ``I'm not rushing to get out of it. ... Seems harmless enough, doesn't it?''
