DOC.HEAD: Renewed Interest in Making Social Security Fairer to Women
DOC.TEXT: The Ozzie and Harriet version of the American family is nearly extinct, but the Social Security system designed around it is much the same. As a result, women are the losers. Married working women usually earn no more Social Security retirement than if they'd never worked a day. Most divorced women get only half the benefits earned by their former husbands. Women who become widowed in their 50s face up to 10 years without any death benefit checks. These inequities have been acknowledged since the mid-1970s, but reforms went nowhere because the system went through a financial crisis. Tax increases passed in the early 1980s have prompted renewed calls for reform. Two House subcommittees are considering legislation. A task force appointed by Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King is working on its own bill. ``I think we have a responsibility to at least look at whether we're serving the needs of families in this country in the 21st century,'' King said in an interview at Social Security headquarters in Baltimore. The Older Women's League, an advocacy group, explains the problem in dollars. The average monthly Social Security retirement benefit for women in 1989 was roughly three-quarters of that paid to men - $488, compared to $639, according to the league. Compounding the problem, by 2030, only one in three women over 65 will be married, compared with 40 percent today. ``More and more women will be living in poverty,'' said Joan Kurianski, director of the Older Women's League. Two factors put working women at a disadvantage. They usually earn less than men and they often stop working to care for children or elderly relatives. The system gives these women a difficult choice. They can base their Social Security check on their own earnings or they can get a check equal to half their husband's benefits. Because their earned benefit is usually lower than the 50 percent spousal benefit, the years they worked and paid taxes go for naught. Divorced women, unless they've earned high incomes themselves, get only the 50 percent spousal benefit - and then only if they've been married 10 years. Reform advocates also bemoan what they call the widow's gap - a quirk in the system that can put widows in their 50s in poverty. While they are too old to begin most careers, Social Security won't pay death benefits until age 60 because they don't have young children. Faced with relatively paltry retirement checks, women must make do in other ways. Lucille Leffall, 65, is a retired beautician in Baltimore who is twice divorced and now gets $300 per month Social Security. She works part time at a senior citizens center and depends on her daughter and son-in-law for help. Without that, Leffall said, ``I would get married again, I guess - if I could find the right person who would go along with my way of thinking.'' Mary Gray, 75, also of Baltimore, worked 14 years in a doughnut shop and became widowed at 57. Her Social Security check now totals $437. She lives in a rent-subsidized apartment, but still has to juggle to meet expenses. ``I was raised during the Depression and you realized then that sometimes you just didn't get what you wanted,'' she said. One proposal to equalize benefits between men and women is called earnings sharing. The total lifetime wages of a husband and wife are combined, then divided to compute each person's retirement check. ``The principle is, marriage is an economic partnership and even if I'm not in the paid labor force, I'm contributing to the marriage,'' said Laurel Beeden, a researcher for the American Association of Retired Persons. But earnings sharing cuts benefits to some people, such as divorced men, so it's never gotten far in Congress. Rep. Mary Rose Oakar, D-Ohio, has tried to solve these inequities with earnings sharing legislation that prohibits anyone's benefits from dropping. Although this would drastically increase the cost, Oakar says the Social Security Trust Fund can afford it. ``If you did the whole bill in one fell swoop it would cost in the neighborhood of $30 billion (a year), but remember, as we speak we have about $90 billion in the trust fund, and by the year 2000, they say it will be up to about $1 trillion.'' A less ambitious proposal by Rep. Thomas Tauke, R-Iowa, would: - Allow women to take up to 10 years out of the work force to care for children or relatives with no loss in retirement benefits. - Allow widows who are ineligible to receive benefits until age 60 to get them at 55. - Allow divorcing women to negotiate in court for part of their husband's Social Security benefits. King, however, doubts the system can afford either plan. Her task force is trying to reform the system without new spending or taxes, a goal she says may be reached at the expense of some people's benefits.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 15, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Red Barber a Highlight of NPR'S Friday Broadcast
DOC.TEXT: Millions of Americans tune in weekly to hear Walter ``Red'' Barber on National Public Radio, 24 years after he signed off his final broadcast of a New York Yankees game. It has meant arising three hours earlier than normal since 1981, when the live Friday segment became a fixture that includes glimpses of history or personal insights. ``I don't enjoy getting up at 5:45 on Friday mornings, but I enjoy doing it,'' he said. ``It's something I look forward to.'' Although Barber usually discusses sports with NPR ``Morning Edition'' host Bob Edwards, he is comfortable with nearly any subject. ``Listeners like to know what the weather is in Tallahassee and what's in bloom,'' he said. ``Basically it's what I want to say, and it gives me pleasure. That goes back to radio in its beginning days.'' Barber, 82, also likes to bring listeners up to date on other old-timers, often noting the death of former players, umpires or journalists along with a personal comment on his association with them. Barber's relationship with NPR began in December 1980 after the death of Elston Howard, the Yankees' first black player. Since Barber had broadcast Yankees games during most of Howard's career, he was a natural. ``They asked for two or three minutes of my thoughts about Howard,'' Barber said. A month later, NPR asked Barber if he was interested in a weekly taped program. He insisted on a live format and refuses most interview requests that aren't live. ``The thing about the show that is attractive is that it's completely spontaneous,'' said Barber. ``As I sit there, the pleasure I get is being myself.'' The show, Edwards said, has become the most popular on ``Morning Edition,'' generating thousands of letters from listeners. ``The biggest complaint we get about the bit (a 3{-minute segment) is it's too short; Red can't really tell a long story,'' said Edwards. ``He is the star of the show, the network.'' Last month, Barber and Edwards broadcast the show together for the first time in a fund-raiser for the public station at Florida State University, in Tallahassee. ``This will be a little easier for me because I'm a little hard of hearing, and now I can read your lips,'' Barber told Edwards. Their Friday show on ``Morning Edition'' has always been through a telephone hookup between Edwards at NPR's Washington studios and Barber's home. ``We just fit,'' Barber said. ``He's a great professional broadcaster. A wonderful interviewer and very sensitive. He doesn't put his ego first.'' Barber prepares for his weekly show with the diligence he approached the thousands of baseball games he broadcast during the heyday of radio. ``I don't want Bob to trip me up,'' said Barber. ``Bob makes it easy,'' Barber teased. ``He throws the big fat pitches to me.'' The weekly segment is unrehearsed and live. ``I have an idea of what I want to ask him,'' said Edwards, 43. ``I have no idea what kind of answers I'm going to get.'' And Edwards marvels at Barber's wit. ``On opening day (baseball) we're doing a call-in show and someone is on the line from Washington,'' relates Edwards. ``Hello, Washington. Washington? I guess they're gone,'' Edwards said. ``You're right, Bob,'' Barber said immediately. ``They moved to Minnesota in '61.'' Barber finds television sometimes too enamored with sports, often at the expense of news. He cited a weekend in early September when Soviet Prime Minister Gorbachev and President Bush met in summit during the Persian Gulf crisis. ``With all of this tremendous news, television only had tennis and pro football,'' Barber said. ``I want somebody to tell me what this means about our society.'' Barber follows the fortunes of protege Vin Scully and Detroit Tiger announcer Ernie Harwell, who moved into a big league job when Barber fell ill during the 1947 season. Two years later, Barber hired Scully - longtime voice of the Dodgers - right out of Fordham University. ``He's my boy,'' Barber said proudly. Barber, who turned author, naturalist and homemaker in retirement, seldom travels anymore so he can spend time with his wife of 60 years, Lylah. ``If I had a so-called career, she made it possible because I'd be gone six months of the year,'' he said. ``She raised our daughter, ran the house and was lonely.'' Daughter Sarah, a college professor, lives in New York City. Barber is delighted he and Lylah have enjoyed good health, maintaining their one-level brick home in a lush, wooded Tallahassee neighborhood. ``She and I have a life to ourselves now,'' said Barber. ``She had a very lonely existence. It was a miserable existence.'' Barber, who always disliked traveling, said he loves his retirement routine. ``I like being at home,'' he said. ``And the Friday morning broadcast is something to look forward to.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 15, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Drug Abuse a Serious Problem Among Elderly People
DOC.TEXT: The elderly and prescription drugs can be a risky combination, and signs of aging may really be adverse drug reactions, according to a study. If faulty prescribing is added to the catalog of drug abuse, ``then the greatest epidemic of drug abuse in America is among our older people,'' the study, ``Worst Pills - Best Pills,'' concludes. Published two years ago by Public Citizen Health Research Group, an enterprise organized by consumer advocate Ralph Nader, the book offers a guide to common prescription drugs, gives advice on how to use them safely and recommends which drugs older people should avoid. ``Some doctors and patients assume that what are actually adverse drug reactions are simply signs of aging,'' the study says. ``As a result many serious adverse reactions are entirely overlooked or not recognized until they have caused serious harm.'' The drugs responsible for the most serious adverse reactions in older adults are tranquilizers, sleeping pills and other drugs intended to affect the mind; high blood pressure drugs and drugs given for abnormal heart rhythms; and drugs used to treat intestinal problems, the study said. More than 9 million adverse drug reactions occur each year in older Americans, with an estimated 243,000 people 60 or over hospitalized for such reactions in 1985, the study said. It said 32,000 older adults suffer hip fractures each year ``attributable to drug-induced falling,'' and 163,000 suffer from mental impairment either caused or worsened by drugs. The study lists several reasons why older people are more prone to adverse drug reactions, including lower weight, a smaller amount of water and a larger proportion of fat than younger people. ``Therefore, the amount of drug per pound of body weight or per pound of body water will often be much higher in an older adult than it would be if the same amount of the drug were given to a younger person,'' it said. And it said drugs that concentrate in fatty tissue may stay in the body longer simply because there is more fat. Other factors: decreased ability of the liver to process drugs, decreased ability of the kidneys to clear drugs out of the body and increased sensitivity to many drugs. Taking over-the-counter drugs in addition to prescription drugs also boosts the odds of an adverse reaction, it said. The study asserts that up to two-thirds of the prescriptions filled by older adults each year fall into three categories: - Not needed because the problem is not one for which the drug is a proper solution. - Needlessly dangerous because a less dangerous drug would give the same benefit. - The right drug, but with a dose that is unnecessarily high, causing extra risks without extra benefits. The study contends a host of illnesses, often attributed to old age, actually can be drug induced. Its list includes: depression, hallucinations or psychoses, involuntary twitches of the face, arms or legs, dizziness on standing, loss of appetite, nausea or vomiting, abdominal pain, bleeding or ulcers, constipation, diarrhea, difficulty urinating or urinary incontinence. The study's advice: Take an inventory of the drugs you or your elderly parents have taken over the last month, put samples in a bag and take them to your doctor for analysis. The study includes a list, with detailed descriptions of possible side effects, of 104 prescription drugs older adults should not use. It also offers descriptions of 183 drugs it says are safer alternatives. --- The study is available from Public Citizen at $12 a copy. Address: Pills, Public Citizen, 2000 P St. NW, Washington, D.C., 20036.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 15, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: `Mr. Potato': Nickname Grew From Early Seed
DOC.TEXT: The potato disease that caused Europe's Great Potato Famine in the 19th century was killing potatoes in Mexico in 1947, and the man who has become ``Mr. Potato'' went to seek a solution. John Niederhauser, a plant pathologist who lives in Tucson, recently received the $200,000 World Food Prize for helping develop a blight-resistant potato. The award recognizes the achievements of individuals who improve the world's food system, said founder Norman Borlaug, a 1970 Noble Peace Prize winner. And Niederhauser's achievements ``have affected countries from Mexico to Bangladesh,'' Borlaug said. Although he spent the first eight years of his life in Washington state on his family's farm, Niederhauser, 73, said he first became interested in potatoes while a student at Cornell University. He said he used to select the best potatoes for farmers while working summers as a potato inspector for the New York State Seed Inspection Service. But it was not until he had gone to Mexico that he earned his nickname, when a former president of the Rockefeller Foundation, George Harrar, introduced ``Mr. Potato'' at a meeting, Niederhauser said. ``It's kind of hung around since then,'' Niederhauser said. Nowadays he's ``retired,'' but his agenda remains full. ``I've retired four times,'' he said. Niederhauser said he began developing a blight-resistant potato after accepting a position with the Mexico-Rockefeller Foundation Agricultural Program in 1947. He said he thought twice about leaving his teaching position at Cornell, but ``I was attracted by the opportunity to work in a country in the undeveloped world and help them produce more basic food. It was different, but I felt we were doing something,'' he said. Late-blight disease occurs when the late-blight fungus, scientifically termed phythophthora incestans, destroys the potato's foilage and eventually the potato itself, Niederhauser said. The fungus originally is from Mexico, and is the main reason U.S. farmers spray potatoes, a practice farmers in developing countries can't afford, he said. The blight-resistant potato was 15 years in the making, Niederhauser said. Mexico is the only place where blight-resistant, wild potatoes can grow, and they were crossed with cultivated potatoes to form an edible, blight-resistant potato that didn't require spraying, he said. Niederhauser was one of four foundation members who worked with the Mexican government, scientists and farmers. They were paid by the foundation but worked as members of Mexico's Ministry of Agriculture. ``My interest in potatoes gradually increased as I saw problems we could help on together,'' he said. In Mexico, Niederhauser and colleagues helped raise annual potato production from 134,000 metric tons when they arrived to more than 1 million metric tons by 1982. Niederhauser's impact, however, is not limited to Mexico. He has worked in Bangladesh, Colombia, India, Pakistan and Turkey with scientists and farmers. Though he worked in Mexico for 35 years and raised four children there with his wife, he has traveled around the world. ``I spent two years in the Soviet Union between high school and college and worked on farms there,'' he said. He studied at the agricultural academy in the Soviet Union in 1935-36. He travels around the world - recently he returned to Mexico to help with an international potato project. Other interested countries include Poland, the Netherlands and Peru. When he's not visiting other countries, he gives seminars and assists with the Biosphere II project in Oracle, northeast of Tucson. Biosphere II is a self-sufficient, enclosed miniature model of Earth. Beginning in December, eight people will spend two years studying ways to address pollution and mismanagement of natural resources. The project also will be a prototype for living space. The biospherians will be producing their own food, including potatoes.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 15, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Company Prepares Families for an Older America
DOC.TEXT: A company has produced four videos to help aging Americans and those who care for them sort through the bewildering choices about insurance and health care. Jeanette Vaughan studied health care in college, but couldn't think of a way to market her research. After seeing ``L.A. Law'' character Arnold Becker peddle a video of himself giving advice on divorce, Ms. Vaughn plunged in. She made the videos ``All About Aging'' and created AgeView Inc., which distributes them. The series sells for $195, and is marketed to hospitals, nursing homes and health care agencies. While the public can buy the series, Ms. Vaughan hopes agencies will buy it to show consumers for free. By 2030, 21 percent of Amercans will be over 65. But Ms. Vaughan said most of the country hasn't considered the idea of an older America. ``The first ones feeling the impact are the women over 40 who are working and also trying to take care of aging parents,'' said Ms. Vaughan, 28 Among the topics on the tapes are how to obtain Medicare, Medicaid, private insurance and home health care; the psycho-social views of aging and how to relate to older relatives; and details on nutrition, safety and equipment use for elderly patients cared for at home. Delores Moyer, executive director of Alverno Health Care Corp., based in Memphis, Tenn., is one of the agencies in 275 U.S. cities that uses the tapes. ``We plan to start broadcasting the tapes across our closed-circuit TV network in the hospitals so patients and families can view the tapes while they are in the waiting room,'' said Ms. Moyer, whose company operates nine hospitals. Ms. Vaughan said she plans to develop additional tapes. ``It's not the answer to everything, but it points people in the right direction,'' she said.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 15, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Do You Know How To Prepare a Will?
DOC.TEXT: Although estate planning involves more than writing a will, it is one of the first - and most important - steps in planning for the distribution of your estate. Still, 70 percent of Americans die without leaving a will, allowing a state statute to make decisions on what is left to whom. To test your understanding of wills, complete the following quiz, prepared by Emmertt G. McBroom, academic associate with the College for Financial Planning. Select one answer for each question. 1. A will is a validly executed document that a) once executed, cannot be changed by you during your lifetime without permission of the court, b) conveys a present interest in property to your beneficiaries at the time that it is executed, c) informs the court and your heirs how you would like to have your property distributed when you die, d) only b and c. 2. To be legally valid in Colorado (laws vary from state to state), your will must a) be a combination of printed material and your handwriting, b) be witnessed by at least three relatives, c) be acknowledged and signed by you in front of at least two witnesses and a notary, d) be filed and recorded with the court. 3. Your will legally can accomplish all except a) specify the rules to be applied if you and your spouse die in a common accident where the order of death cannot be determined, b) establish trusts for your spouse or children, c) name the person that you want to receive your interests in your joint tenancy with right of survivorship property, d) direct which assets will be used to pay taxes and administrative expenses. 4. The person named in your will to administer the affairs of your estate is called a a) beneficiary, b) trustee, c) guardian, d) personal representative. 5. In selecting the person to name as administrator of your estate, all of the following are important considerations except a) fairness and impartiality, b) low, or no, administrative fees, c) sufficient time and willingness to serve as administrator, d) good business judgment and experience. 6. Your will should be reviewed and revised if a) there have been major tax law changes, b) you no longer wish to include a particular beneficiary, c) you marry, divorce, or have a child, d) all of the above. 7. In Colorado, the law requires that a decedent's will must be lodged with the probate court or probate division of the district court a) within 10 days of death, b) within 30 days of death, c) within 90 days of death, d) never; there is no requirement to lodge a will. 8. Only the assets specifically described in your will must be probated (distributed from the deceased to one or more beneficiaries) through the courts. a) True b) False. 9. To avoid having certain assets probated upon your death, you could a) create and transfer the assets to a trust prior to your death, b) place some other person on the title as a ``tenant in common,'' c) have a will provision that transfers the assets to a trust, d) retitle those assets held in ``joint tenancy with the right of survivorship'' to name you as the sole owner. 10. Only assets that must be probated are subject to federal estate tax. a) True b) False. --- ANSWERS: 1. c; 2. c; 3. c; 4. d; 5. b; 6. d; 7. a; 8. b; 9. a; 10. b. --- Some final things to consider: - If you don't have a will, consider having one written as soon as possible, and review it regularly - at least annually. - Keep a copy of your will in an easy-to-locate place. This does not necessarily mean a safe deposit box, which may be sealed at your death and access by beneficiaries denied. Send a copy to the personal representative (executor or executrix). - In addition to your will, leave a letter of intent that outlines specific, final arrangements, such as medical care or funeral instructions. It can expedite the distribution of your personal effects instead of waiting for the lengthy probate process. --- The College for Financial Planning is a non-profit, educational institution offering financial planning education to professionals throughout the financial services industry.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 15, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Your Vegetables Have a History, If You Only Look
DOC.TEXT: A garden abounds in fascinating lore. Each plant has a story, some highly dramatic or amusing, and getting to know them adds a satisfying dimension to gardening. Take arugula, the salad green. The name suggests a recent Mediterranean arrival. But digging in old books, I found that under the name ``rocket'' it was a favorite of Queen Elizabeth I and came to America with the Puritans. At various times, this herb was celebrated as a digestive aid, a pain-killer, a deoderant, a freckle remover, a cough medicine, a flavoring for preserved meats and, like many other innocent edibles, an aphrodisiac. Over the years I've put together a modest little shelf of histories containing such tidbits. I found one of my best books by chance. Browsing in a bookstore, I glimpsed the title of a thick paperback that was gathering dust near the floor. It was ``Sturtevant's Edible Plants of the World.'' This 685-page volume (Dover Publications Inc., New York) turned out to be a gold mine on the origins of vegetables and their legends or superstitions. Boston-born Edward Lewis Sturtevant, a 19th century agriculturist, touches on 2,897 species, with comments from 560 sources. He tells astonishing tales, like that of a group of ancient Greek soldiers choosing slaughter in battle rather than escaping through a field of fava beans they believed evil. Some books may be out of print, but you can get them at your library or through inter-library loans. With luck you may find some in second-hand bookstores to add to your collection. The National Geographic Society steered me to a store that had one of the few remaining copies of ``The World in Your Garden,'' published by the society in 1957. This is a superb volume containing instructive and entertaining essays on where our plants come from. One writer in the book, Victor R. Boswell, says he looked at a friend's garden and told him, to his surprise, that the only truly American vegetables he was growing were tomatoes, snap beans, peppers, limas and potatoes. All the others in his garden were of foreign origin - onions, radishes, lettuce, spinach, beets, chard, cabbage, broccoli, collards, carrots, parsley, turnips, peas, asparagus, soybeans, mustard and eggplant. What the colonists found in North America and what they brought with them is beautifully told in Ann Leighton's ``Early American Gardens'' (Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston, 1970), still available in paperback from the University of Massachusetts Press. A captivating item in this book is the bill of sale listing the seeds John Winthrop Jr. carried on a 1631 voyage to New England. Leighton's book profiles the culinary and medical uses of individual plants in that era and contains rich quotations from herbalists of antiquity, like the Greeks Galen and Dioscorides and the Roman Pliny the Elder, and such early English writers as Nicholas Culpepper, John Evelyn, John Josselyn, John Gerard and John Parkinson. ``The Secrets of the Seed'' by Barbara Friedlander (Grossett and Dunlap, New York, 1974) sparkles with references to quaint customs of the past, such as a girl giving a turnip to a suitor to signify the cold shoulder. And historical bits, like an 1893 ruling of the U.S. Supreme Court that the tomato was a dinner table vegetable rather than a fruit. An importer who wanted to avoid paying duty argued it was a fruit, which biologically it is. A British writer, Alice M. Coats, does a good job profiling flowers in ``Flowers and Their Histories'' (McGraw-Hill Book Co., 1971). Want to know about petunias? Coats tells us, ``The first recorded petunia was P. nyctaginiflora, a white, sweet-scented, night-blooming flower which was discovered in Brazil in 1823 by a French commission.'' It was named ``petunia'' because of its resemblence to the tobacco plant known to the natives as ``petun.'' A book I like to browse in is Harold McGee's ``On Food and Cooking'' (Charles Scribner's and Sons, New York, 1984). McGee's 684-page volume ranges far and wide in history and science. On fruits and vegetables, he deals, among many other things, with tantalizing questions, such as why onions make us cry. Delving into the background of food can absorb one completely, as witness Margaret Visser's 351-page ``Much Depends on Dinner'' (Grove Press, New York, 1984). If you want the lowdown on the lettuce you're growing, look it up here. She has 37 pages on it. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: George Bria retired from the AP in 1981 after 40 years that included coverage of World War II from Italy.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Nov. 15, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Doctors Seek New Ways To Care for Elderly in Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Doctors are trying to find out why some older patients in hospitals get well physically but never seem to recover emotionally. ``The illness gets better, but the patient gets worse,'' said Robert M. Palmer, a geriatrician at University Hospitals of Cleveland. Palmer and Dr. C. Seth Landefeld recently received a $485,000 grant from the John A. Hartford Foundation to study elderly patients affected by ``dysfunctional syndrome.'' The doctors said some patients who are hospitalized can no longer perform simple tasks, such as walking, bathing and dressing, when there seems to be no physical reason. Landefeld said up to 30 percent of patients over 75 lose some ability. Part of the grant was used to remodel a hospital unit to determine whether a change in atmosphere can reduce the incidence of the syndrome. The 15-bed unit, which opened in July, represents a departure in the way such patients are cared for, the doctors said. Greater emphasis is placed on how well a patient is eating, walking, sleeping and using the bathroom and on signs of depression. The doctors plan to compare how well patients do in the new unit with results from other hospital units. ---
DOC.HEAD: At 65, He's Newest Prosecutor
DOC.TEXT: Sol Weinberg has the enthusiasm of a kid just out of law school. Weinberg is practically just out of law school, but he's no kid. The Camp Hill resident, who recently became a Dauphin County assistant district attorney, is 65. He retired as a lieutenant colonel after a 24-year Army career, including combat in World War II, Korea and Vietnam. Weinberg remembers reading at 15 about Clarence Darrow, the celebrated attorney of the ``Scopes Monkey Trial.'' ``The seed was planted years ago and never left the back of my mind,'' he said. Last year he became what officials at Dickinson Law School believe is their oldest graduate. His new boss, District Attorney Richard A. Lewis, said Weinberg's age wasn't really a consideration in his hiring for the $24,000-a-year job. ``True, most of our attorneys are right out of law school and in their mid to late 20s,'' said Lewis. ``There are some exceptions to that rule, but very few. But in Sol's case, anybody who wants to be a district attorney that bad deserves it.'' ``I like it very much,'' Weinberg said. ``I'm just getting my feet wet.'' He has about 10 cases assigned to him so far - ``just run-of-the-mill kinds of court cases.'' Law school was tough and the hours long, and Weinberg said he asked himself at times why he didn't just pack it in and go to the golf course. ---
DOC.HEAD: Curbs on `Medigap' Will Help Consumers, Group Says
DOC.TEXT: The National Consumer's Union says the impact of increased Medicare premiums and taxes will be offset by meaningful new protection for those buying supplemental ``Medigap'' insurance. Since 1965, when Medicare was established, ``consumers have complained bitterly about sharp sales practices, rip-off policies and skyrocketing rates,'' said Gail Shearer, a Consumer's Union executive. The Medigap private insurance market was intended to help fill gaps in Medicare health insurance coverage for the elderly. But Ms. Shearer said it has left consumers ``confused and overwhelmed.'' ``They waste money on unnecessary coverage, cannot tell a good policy from a bad one and often have no one to turn to except the insurance agent for advice,'' she said. The Consumers Union said the new curbs on ``Medigap'' include: - Requirements that companies package insurance benefits in similar fashion, allowing older people to compare policies. - Establishment of state and local counseling programs to help the elderly make the best insurance coverage decisions. - Requirements that private insurance companies pay more in benefits. Companies had been encouraged to pay out 60 percent on premiums collected. Now they will be required to pay out 65 percent. - Forbidding the sale of duplicative and unnecessary policies. ---
DOC.HEAD: New Tests Toward Preventing Falls
DOC.TEXT: New tests for impaired balance in older people may help discover a way to anticipate and prevent falls, one of the chief hazards to the overall health of the elderly, researchers report. The balance tests involve how far one can reach while standing. Researchers at Duke University and at the Veterans Administration Medical Center at Durham, N.C., conclude that the test may be useful not only for measuring balance but for detecting change in balance over time and helping in the design of protective environments for balance-impaired older people. Reporting in the November issue of The Journal of Gerontology, Pamela W. Duncan of Duke's Center for the Study of Aging says using the act of reaching as a measure is practical and can easily be performed at home or in nursing homes.

Trans World Airlines Inc. has proposed buying Pan Am Corp. for $150 million in cash and $300 million in securities, the two struggling airlines said Sunday. The proposal is contingent on Pan Am calling off its $400 million agreement to sell important U.S.-London routes to United Airlines' parent, said Pamela Hanlon, Pan Am spokeswoman. TWA, which also flies into London's Heathrow airport, stipulated that Pan Am and TWA would have to sell overlapping international routes if the buyout is completed, she said. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - More than half the securities fraud charges against Charles H. Keating Jr. were jeopardized by a judge who said they cannot stand as written. Superior Court Judge Lance Ito said Friday that in 20 of the 42 counts against the Arizona developer and three co-defendants, the indictment appeared to be lacking. He said two other counts violated the defendants' right to due process because they were too vague. Keating, the former head of American Continental Corp., was jailed for 33 days on a 42-count indictment. He posted a reduced bond of $300,000 last month. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Fear of war in the Persian Gulf jolted oil prices for the third straight month in October, but slowing economic growth held wholesale price inflation for non-food and non-energy items to zero. The Labor Department said Friday its Producer Price Index for finished goods, one step short of retail, jumped a seasonally adjusted 1.1 percent last month. That followed increases of 1.6 percent in September and 1.3 percent in August, bringing the annual inflation rate for the year so far to levels not seen in nine years. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The vast majority of top economists in a monthly survey believe a recession will begin before year's end, but most predict it will be brief and relatively mild, a prominent economic newsletter reported. Blue Chip Economic Indicators said 80 percent of the 55 economists in its survey, released Friday, feel a downturn will start before the end of 1990. Another 5 percent said the slump would start in 1991. --- RIYADH, Saudi Arabia (AP) - Saudi Arabia expects to be producing 8.5 million barrels of oil a day soon and is considering expanding its oil industry to put out 10 million barrels a day despite the threat of war with Iraq. Saddam Hussein has threatened to devastate the kingdom's main oilfields in the northeastern desert if the U.S.-dominated multinational force in Saudi Arabia launches an offensive to liberate occupied Kuwait. The Saudis have already raised their oil output to 8.2 million barrels a day, a 10-year high and a 57 percent increase since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Federal savings and loan regulators may seek up to $10 billion from Drexel Burhnam Lambert Inc. for junk bond investment losses at more than 20 thrifts, people involved in the case said. A lawyer for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. said Friday that ``very substantial claims'' would be filed next week against the collapsed Wall Street firm now in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. The claims are to be negotiated along with dozens of other civil actions in the bankruptcy reorganization. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Dow Jones & Co. Inc. said it was boosting advertising rates for 1991 at The Wall Street Journal, the nation's largest daily newspaper. At the same time, the company said Friday it was closing the composing operations at its printing plant in Naperville, Ill., and transferring the plant's responsibilities to a plant in Dallas, for a net reduction of 30 jobs. The moves come as Dow Jones begins an austerity program under which it has frozen capital spending, is trying to hold salary spending in 1991 at 1990 levels and is taking other steps to cut costs. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - President Bush has vetoed a bill intended to block drug companies from reaping windfall profits through monopolistic marketing of drugs that treat rare diseases. The bill, vetoed Friday, applies to ``orphan drugs'' used against diseases that affect fewer than 200,000 people. It was designed to foster more competition by eliminating the seven-year exclusive marketing rights granted under current law to companies that develop such drugs. --- SYDNEY, Australia (AP) - Qantas Airways will reduce its work force by 500 by the end of February to help it survive an industrywide downturn prompted by higher jet fuel costs, chief executive John Ward said. Ward also said Friday that five Boeing 747s would be sold earlier than planned and flying hours would be cut back, as part of a cost-cutting plan imposed because of rising jet fuel prices. ---

The stock market staged a broad rally Friday, inspired by falling interest rates and hopes for a more generous credit policy at the Federal Reserve.The Dow Jones industrials average climbed 44.80 to 2,488.61. The dollar declined broadly in slow trading. Bonds jumped. Soybean futures tumbled; oil and precious metal futures fell; cattle futures rose; and pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Woes Create Boom for Bankruptcy Lawyers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Roger Frankel's golf game is deteriorating. Gerald Munitz had hoped to take it easy and spend ore time with his wife and six children. The economic downturn has breathed new life into what had been a shunned speciality - bankruptcy law - and Frankel and Munitz are part of the boom. Law schools report that more students are interested in learning about bankruptcy, though some prefer to call it corporate restructuring. ``Certainly, there is a feeling it's a much more stable part of the profession right now,'' said June Thompson of Harvard law school's career services office. The newfound interest in bankruptcy law is due, in part, to a credit crunch among corporations and individuals that took part in the wheeling and dealing and spend-now, pay-later economics of the Reagan era. The Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts said the number of bankruptcy petitions filed annually nationwide has doubled in the past five years to more than 725,000. Corporate bankruptcies comprise less than 10 percent of the total. Most involve individuals seeking a way out from under a mountain of debt, often caused by running up credit card charges. Frankel, a bankruptcy lawyer for 20 years, said, ``I have never seen it like this'' in the nation's capital. His five-day work week of the past is gone. Since last spring, he's been on the job 10 hours to 12 hours a day, six days a week. ``My golf game is suffering. Seriously, I have young kids I'd like to see grow up. It's difficult,'' he said. Munitz said it is the same in the nation's heartland. His Chicago practice is taking up more and more of his time ``just at the point in life when you're hoping to take things easier,'' he said. Munitz, 57, and a father of six children ranging in age from 11 to 27, said he would like to see more of them and his wife than his work permits. The sums of money also have changed since he started practicing. ``As a young lawyer, when someone owed a million dollars, that was all the money in the world,'' he said. ``It's peanuts these days. We're accustomed to dealing with a billion dollars in debt. The numbers are mind-boggling.'' The competition for bankruptcy experts has law firms scrambling to hire them. ``There are a lot more bankruptcy lawyers, particularly among young people who five or eight year ago turned their nose up at this kind of thing,'' said Nathan Feinstein, a bankruptcy expert here. Feinstein, who heads an American Bar Association committee on bankruptcy law, said that in the early 1980s only a handful of the nation's 200 largest law firms had a bankruptcy department. Today, nearly all of them have teams of bankruptcy attorneys. Many have acquired bankruptcy ``boutiques,'' small firms of perhaps a dozen or fewer lawyers who practice the specialty. The demand has become so great that bankruptcy attorneys have been flooded with offers to switch firms, Feinstein said. ``You start worrying if you haven't been called by a headhunter this week,'' he said. Job placement firms say the hunt for bankruptcy expertise is not limited to the traditional financial centers, New York, Los Angeles and Chicago. The nation's capital, for example, is a seller's market for attorneys - due only in part to the state of the local economy. There have been a number of major bankruptcies in the Washington, D.C., area, and a downturn in what once was considered a recession-proof real estate market. The collapse of the National Bank of Washington alone has spawned a cottage industry for lawyers. More than three-dozen lawyers showed up in a federal courtroom here recently to handle a spate of cases arising from the bank's demise. ``All I know is the bank lost, I lost and the lawyers won,'' said Luther M. Hodges, former chairman of the bank's parent company. Some businesses go belly up in bankruptcy and sell off their assets. But in most bankruptcy proceedings, the overextended borrower engages in what is called restructuring or reorganization. Creditors are paid a fraction of what they are owed as the debtor is placed under strict court scrutiny. Ironically, bankruptcies do not necessarily jump when a recession hits. The opposite may be true as lenders decide it's a bad time to collect when the value of corporate assets is reduced.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street's `Sex Symbol' Celebrates 20 Years On PBS
DOC.NOTE: Eds: In 3rd graf, `Friday' is Nov. 16 and `next Monday' is Nov. 19. Also moved in advance. Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Combining anemic puns with relevant statistics, Louis Rukeyser grins and winks his way into the homes of 10 million television viewers every Friday. Since 1970, Rukeyser has demystified the jargon and gyrations of the economy. His irreverant attitude toward the often-stuffy subject has made his show, Wall Street Week, one of the most popular half hours on public TV. A 20th anniversary program with some of the show's best guests will air Friday from the popular Tavern On The Green restaurant in New York. A one-hour retrospective will follow on next Monday. The rakish, white-haired Rukeyser is one of the most durable television personalities on the air, rivaling veteran luminaries such as Mr. Rogers, Johnny Carson and Julia Child. He is known for painful fits of prose. Once while answering a viewer's letter on investing in a hairpiece manufacturer, Rukeyser said, ``If all your money seems to be hair today and gone tomorrow, we'll try to make it grow by giving you the bald facts on how to get your investments toupee.'' After a market slump, he considered changing the name of the show to Wall Street Wake. He often consoles viewers by telling them to remember that its only their money, not their life. ``We have in America a bad tendency that things have to be either serious or fun,'' he said, before taping the show at Maryland Public Television in suburban Baltimore. ``Whereas in real life, this isn't true. The teachers we all remember in high school and college were not the ones who put us to sleep. I don't think any of us should apologize for not being dull. ``Nobody wants to come home on a Friday to be `educated.' First you have to pull them into the tent.'' Along the way, Rukeyser was dubbed by People magazine as the only sex symbol of the ``dismal science'' of economics. The New York Daily News identified him as the ``economic guru of the industry.'' ``Outside of the Wall Street Journal, Rukeyser has been a pioneer in demonstrating the popular appeal of quality business journalism,'' said Thomas Rosenstiel, a media cretic for the Los Angeles Times. ``He is especially good at proving that this stuff can be interesting and useful without being deadly dull.'' Rukeyser, 57, appears each week with three panelists, chosen from a pool of money managers and financial analysts, who question the guest of the week, such as the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission or noted economist John Kenneth Galbraith. In addition, technical analysts, whom he calls elves, vote on a weekly ``Elves Index'' that assesses the strength or weakness of the economy. Rukeyser doesn't makes any predictions other than to say he is a long-term bull. He constantly issues disclaimers on stock tips offered by guests of the show. Nonetheless, their recommendations often cause share prices to rise sharply the week after the show airs. Ralph Acampora, head of Prudential-Bache Securities' technical analysis division and one of Rukeyser's elves, credits him with starting business coverage on TV. ``When I started with Prudential, I told them I wanted a big chart room and a television,'' Acampora said. ``They asked me why I wanted a TV, and I told them, `Mrs. O'Brien sitting at home has the greatest information in the world.''' That mythical viewer is watching business news on Cable News Network and Financial News Network ``and its all because of Lou,'' Acampora said. Rukeyser, a former foreign correspondent for ABC and The (Baltimore) Sun, became the first economic commentator for a network in 1968 with ABC. He moonlighted on the PBS show for three years before leaving ABC, complaining about television coverage of economics. He still maintains economics is the most poorly covered area of American journalism. ``The prevailing view is that the subject of economics is too dull and-or too complicated to hold an audience larger than the capacity of your average telephone booth,'' he said. ``I think that's nonsense. I think there is a hunger in the American public for clear, believable, understandable, usable pocketbook information.'' Despite his bullish outlook, he concedes the economy is currently looking bleak, but he's quick to remind anyone that he doesn't invest for short-term profit. ``Punk, anemic, weak, getting weaker. The outlook for the next few months is soggy at best,'' Rukeyser said. ``But even with minimal policy changes we can be on our way again by 1992.'' Rukeyser, who also writes a syndicated newspaper column, lectures and has written two books, is known for being tough on his panelists and guests. He continually pleads with them to speak in English. ``Jargon is a very convenient shield for people not entirely sure of what they are saying,'' he said. Rukeyser says he will continue doing the show as long as it is fun, which it still is, and as long as his audience still wants him. Or as he might put it: His stock may be maturing, but his ratings are bullish and the dividends rewarding. So rally 'round the tube in confidence the guru will keep your interest primed.

DOC.HEAD: Leaner, Wiser Thrift Industry Gathers for Annual Convention
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan executives gathering in the luxury hotels atop Nob Hill for their 98th annual convention represent a smaller, humbler and healthier group of businesses than in years past. Fifteen months after enactment of President Bush's thrift bailout program, many of the nation's troubled S&Ls are gone - closed, sold to new owners with government assistance, or placed under the management of federal regulators. This year's convention of the U.S. League of Savings Institutions, which began Sunday, will be attended by executives from the ``healthiest of the healthy'' - about 600 of the remaining 2,900 S&Ls, according James Grohl, senior vice president of the trade association. On average, they hold tangible capital equal to 4.3 percent of their assets - nearly half again as much as required under the reforms of last year's S&L law, Grohl said. Capital is a key measure of financial health. It is the investment of an institution's owner, which serves as a cushion to absorb loss. The emphasis on the survivors is evident in the league's changing leadership. Donald Shackelford, chairman of State Savings Bank in Columbus, Ohio, will be installed as the group's new chairman, the top elective office in the organization. Shackelford replaces Kenneth D. Seaton, chairman of D&N Savings Bank, Hancock, Mich., and is vaulting over the head of Robert B. O'Brien, chairman of Carteret Savings Bank, Morristown, N.J., who will serve as league vice chairman for a second year. State Savings Bank's tangible capital is 6.5 percent of its assets, placing it among the top 11 percent of institutions, according to Sheshunoff Information Services, an Austin, Texas, consulting firm. In contrast, D&N has been forced to lay off employees and cut its dividend. Carteret's holding company, AmBase Corp., is laden with debt and losing money. ``The incoming guy is symbolic. He's Mr. Goodthrift,'' said Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America, a trade group representing smaller, community-based banks. ``The leadership has to come from those that are strong, those that are successful and those that will survive,'' League President Frederick L. Webber said. ``Catering to the lowest common denominator ... cannot be the case.'' The league was once one of the nation's most powerful lobbying groups. But its power has shrunk along with the industry it represents. This year, 2,978 S&L executives and their spouses, league staff members, journalists and others are expected to attend the convention, down from 3,862 in 1989 and 5,500 in 1988. The surviving thrift officials are left pondering how to regain even a portion of their former clout and their good name. ``They're lepers. They know it and they're unhappy about it,'' said financial institution analyst Bert Ely of Alexandria, Va. President Reagan visited the convention in 1982; George Bush did the same in 1985 as vice president. In other years the convention attracted, at the very least, a Cabinet secretary or congressional committee chairman. This year, not one member of Congress is scheduled to appear. At least three House incumbents with ties to the S&L industry were unseated last week: Rep. John Hiler, R-Ind., accused by his opponent of having a pro-S&L voting record; Rep. Charles Pashayan, R-Calif., who interceded with regulators on behalf of Lincoln Savings and Loan owner Charles Keating, and Rep. Denny Smith, R-Ore., who sat on the board of a local S&L. Convention headliners this year are Housing and Urban Development Undersecretary Alfred DelliBovi and two Treasury Department officials - Office of Thrift Supervision Director Timothy Ryan and Comptroller of the Currency Robert Clarke, a bank regulator. The league's record of success in Washington has been mixed this year. It successfully persuaded the Office of Thrift Supervision to relax limits on the dividends struggling but solvent thrifts may pay stockholders and to increase the size of the loans healthy thrifts may make to one borrower. But its drive to get Congress to dilute rules forcing the industry to concentrate 70 percent of its assets on housing went nowhere. The league also hasn't persuaded the thrift office to allow its members to convert to state savings banks, which operate with fewer restrictions on their lending. Next year one of the group's goals will be to prevent Congress from saddling it with more of the S&L bailout cost. Another is to keep federal deposit insurance from being dramatically scaled back.

DOC.HEAD: After Gulf Crisis, Analysts Envision Oil Glut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Once the Persian Gulf crisis is over, the world will find itself flooded with oil as nations start arguing over how much crude each should pump, experts believe. OPEC nations that stepped up production to offset the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude will be caught in a double whammy as prices come crashing down and the previously boycotted oil pushes its way into the market. The producers will have a tough time trying to agree on who should cut back and by how much, analysts say. ``That's inevitable, and it may be very difficult for them to do, because when the crisis ends, the 11 OPEC countries other than Iraq and Kuwait will already be producing more oil than the world needs from all of OPEC,'' said Philip Dodge, an oil analyst with Nomura Securities International Inc. After Iraq invaded Kuwait in early August, the international embargo of their oil created a shortfall of about 4 million barrels of crude a day. Saudi Arabia and Venezuela immediately began pushing for higher production levels to erase the deficit. OPEC oil ministers eventually agreed to temporarily lift the cartel's quotas. Within weeks, the combination of more oil and less demand had virtually erased the shortfall. Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest exporter, says it plans to keep pumping more. Since the crisis began, Saudi production has gone up about 57 percent, from around 5.2 million barrels a day to around 8.2 million barrels a day. The Saudis hope to bring production to 8.5 million barrels a day in the near future, and they want to raise capacity to a potential level of 10 million barrels a day within the next two years. It remains unclear whether a war in the Gulf would damage any Middle East production facilities or how long it would take to repair any damage. The Iran-Iraq war showed it is hard to stop the flow of oil through repeated bombings, although experts agree that Iraqi troops might be able to cause greater damage to Kuwaiti facilities by blowing them up with explosives placed right at the wellhead. Regardless of any damage or its longevity, the oil markets will eventually feel the glut as Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude gets back in. Once that happens, the nations that increased their production during the crisis will probably be reluctant to cut back, particularly since their oil will bring far less money per barrel. ``All the OPEC producers are going to be at higher levels than they were before the invasion,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``Other members are probably going to be reluctant to cut back on production. They'll have to adjust the quotas and who's going to be able to produce what, and that sort of thing.'' It won't be easy, and some in the industry believe the strains on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will be great. Dodge said he thinks Venezuela might even weaken its ties to the Arab oil producers and try to align itself more closely with consuming nations. ``I would say for all intents and purposes, Venezuela's out of OPEC,'' Dodge said. ``That's partly because the Arab members of OPEC were cheating on them so much. I think Venezuela was the most well-behaved of all the OPEC countries.'' There have already been some small oversupply problems, as Saudi Arabia and Iran have had trouble selling all the oil they are pumping, because buyers are not interested in getting the entire stock of certain less-desirable grades. The same thing happened when the Bush administration decided to sell 5 million barrels from the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve in an effort to bring down spiraling prices. Some 800,000 barrels of an inferior grade did not have a single bidder, but the war-induced high price of oil did not budge on such evidence of strong supply.

DOC.HEAD: New Owners of Argentine Phone Company Plan Changes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The new owners of Argentina's dilapidated telephone system face a huge task as they try to reform a business that has been run down during 42 years of state ownership. The Empresa Nacional de Telecomunicaciones was once one of the best systems on the continent, but it is now in a state of disarray. When it rains, lines go dead. On sunny days, calls dialed correctly often ring the wrong number, or get crossed so that several voices are heard. FAX and computer tramsmissions break off because of the weak quality of the lines. As many as 500,000 lines - one of every seven - may be out of service at any moment. Repairs can take months. Regional circuits are so crowded that during the business day it is difficult to call the provinces from the capital. Telephone books are years out of date, except for those in the capital. Services like call forwarding and speed dialing don't exist. ``There is a lot to do,'' said Jan Jacques Damlamian, the industrial director of France Telecom, which owns France Cables and Radio and has become a partial owner of the Argentine system, known as ENTel. On Thursday, a group of investors led by the Spanish phone company Telefonica and New York-based Citibank bought a 60 percent share of ENTel's southern half, a system of 1.5 million lines that stretch from Buenos Aires west to the Andes and south through Patagonia to Tierra del Fuego. Another group led by the Italian and French phone companies STET and Cables and Radio, respectively, and New York-based J.P. Morgan bank, bought ENTel's northern half - 1.6 million lines from Buenos Aires west to Chile and north to Bolivia, Paraguay, Brazil and Uruguay. The privatization, with a value of about $1.34 billion, is one of the largest in Latin American history. Despite the sorry state of the system, the new owners are confident they can turn things around and start turning a profit. One way to achieve savings will probably be cuts in the ENTel staff of 43,000, about one person for every 72 lines. Telefonica manages to get by with one worker for every 186 lines. ``We're not the little sisters of the poor. We're here to make money,'' Telefonica president Candido Velasquez told the newspaper La Nacion. Rates were raised drastically in the months leading up to the sale. They will be kept high. So will installation charges. A new phone line for a business may cost $2,500, Telefonica directors said at a news conference. ``Good service costs more than bad service,'' Velasquez said. In the past, ENTel employees paid reduced rates for their phones. ``In principle, I'm against that,'' Telefonica's director of international business, Luis Martin de Bustamante, said. Costs will also be brought down by modernizing outdated equipment. Tens of thousands of lines that are out of service will be repaired so they can be brought back on-line, and hundreds of thousands of new lines will be installed. Also, the new owners will try to bolster business by getting several hundred thousand people off of the lengthy waiting lists for new phones. The penetration level of one phone for every 11 Argentines is relatively low by the standards of developed countries. The new owners stress that change won't come overnight.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T and Japanese NEC Win Indonesian Telephone Contract
DOC.NOTE: Eds: One name correct for Suharto and Murdiono
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. and Japan's NEC Corp. have won a multimillion dollar contract to install 700,000 new digital telephone lines on Java, Bali, Sulawesi and Sumatra, a spokesman of the state-owned telecommunications company said Monday. Muhammad Gempita said the government has chosen the American and Japanese companies over three other bidders. The three other companies were Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan, Ericson Australia Pty. of Australia and Alcatel NV of the Netherlands. The government last February put off awarding a contract for a $300 million telecommunications project as none of the bidders fully met its requirements with regard to funding and price. AT&T and NEC had been the last companies in the contest until the government's decision for a retendering. The announcement came after reports that the U.S. and the Japanese governments were pressing the Indonesian government to give the contract to bidders from their countries. The spokesman did not give many details on the contracts won by the two bidders, but informed sources said the scope of the digital telephone project has been changed extensively from its original plan. The retendered contract originally called for the supply of only 350,000 line units for a price of $300 million. The scope of work now seemed to have been enlarged and the two winners will now each supply 350,000 lines, of which 200,000 lines will be imported and the other 150,000 lines will be made locally in a joint venture with a local company. The value of the contract is still to be negotiated, the spokesman said. The president director of the state-owned telecommunications company, Cacu Sudarijanto, said the contracts will be signed with both companies in January and they will be expected to complete work in three years.

DOC.HEAD: Union Rejects General Dynamics Contract, Agrees to One-Week Extension
DOC.TEXT: The largest labor union at General Dynamics narrowly rejected the company's offer for a new three-year contract Sunday, but did not vote to strike. Company officials and the 10,000-member International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers agreed to a one-week extension of their current contract. The existing agreement, which covers an estimated 10,000 production and maintenance workers at GD's Fort Worth Division, would have expired at 11:59 p.m. Sunday. With just hours to spare, union members voted 3,898 to 3,700 to reject the company's final offer during a tense meeting at the Tarrant County Convention Center. Instead of calling for a vote to strike, union leaders recommended extending the deadline to midnight Nov. 18. The extension was approved by a 5-to-1 majority. Union president Pat Lane said the IAM asked for the extra time because GD obtained a temporary restraining order Friday that would prohibit union members from picketing the company's Fort Worth plant during rush hours when lines of cars are trying to get in and out of the plant. Union attorney Rod Tanner said he plans to file a motion today to dissolve the restraining order. Three main issues apparently separates the two sides: wage increases and bonuses, GD's proposal that workers pay a portion of health care premiums, and the company's practice of sending work outside the plant to other suppliers. GD's best and final offer provided for general wage increases of 5.5 percent the first year and 3 percent the following two years of the contract. The company also offered a $1,000 bonus payable Nov. 30 if union members ratified the contract. Both sides clearly would like to avoid a strike, with union members facing an uncertain economy and GD pressed to meet Air Force production schedules for its F-16 Fighting Falcon jet. Both sides still carry bitter memories of a 17-day strike in 1984 that led to an outbreak of violence at picket lines outside the plant's main gate.

DOC.HEAD: Supply Woes, Environment Concern of Organization
DOC.TEXT: A toughened Clean Air Act and the threat to oil supplies poised by the Persian Gulf crisis are among the challenges to be addressed by oil industry experts attending the American Petroleum Institute's annual meeting here. About 1,200 industry executives and analysts are expected at the three-day meeting that ends Tuesday. The passage in October of the new Clean Air Act prompted the petroleum and auto industries to conduct a joint effort to develop a new gasoline to meet the stricter standards for gasoline emissions. Industry officials say the act has mandated a product for which manufacturing technology does not exist, and may not exist when the cleaner gasoline is required to be on the market. The Clean Air Act requires a 15 percent reduction in gas emissions by 1995, and 25 percent by 2000. Because of the new standards, other fuels - such as ethanol - may become more desirable. But low oil prices in the 1980s helped weaken the effort to develop alternative fuels. Raymond G. Friend, vice president of High Plains Corp. of Wichita, Kan., which produces ethanol, says ethanol's reputation as damaging to autos is false and has been challenged in a federal lawsuit against nine oil companies. ``The anti-ethanol campaign has diminished and demand is building,'' he said. A number of oil companies, among them Amoco and Texaco, have introduced reformulated, less-polluting gasolines. The crisis in the Persian Gulf has increased the relationship between supply and environmental issues. The crisis has increased oil industry interest in environmentally sensitive areas of the United States now closed to drilling as possible new sources of oil. They include the outer continental shelf, federal lands in the lower 48 states and the Arctic Wildlife Refuge in Alaska. But Charles J. DiBona, president of the petroleum institute, acknowledges that a lack of public trust stemming from the Exxon Valdez oil spill in March 1989 reduces oil industry options. ``There is not a lot of recognition that we ought to address the question of access to public lands (for oil exploration),'' DiBona said recently. ``This (Persian Gulf) crisis has not caused people to reassess opening the arctic refuge or offshore drilling.'' DiBona says domestic exploration is an answer to U.S. dependence on foreign oil supplies. The number of drilling rigs in the United States has increased to 1,100 from about 900 since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. But new drilling will be fighting the recent downward trend in U.S. oil production from 3.7 billion gallons in 1985 to 3.3 billion gallons in 1989. ``There is a real need to rethink the domestic exploration strategy,'' said James M. Patterson, professor of marketing at Indiana University in Bloomington. ``About 80 percent of the holes ever drilled are in the lower 48 states, so there are probably no great surprises here.'' Patterson says oil companies must pursue oil in other areas outside the Middle East if exploration is not allowed in the arctic refuges. He said Mexico, despite its long history of opposition to U.S. participation in its oil industry, may be willing to change. Venezuela, Canada, Romania and the Soviet Union may also present opportunities, Patterson said. DiBona said the institute faces several legislative issues including its continuing effort to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to Drilling. He said the industry is concerned about congressional consideration of a Resource Conservation and Recovery Act that would regulate underground reinjection and storage and state-level attempts to prevent large petroleum companies from operating their own gasoline stations.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Saturn Will Add 7 Models by 1994
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp.'s Saturn subsidiary is planning to produce 10 models by 1994 and possibly expand its current one-plant operation, a trade journal said today. Saturn Corp. sent three models of cars - single- and twin-cam sedans and a sporty coupe model - to showrooms Oct. 12. The Automotive News reported in today's editions that the company would add a luxury sedan and coupe, a coupe convertible, two station wagons and two two-door hatchbacks. At least two of those vehicles would be added in each of the next three model years, the publication said. Saturn spokesman Mark Tanner refused to comment on the report Sunday. ``We don't talk about future plans,'' he said. A Saturn dealership official told The Automotive News that Saturn has tentative plans for a small pickup and a second plant or plant expansion. The dealership official, who requested anonymity, told the publication Saturn officials ``said they wanted to give us a minivan and a small pickup, but they said they couldn't do that before 1996 because they'd need to build another plant.'' He also said a minivan is on the drawing board. Saturn's $2 billion Spring Hill, Tenn., plant can produce up to 240,000 vehicles annually. The Automotive News said production there was scheduled to reach 303,000 by the 1993 model year and 360,000 the following model year. That likely would force Saturn to build a second plant or expand the existing facility, it said.

DOC.HEAD: USX, Union Recess Talks
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. and the United Steelworkers union have recessed talks without reaching an early contract settlement. USW chief negotiator Andrew ``Lefty'' Palm said Sunday the company's proposal fell short on wages, on cost-of-living hikes for retirees and on job security in the event USX sells its steel division, as some analysts predict. ``The company is obviously disappointed that no agreement was reached, but I remain optimistic that a competitive agreement in the interests of all concerned parties will be reached before the Feb. 1 expiration date,'' said Thomas W. Sterling, vice president of employee relations for USX's steel division. Bargainers started talks Oct. 15 on a new contract for 18,000 USW members in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Alabama, Minnesota and California. Although the four-year contract runs for 10 more weeks, the company and union had imposed a settlement deadline of Nov. 10. The two sides met for four hours Saturday in Coraopolis, Pa., before deciding to recess. No date was set for talks to resume. ``This union tried very hard to get an early agreement,'' Palm said at a news conference. Palm said the company proposal would have restored wages to the 1982 level but did not provide for further increases. Steelworkers have made wage concessions to USX for the past eight years. Complicating the negotiations was USX's recent announcement that it plans to make its steel division a separate subsidiary, prompting some analysts to predict the division will be sold. The union wants a contract that restores $1.30 an hour in concessions plus offers compensation for the past 18 months, when USX steelworkers were paid less than their counterparts at other domestic steel makers. Palm said the company's offer was less generous than terms accepted by USW members at LTV Steel Inc., Bethlehem Steel Inc., National Steel Inc., Armco Inc. and Inland Steel Inc. The current contract was reached after a six-month work stoppage in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: TWA Offers Pan Am $150 Million in Cash and $300 Million in Securities
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines Inc. wants to buy Pan Am Corp., but only if Pan Am's deal to sell important routes to London falls through, TWA chairman Carl Icahn said. Icahn has proposed offering about $150 million in cash and securities with a face value of $300 million for the struggling carrier. Although TWA is considered to be in better health than Pan Am, both have been hurt by rising fuel prices since the Iraqi invasion and fewer passengers since the economy started weakening. In a telephone interview late Sunday, Icahn said Pan Am Chairman Thomas Plaskett had asked him to make an offer in case Pan Am's talks with United Airlines parent UAL Corp. fall through. As part of a $400 million deal, Pan Am has agreed to sell key routes between New York and London to UAL. Icahn, who sent his proposal in a letter to Plaskett Friday, said his proposal would only be valid if the Pan Am-UAL route deal was terminated. The letter emphasizes that TWA does not want to disturb the arrangement with United, according to a source who spoke on condition of anonymity. If TWA buys Pan Am, duplicated routes like those to London's Heathrow airport, would be sold, Pan Am said. Icahn's letter, which was dated and delivered late Friday, proposed Pan Am shareholders receive $1 per share in cash and securities with a face value of $2 per share. The securities, either preferred stock or promissory notes, could bring different market prices. Pan Am's stock was up 12{ cents at $1.75 early today on the New York Stock Exchange. Pan Am said in a statement it was still working to complete the route sale to United, but that the deal could be called off if it is not completed by Nov. 14. Joe Hopkins, a spokesman for United, would not comment on the TWA proposal. Icahn's letter also proposed buying the Pan Am Shuttle, which flies between Boston, New York and Washington, by the end of the year. TWA's proposal to buy the rest of the company is open through Nov. 16 and TWA would plan on completing the deal by the end of March. The Wall Street Journal reported recently that Pan Am's pilots might be willing to pay $150 million to $200 million for the shuttle alone. Subtracting other elements of Pan Am's deal with United, the London routes are valued at about $290 million. TWA and Pan Am are the only two U.S. airlines flying into London's Heathrow airport. Other duplications are between the U.S. and Paris and the U.S. and Rome. Pan Am last week announced that if it completed the route sale to United it would turn much of its attention to Latin America and bolster its Miami operations. Rising fuel prices since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has hurt many airlines. TWA last month announced 430 layoffs from its workforce of 33,000 to cope with the rising jet fuel prices and the economic downturn. TWA also said it would stop hiring and training new pilots and flight attendants. TWA, headquartered in Mt. Kisco, N.Y., earned $103.4 million in the second quarter of the year, but that included one-time gains from the sales of assets totalling $160.2 million. In the second quarter of 1989, the airline lost $4.4 million. Earlier this month, Pan Am announced it had lost $29.1 million, or 19 cents per share, for the third quarter. In the same period a year earlier the airline lost $18 million, or 12 cents a share. The airline cited rising jet fuel costs for the poor performance.

DOC.HEAD: Bad Weather Cuts Rig Count by 20
DOC.TEXT: Oklahoma led a list of several major oil producing states reporting declines in the number of working oil and gas rigs this past week, a new survey said Monday. The overall total of working rigs in the United States dropped by 20 to 1,124 from the previous week, Baker Hughes Inc. reported. The decrease, attributed partly to bad weather, followed several weeks of increases that had taken the total to its highest level since Dec. 28, 1987. The count a year ago was 1,045, the Houston-based toolmaker said. Last week, the count improved by 37 to 1,144. ``Part of that decline, good part of it, was the weather,'' said Ike Kerridge, a vice president at Baker Hughes. ``Oklahoma lost 16 rigs and we identified 11 of those that cannot move because of wet ground. Oklahoma had about four inches of rain last week.'' Kerridge said some of the losses were offset by a ``good increase in the offshore drilling rigs.'' Of the total rigs running as of Monday, 109 were offshore, 26 were in inland waters and 989 were on land, the toolmaker reported. Baker Hughes has kept track of the rig count - a widely watched index of drilling activity - since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not those producing oil. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Besides Oklahoma, other major oil producing states reporting rig losses for the week include Pennsylvania, which dropped by eight; Wyoming, down by five; California and Colorado, which each lost two; and Kansas, New Mexico and Ohio, which each lost one. Among states reporting gains for the week are Louisiana, which added eight; Texas, up by three; and Michigan and North Dakota, which each increased its count by one rig.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans, Wheat Higher; Corn Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grains and soybeans futures dipped at the outset of trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, but soybeans and wheat quickly rebounded. Soybean futures prices had fallen sharply Friday following an Agriculture Department report after Thursday's close, which indicated a larger supply of soybeans than many analysts expected. Grains, pressured by weak export business in the face of large world supplies, followed soybeans' slide. But prices rebounded for soybeans and wheat after the opening amid bargain-hunting and profit-taking. DOC.HEAD: AFT President Quits Channel One Board
DOC.TEXT: The president of the American Federation of Teachers has resigned from the board of advisers that Whittle Communications created in connection with its commercially-sponsored news program for teens in the classroom. AFT president Albert Shanker quit the board, contending a breach of trust with Knoxville-based Whittle and its Channel One television news program that is beamed to schools across the country. ``When I agreed to serve on the Channel One Council of Advisers, I made it clear in writing that my decision in no way constituted an endorsement either of the program or of advertising in the public schools,'' Shanker wrote Whittle chairman Chris Whittle. ``In fact, I explicitly stated my role would be that of a `watch dog,''' he wrote in the Oct. 12 letter. ``I should have realized that being on the council would inevitably lead to the perception that I endorsed Channel One,'' he wrote. ``But it was not until I saw my name and picture being used in Channel One promotional materials that this point was driven home.'' Shanker said his resignation was effective immediately and asked Whittle to stop using his name and picture in promotional materials. The AFT is formally opposed to TV commercials in the classroom and denounces the lack of funding that compels schools to accept commercials in return for TV equipment, such as Whittle offers with Channel One. Schools that sign up to show the Channel One news show to their students are loaned satellite dishes and television monitors for every classroom. They get to keep the equipmnet only as long as they show the 12-minutes news show with its ads every school day. Whittle spokesman Tom Ingram said Chris Whittle and Shanker had talked about the resignation. ``He was not able to attend any of the meetings, and the reason he joined was to have input,'' Ingram said. ``Being unable to attend, he was unable to have input.'' As for the promotion, Ingram said, ``We are going to go ahead and continue to use the material, and he understands.''

DOC.HEAD: P&G Sells Texas-based Chili Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: The Procter & Gamble Co. said Monday that William B. Reilly & Co. has bought Caliente Chili Inc., an Austin, Tex.-based subsidiary that P&G obtained in its merger with Noxell Corp. last year. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. Procter & Gamble said Caliente Chili, which makes chili and Mexican food products, does not fit into P&G's food businesses. P&G had worlwide sales of $24.1 billion in the year that ended June 30.
