DOC.HEAD: Newmont Wins Control of BHP Gold
DOC.TEXT: Newmont Australia Ltd. has won control of BHP Gold Ltd. after BHP Co. Ltd. accepted Newmont's offer for its 54.9 percent stake in the gold mining concern. Under terms of the stock swap, BHP will continue to own 23 percent of the new company which will be Australia's largest pure gold producer. BHP said in a statement Monday that the new company would be among the top 15 gold companies in the world with anticipated 1991 production of about 750,000 ounces. ``BHP has undertaken a broad program of due dilligence covering all major technical, legal and financial matters and is satisfied that the merger will provide the opportunity to strengthen its current investment in the Australian gold industry,'' BHP said. Newmont launched the bid in September after taking court action against a similar bid launched on it by Robert Champion de Crespigny's Poseidon group. Poseidon later abandoned its bid for Newmont, but retains a 19.9 percent stake in the company, which would be equivalent to about 12 percent of a merged Newmont-BHP Gold group.

DOC.HEAD: Chase Manhattan To Cut Back Its Spanish Operations
DOC.TEXT: Chase Manhattan Corp. is cutting back its Spanish operations and ``informal discussions'' are now under way with foreign and local banks to sell its retail and leasing operations, a spokesman for the New York-based banking company said Monday. Chase said it will retain its corporate banking arm in Spain, where it has 14 offices with 400 employees. The bank spokesman declined to confirm reports that some 60 people will reportedly be laid off under the cutback plans. The cutbacks are part of Chase's larger international restructuring strategy announced last June, calling for a $300 million reduction in operating expenses throughout the world.

DOC.HEAD: Increased Fuel Costs Force Northwest Airlines Earnings Lower
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines said Monday that higher fuel costs associated with the Middle East crisis caused a 47 percent drop in its third-quarter earnings and will result in a fourth-quarter loss. The nation's fourth largest airline reported net income of $91 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, down from $134 million for the same period in 1989. Operating revenues grew from $1.8 billion during the third quarter in 1989 to $2 billion to the same quarter this year, the airline said. Northwest said its fuel expense jumped 30.5 percent from last year's third quarter, from $259 million to $338 million. The escalation in prices followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``We anticipate that continued high fuel expenses for the remainder of the year will result in a fourth-quarter net loss,'' said John Dasburg, Northwest president and chief executive officer. Northwest said it has adopted a number of measures to deal with its soaring fuel bill, including fare increases, flight schedule reduction, deferral of non-essential expenses, and a ceiling on the number of people it employs. Northwest said operating expenses increased from $1.6 billion to $1.9 billion in the third quarter, while operating income decreased from $181 million to $116 million. Northwest's cash flow from operations was $195 million, compared with $174 million from the same quarter a year earlier. For the first nine months of 1990, Northwest posted net earnings of $111 million, down from $240 million for the first nine months of 1989. Operating revenues for the first nine months were $5.4 billion, up from $4.9 billion, and operating expenses grew from $4.6 billion to $5.3 billion. Operating income for the three quarters was $90 million, compared to $297 million in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: EgyptAir Orders 737s
DOC.TEXT: EgyptAir has ordered five Boeing 737-500s worth about $150 million, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said Monday. The Egyptian airline said it plans to use the planes on domestic flights and for service between Egypt and Europe. The new twin-engine jets will seat 108 to 132 passengers and have a range of 3,340 miles. For the year, Boeing has received firm orders for 418 planes, worth approximately $38.87 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Competitors Plan To Break Intel's Lucrative Computer Chip Monopoly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: With AM-Computer Show, Bjt. Embargoed by source until 6 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: Several competitors are trying to break Intel Corp.'s lucrative monopoly over a microprocessor that increasingly is the chip of choice for IBM personal computers and compatible models. Intel's 80386 microprocessor has been a runaway success, bringing in about a billion dollars a year in revenue and some of the highest profit margins the semiconductor industry has ever seen, said Michael Slater, editor of the newsletter Microprocessor Report. Microprocessors are fingernail-sized wafers of silicon containing circuitry that acts as the brains of personal computers. One of the would-be interlopers, Advanced Micro Devices Inc., began giving private demonstrations Monday of its 386 clone at the huge Comdex computer show here. AMD removed Intel's chips from several personal computers and replaced them with its own version. ``There are no compatibility problems with it - it works,'' said AMD spokesman David Frink. He said about 20 computer makers are testing the chip or have already evaluated it. A public announcement of the AMD microprocessor awaits a determination of its price and availability date, officials of the semiconductor company said. AMD says it used a process called reverse engineering to devise a chip that mimics the 386 but uses different circuitry. In fact, AMD says its chip is better because it uses less power. Several other semiconductor companies also are working on 386 clones, industry analysts say. But Intel, one of the world's largest semiconductor companies, is not sitting still while competitors try to chip away at its blockbuster product. It is involved in a thicket of legal conflicts with AMD, with which it once enjoyed a cooperative relationship. Intel has filed two lawsuits, one contending AMD has no right to a crucial component of the 386 chip called microcode, and the second charging that AMD would infringe on Intel's trademark if it uses the 386 name to market its chip. On Friday, a federal judge denied Intel's request for an injunction to block AMD from using the 386 name. But it was unclear whether the ruling would give computer makers who use the AMD chip the right to call them 386 machines. The microcode suit stems from a 1976 agreement in which Intel granted AMD the right to the patents and microcode for Intel microprocessors. Intel now claims AMD may only copy the microcode for its own use, not to sell chips containing it. Microcode is a set of software instructions contained in a memory device on each microprocessor. It tells the circuits how to process data. AMD, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., will devise microcode of its own to mimic Intel's if it loses the suit, Frink said. AMD also is involved in another legal battle with Intel that could result in AMD gaining rights to make a carbon copy of the 386 chip. That dispute, now in abritration, stems from a 1982 technology-sharing agreement between the two companies. Intel claims AMD reneged on the agreement. AMD says it met the terms of the pact and should be given access to the 386 chip, as well as $500 million in damages. An arbitrator ruled last month that Intel did not act in good faith in the dispute, but he delayed deciding whether AMD should gain rights to the 386 chip until another phase of the proceeding, which is scheduled to start this week. ``The lawyers are really doing well over Intel and AMD,'' said Slater, the newsletter editor. Intel's 386 chip, introduced in 1985, is becoming the favored microprocessor for International Business Machines Corp. personal computers and clones. It is faster than the 286 chip it succeeded but not as costly as Intel's top-of-the-line 486. Four companies, including AMD, make clones of the 286 chip under license from Intel, said Intel spokeswoman Pam Pollace from the company's Santa Clara, Calif., headquarters. But no such licenses are planned for the 386 chip despite the fact that Intel has been rationing its production to customers, Pollace said. She said Intel expects to meet demand by year's end. Dataquest, a high-tech research firm, says 7.3 million personal computers with the 386 chip and its lower-cost variant, the 386SX, will be shipped this year. Dataquest projects that shipments of 386-based machines will grow at a double-digit pace over the next four years, while those of computers with the 286 will decline about 7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Municipal Bonds Strong, Corporates Stagnant
DOC.TEXT: Municipal bonds prices were higher in early trading today, but corporate bond prices were little changed. Trading was subdued, however, as the market for U.S. government bonds was closed in observance of the Veteran's Day holiday. In earlier trading in London, U.S. Treasury bonds were buoyed by weak oil prices to close with prices firmly higher than levels reached in New York on Friday.

Gainers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, up 2} at 113; American Express, up 1} at 21]; General Electric, up 1| at 55], and Philip Morris, up } at 49{. Pan Am Corp. was unchanged at 1| in active trading following the weekend news of a conditional bid for Pan Am by Carl Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 2.30 to 173.47. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 2.96 at 293.99. Volume on the Big Board came to 113.01 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: Skeptical of Government Numbers and Budget Jargon
DOC.TEXT: Should we believe the government when it says the budget has been cut or the economy is still expanding? Private-sector economists, business people and others are increasingly skeptical of government jargon and statistics. Most recently, their eyebrows were raised by the government's figures for the third-quarter gross national product, which showed growth running at an annual rate of 1.8 percent, confounding a vast number of researchers who were convinced the report should have shown the economy shrinking. Walter J. Williams of American Business Econometrics, a Ridgewood, N.J., advisory firm that counts blue-chip corporations as clients, declared flatly that the supposed expansion will be revealed eventually as a contraction. Williams estimates that in reality the decline amounted to about 2 percent on an annual basis, and he expressed the personal opinion that the numbers were manipulated to influence the November elections. Economist E. Erich Heinemann was equally blunt, declaring the report of accelerated economic growth ``spurious'' and ``phony as a three-dollar bill.'' Referring to underlying assumptions, he said, ``the illogic is dazzling.'' Such comments are becoming widespread, and involve not just the accuracy of numbers but the intent of words as well. Economists and business people, for example, are upset that Americans believe Congress actually cut the budget. Among those angered by that interpretation are members of the U.S. Business and Industrial Council, made up of the heads of mainly small and medium-sized businesses, many of whom have had to cut their own budgets. The council, a conservative group based in Washington, issued a statement saying ``our member companies are increasingly frsutrated by the jargon of deficit reduction.'' The statement explained they ``cannot fathom the `current services' approach to budgeting, which allows for automatic increases in spending.'' The ``reduction,'' it says, allows for $240 billion in new spending. It is the statistical communications, however, that seem to receive the most criticism, and Williams asserts that some of the distrust arises from the suspicions that economic numbers are managed. For the past four years, Williams has questioned members of the National Association of Business Economists on the credibility of economic numbers, which in recent years have become more prominently displayed in the media. The chief complaint that his fellow economists have, he said, is that government agencies that produce statistics lack adequate funding and staff. But fears of manipulation, especially in election years, are growing, he ssaid. His survey in 1987 showed 15 percent of economist-respondents thought the staticstic were doctored. In 1988, an election year, the percentage rose to 33, dropped back to 15 in 1988 and soared to 39 in 1990, another election year. Williams said his surveys are ``blind,'' meaning respondents do not sign. But in the most recent survey, held in Washington in September, Williams said several government economists spoke to him about their own doubts. The report of higher gross national product in the third quarter was especially bewildering, since many economists had forecast in advance that it would fall. Unconvinced, they now look for downward revisions. Heinemann observes that the alleged pickup in GNP depended on an assumption that inflation slowed last summer, but that ``anyone who has gone to a supermarket or a gas station in the last few months knows that is not true.'' He points to inconsistencies: Industrial output was said to have risen, but other statistics fail to coincide. ``What happened to the goods? Did somebody buy them? Did they go into inventory? Were they exported?'' He said, ``The way the government tells the story, the answer is none of the above.'' But, he added, ``Clearly these figures cannot all be correct.''

DOC.HEAD: Public Inquiry Accuses Occidental of Safety Lapses in Rig Disaster
DOC.TEXT: A public inquiry into the Piper Alpha oil rig disaster accused Occidental Petroleum Ltd. of unsafe practices in the July 1988 explosion that killed 167 men. The inquiry published Monday also recommended that responsibility for oil platform safety be transferred from Britain's Department of Energy to the Health and Safety Executive. The report recommends a thorough overhaul of existing safety practices regarding oil rigs and a tough new regime for oil and gas companies that own and operate the rigs. Energy Secretary John Wakeham said he passed the inquiry's report on to Scotland's senior law officer to determine whether Occidental, the Piper Alpha operator, should be prosecuted. The Piper Alpha disaster was the world's worst oil rig explosion. The platform burst into flames when gas from ruptured pipelines caught fire and the emergency systems on the rig failed to operate. The smoke and flames were so intense that rescuing the men on the rig by helicopter or lifeboat was impossible. The 62 survivors reached the sea by rope and hoses and by jumping off the platform. ``At no stage was there a systematic attempt to lead men to escape,'' the report said. The report was written by Scottish High Court Judge Lord Cullen, who conducted the year-long inquiry into the disaster. ``The government is now acting to implement the recommendation for a new regulatory system and to ensure that the lessons of this terrible event are fully learnt and fully put into effect,''' Wakeham said. Cullen said the inquiry found a number of areas ``in which the laid-down procedure was not adhered to and unsafe practices were followed.'' He also said Occidental was ``too easily satisfied'' the platform systems were operating correctly the night of the disaster. He criticized Occidental for failing to provide proper emergency training for its staff and not paying sufficient attention to the threat of a major hazard. He said the energy department conducted inspections on Piper Alpha that were ``superficial to the point of being of little use as a test of safety.'' Glenn Shurtz, president of the Occidental Petroleum Corp. unit, rejected Cullen's criticisms, but pledged to do anything to ``make the North Sea a safer place to work.'' ``Lord Cullen's report and the profound changes it will bring to the whole oil industry will ensure that these men did not lose their lives in vain,'' Shurtz said. Occidental said it already has implemented many of Cullen's recommendations after studying the evidence at the inquiry. The U.K. Offshore Operators Association, which represents 36 gas and oil companies working in the North Sea, welcomed the report as a ``blueprint for the future.'' Director Harold Hughes said the companies already have spent $1.5 billion on improving safety. He also said giving the Health and Safety Executive responsibility for offshore safety would provide a strong, independent framework to reassure people of oil rig safety. Under the recommendations, the Health and Safety Executive would have the power to close down rigs if they do not meet new safety standards.

DOC.HEAD: Gates Sees Wider Capabilities for Future Desk-Top Computers
DOC.TEXT: Microsoft Corp. Chairman Bill Gates today outlined his vision of the futuire of personal computers in which the desktop machines will provide access to almost unlimited information. In the keynote address at the giant Comdex computer show, Gates described a future in which computers are vastly more useful and easier to use. Gates, whose company developed the most widely used operating system for personal computers, outlined new technology that will bring video, voice and handwriting recognition capability to personal computers. ``This is a formidable challenge. No single company is going to be able to do this,'' he said. Gates called for cooperation among computer hardware and software companies to bring about his vision which he calls ``information at your fingertips.'' In an amusing series of videos on a giant screen, Gates depicted how computers containing these new technologies would be used in a mythical town of Twin Points, a spoof of the TV series ``Twin Peaks.'' He showed how a deliveryman used a handheld computer that recognized handwriting to enter orders, how students at a school could use a computer much like an encyclopedia today and how a couple building a house could ``walk through'' their a three-dimensional model of their proposed home on a computer screen. Gates said these new technologies are not some science fiction dream but are all under development or are already in use. Gates' speech kicked off a weeklong Comdex show that promoters say attracted about 120,000 computer retailers, distributors and other industry people.

DOC.HEAD: New Crisis Erupts Over Agriculture in Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: The collapse of weekend talks on farm subsidies jeopardizes next month's meeting to conclude ambitious accords for liberalizing trade, a top trade official warned Monday. Arthur Dunkel, director-general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, told an emergency meeting of senior trade negotiators that major political hurdles remained. The emergency meeting was convened after talks on cutting farm subisidies broke up in disarray. Dunkel called for ``basic changes in present positions in the next hours or, at most the next days.'' ``It is not an exagggeration to say that the Brussels meeting is now in jeopardy,'' he told a special session of GATT's Trade Negotiations Committee which is overseeing the Uruguay Round of trade talks. The talks, launched in 1986, are meant to end by Dec. 7 with far-reaching agreements to reduce barriers to trade in 15 sectors. Hopes of progress in agriculture, the linchpin in the entire talks, were dashed Saturday when the United States and a group of farm exporting nations rejected a European Community proposal on cuts in farm supports. They also said offers from Japan and South Korea were inadequate. ``The EC hasn't yet demonstrated to others that it has the flexibility to negotiate a package,'' Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Rufus Yerxa said in a telephone interview. Yerxa called for ``significant movement in key areas ... including export subsidies.'' The 12-nation trading bloc submitted its proposal only last Thursday after a month's internal wrangling. It offers an overall 30 percent cut in farm supports but does not give commitments in specific areas. The cuts over 10 years would be back-dated to 1986, thus giving the EC credit for measures already taken. An EC official, who requested anonymity, described the offer as ``substantial.'' He urged Washington to adopt a ``more realistic approach'' to cuts in farm support. The United States and the 14-nation Cairns Group of farm exporters have proposed reductions of 75 percent in internal supports and import barriers. They want export subsidies to be slashed by 90 percent as these are considered the most trade distorting. The reforms would take place over 10 years, using 1991 as base-year. Japan's offer also provides for a 30 percent cut in farm supports, but makes no provision for reducing import barriers. In particular, Tokyo has showed no sign of relaxing its ban on rice imports. South Korea, another big food importer, has similarly said it is ready to negotiate reductions of up to 30 percent in farm supports while defending its restrictions on rice imports. The trade source said no date was set for the resumption of talks on agriculture as progress was now dependent on new instructions from capitals. The source spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The ball is in the Community's court,'' Yerxa said. The deadlock in the Uruguay Round is expected to be high on the agenda when U.S. President George Bush meets EC Commission President Jacques Delors and Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti in Washington on Tuesday. Also Tuesday, thousands of European farmers are expected to assemble with their livstock at GATT's Geneva headquarters to protest at what they see as attempts to cut their living standards.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Products Find New Home in Midwest
LaserPhoto ST1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to correct cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: The Midwest is thinking about earthquakes. Survival kits are popping up on store shelves and companies are hawking everything from anti-shatter window film to portable chemical toilets. ``It's incredible, the response we're getting,'' said Henry Lawson, vice president of CEPP Corp. of Los Angeles, the nation's largest emergency preparedness firm. ``We're shipping thousands of kits. We're getting lots of orders.'' The sudden upswing in business stems from a projection by New Mexico climatologist Iben Browning. He says there's a 50 percent chance of a major earthquake occurring Dec. 3 on the New Madrid Fault. The fault zone runs from Marked Tree, Ark., north to Cairo, Ill., and touches portions of Missouri, Arkansas, Tennessee, Illinois and Kentucky. On Thursday night, a minor earthquake near New Madrid, Mo., shook some homes and heightened worry. The tremor was felt in at least three states, but there were no reports of damage or injuries. Browning's projection has been roundly criticized by earthquake experts and geologists as nothing more than a random guess, but that hasn't prevented schools, businesses and residents from preparing for the big one. And companies that specialize in earthquake preparedness are getting ready for a big surge in business this week because they expect a two-part NBC mini-series about an temblor in Los Angeles will stir up more concern. Scientists and emergency officials have criticized that series, which ends tonight, for exaggerating the death and devastation a big quake would cause. CEPP Corp. is one of at least a dozen companies or groups selling various emergency kits that range in cost from $15 to $150 and include such items as thermal blankets, pouches of water and food guaranteed to last five years, flashlights and first-aid supplies. Another California company, The Emergency Lifeline of Santa Ana, is conducting 16 emergency preparedness seminars in the region at $50 a person and has mailed 10,000 catalogs to schools and businesses here. The catalog includes such items as: - ``QuakeBrace,'' which uses industrial-strength Velcro to fasten computer equipment or other expensive items to walls or desktops. - a combination radio and flashlight powered by a hand-cranked generator. - shatter-resistant window film that can prevent flying or falling glass. - a portable chemical toilet. ``I'm sure all of the companies in the emergency preparedness business have their eyes on the Midwest,'' said Kathy Gannon, a native Missourian who founded the Santa Ana company five years ago. ``There's already getting to be a glut of kits on the market.'' These products are familiar to Californians, rattled by many quakes over the years. The emergency preparedness industry has been growing quickly there since the mid-1980s, but the Midwest is really the first new market. Gannon and Lawson said they expect that what's happening in the Midwest gradually will occur in other parts of the country and around the world as more people begin preparing for natural disasters. ``The '90s have been named the decade of emergency preparedness by the United Nations,'' Gannon said.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Higher, Grains Lower
DOC.TEXT: Soybeans futures prices rallied in light trading from sharp weekend losses Monday as commercial buyers began to cash in on the oversold product. Grains were mostly lower. Soybean futures prices slipped sharply Friday, to an 8{-month low, following an Agriculture Department report that indicated a larger than expected supply of soybeans. The USDA monthly crop report, released after Thursday's close, raised the soybean production estimate 4.4 percent to 1.9 billion bushels from the October estimate of 1.82 billion. The market had expected a number near 1.84 billion. The Veterans Day holiday kept most traders on the sidelines, but some commercial buyers snapped up the low-priced commodity, said John Frazier, director of the agricultural division at Gerald Inc. ``Soybeans have been beat down for a long time, so it was expected they would go up,'' Frazier said. ``We're just biding time till tomorrow when everybody comes back.'' Grains, pressured by weak export business in the face of large world supplies, continued their slide. At the close, wheat futures prices were 2\ cents to 1} cents lower with December at $2.64 a bushel; corn futures were } cent lower to } cent higher with December at $2.30{ a bushel; oats were 3} cents to 3\ cents lower with December at $1.14\ a bushel; soybeans were 4\ cents to 3\ cents higher with November at $5.70{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Shanker Quits Channel One Board, Plans to Host Show on Companion Channel
DOC.TEXT: A leading teachers union official has quit as an advisor to the Whittle Communications' service that provides commercially-sponsored news programs for classroom viewing. Albert Shanker, head of the American Federation of Teachers, said he was resigning from the Channel One Council of Advisors because his membership on the panel left the impression he was endorsing advertising in public schools. But even as he stepped down from the 12-member advisory board, Shanker apparently agreed to serve as host of a program for teachers that will be carried on a commercial-free companion service to Channel One. William Gubbins, a group editor at Whittle Communications, said Shanker is scheduled next week to tape the first segment of a monthly series ``The World of Teaching - An Anthology'' designed for teachers. The program will be carried on a private network that Whittle is calling The Educators' Channel. That service will be delivered over the same system that carries Channel One, a daily 12-minute news show with advertising for teens in the classroom, into an estimated 5,000 schools. Shanker could not be reached Monday to comment on his plans. The AFT offices in Washington, D.C., were closed for the Veterans' Day holiday. But according to an Oct. 12 letter sent to Whittle Chairman Christopher Whittle, Shanker said he made it clear when he agreed to be on the Channel One advisory panel that ``my decision in no way constituted an endorsement either of the programming or of advertising in the public schools.'' ``In fact, I explicitly stated my role would be that of a `watch dog','' Shanker wrote. Shanker told Whittle he should have known that being on the council would ``inevitably lead to the perception that I endorsed Channel One.'' But he said that realization was not driven home until he saw his name and picture being used in Channel One promotional materials. As a result, he said he was resigning the post on the advisory council immediately and asked that his name and picture no longer be used on Channel One promotional materials. The situation was particularly sensitive for Shanker since the policymaking arm of the teachers group he heads has gone on record against showing TV commercials in the classroom. He noted the teachers' panel also ``condemned the lack of resources that put schools and districts in the position of accepting commercials in return for equipment.'' Schools that agree to show the Channel One news show with ads to their students every day are loaned a satellite dish, videocassette recorder and TV monitors for every classroom for as long as they show the program. The same satellite system is used to transmit the Channel One news show and the Educators' Channel to the schools. Tom Ingram, a spokesman for Whittle Communications in Knoxville, Tenn., said Shanker also told the company other commitments had made it impossible for him to attend any of the advisory board's meetings. He said Whittle has agreed to take Shanker's name off any new promotional materials for Channel One although the company will continue to use materials already in stock that may include his name or picture. ``While we are sorry he was not able to participate on the advisory board, we are excited about still having him on the Educators' Network,'' Ingram said.

DOC.HEAD: Economists Predict Fed Will Cut Interest Rates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, There was, with 1 graf to CORRECT that rate now stands at 7 percent, sted 6.5 percent. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve, responding to increasing signs of a recession, soon will cut interest rates in a move that should prompt banks to lower a variety of consumer and business rates, many private economists predicted Monday. The Fed's credit easing is likely to spur a one-half percentage point cut in the prime lending rate, and home mortgage rates should decline modestly as well, many analysts said. Any reduction in the prime rate, which has been stuck at 10 percent since January, would be seen as a boost to economic activity because about one-third of all consumer and business loans are tied to changes in the prime. The Fed's top policy-making body, the Federal Open Market Committee, will meet behind closed doors Tuesday to map interest rate strategy. DOC.HEAD: Price Relinquishes Day-to-Day Control at The National
DOC.TEXT: The president and publisher of The National has been relieved of day-to-day duties at the sports daily and three other top executives have been dismissed, a company spokesman confirmed Monday. An executive associated with the Mexican media and entertainment concern that is the paper's biggest shareholder has been brought in to take greater control of operations at the 9-month-old newspaper. The moves come as the paper continues to absorb heavy losses in its bid to become the United States' first national sports daily. Backers of the newspaper have run into a miserable advertising climate and skepticism about the potential audience for a daily publication devoted exclusively to sports. Peter O. Price will continue to hold the titles president and publisher but will be involved with broad, non-operational issues, a spokesman for the paper, Steve Hammond, said. He said Price would be involved, for instance, in planning for the rollout into new markets. The National is currently available in nine markets with plans to expand into three more - Baltimore-Washington, Philadelphia and Atlanta - by early 1991. Hammond said the three executives dismissed last week were Diane Morgenthaler, circulation director; Timothy Lasker, assistant publisher, and Daniel W. Correa, finance and administration director. He said none of the three has yet been replaced. He described the changes as a ``business decision,'' but declined to elaborate. Price has been unavailable for comment for the past several days. Calls placed Monday to Price and all three dismissed executives were not returned. Hammond confirmed that Jaime Davila has been brought in to assume Price's operating responsibilities at the newspaper, whose biggest shareholder is Emilio Azcarraga, the Mexican media baron. Davila is a top executive at Univisa Inc., the U.S. subsidiary of Mexico's Televisa entertainment and publishing concern that Azcarraga heads. Davila and Azcarraga were also said to be unavailable for comment. It was disclosed last week that The National will cease publishing a Sunday edition after Nov. 25 and publish only on weekdays. The paper had been publishing six days a week, Sunday through Friday, since its launch Jan. 31. Editor-in-chief Frank Deford also said last week there will be a handful of jobs cuts at the paper, which employs about 200 people, but that he was hopeful the cuts could be made through attrition rather than layoffs. The National was launched in three cities - New York, Chicago and Los Angeles - and has since begun publishing editions in San Diego, San Francisco, Detroit, Dallas, Boston and Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Outlet No Longer Seeks Buyer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for 5th graf pvs, David E., adding chairman's comments. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A broadcast company with television stations in Providence and Columbus, Ohio, said Monday it no longer will actively seek a buyer. Outlet Communications Inc., which has sold most of its broadcast properties, also reported a third-quarter net loss of $268,000, better than the $2.2 million loss reported a year ago. Revenues were $11.3 million vs. $22.5 million a year ago. Outlet said it had discontinued the services of financial adviser First Boston Corp., which had been exploring a possible sale, merger or other alternatives. David E. Henderson, Outlet's chairman, president and chief executive, said the slumping economy made a sale unlikely. The idea was to find ``a public corporate structure who would buy the stock of the company,'' he said. ``It doesn't appear in this climate that we're going to find a buyer. There's nothing in the wind to suggest our current economy is going to improve.''

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: credit conditions.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 44.80 points on Friday, climbed another 51.74 to 2,540.35. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 3 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchang, with 1,157 up, 381 down and 434 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 161.39 million shares, against 145.16 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index rose 2.90 to 174.07.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Drops $2 As War Seems More Distant
DOC.TEXT: Oil fell more than $2 per barrel on the futures market Monday, as traders decided rising supplies posed a greater immediate threat than war in the Persian Gulf. ``It's de-escalation of the war premium, the prospect that war might be delayed,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Light sweet crude tumbled $2.02 to $31.87 per barrel for December contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Contracts for delivery of crude in later months all dropped. Trading volume was lighter than usual because of Veterans Day. The drop followed a decline of $1.64 per barrel for next month delivery on Friday, when a wild rumor of an Iraqi coup depressed prices at the end of the day. Traders on Monday said war with Iraq did not seem as likely in the near future because news stories have indicated President Bush lacks the domestic and foreign support he needs to try to push Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. ``A lot of people are feeling it's not so close, so they're liquidating,'' said Christian Gohler, a broker with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. Gohler said oil futures also fell because world oil supplies have been on the rise, despite the boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. ``At the moment, the market is being extremely well supplied, because the OPEC nations and others have increased production to meet demand,'' Gohler said. Traders anticipated the next weekly statistics from the American Petroleum Institute, which are to be released Tuesday evening, would show the U.S. crude oil stockpile has increased. Hittle also pointed out that some sour crude is not being unloaded in Europe because of a lack of immediate demand. As oil took its dive Monday, so did most other energy futures traded on the exchange. Home heating oil was off 3.72 cents at 86.52 cents a gallon for December contracts, with contracts for delivery in later months all moving down as well. Unleaded gasoline fell 4.70 cents to 83.53 per gallon for December contracts, with later delivery month contracts falling. Natural gas futures were mixed, with December contracts down 1.9 cents at $2.41 per 1,000 cubic feet. Separately, the Mercantile Exchange announced steps Monday that will enable oil traders to buy futures contracts up to 36 months in advance, twice the current 18-month limit. The exchange asked regulators for the extention in August, when Iraq's invasion of Kuwait threw world oil markets into a state of chaos. ``With the growing volume and open interest in the back months of our existing contract, industry need for a long-term hedging vehicle became evident,'' the exchange's chairman, Z. Lou Guttman, said in a statement. The more distant months will become available beginning Nov. 20.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Declines in Thin Trading, Gold Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell broadly in sleepy trading on world currency markets Monday, largely on anticipation the Federal Reserve would move this week to lower interest rates. Gold prices were lower. Trading was extremely light with many bank trading floors closed in observation of Veterans Day. Lack of news indicating increased volatility in the Middle East kept investors focused on what te Fed might do after Tuesday's meeting of its policy committee. Lower interest rates generally diminish the value of the dollar. ``With the war specter off the horizon and with rumors that the Fed will drop rates by tomorrow, there's nothing positive for the dollar at the moment,'' said Michael McGuinness, vice president of Harris Trust & Savings Bank. Also driving down the dollar's value against foreign currencies was a slide in oil futures prices. Traders were discouraged by a $2.02 drop in the December contract for light, sweet crude to $31.87 per barrel. The oil drop added strength to the yen because traders read it as a favorable sign for Japan's oil-dependent economy. The dollar fell against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 128.30 yen, down from Friday's 129.70. In overnight trading in Tokyo, the dollar traded at 130.50 yen, unchanged from Friday's close, and in London, it fell to 128.80 yen. The British pound also strengthened to $1.9660 from $1.9655 late Friday. In earlier London trading, the British pound traded at $1.9627, compared with $1.9670 late Friday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's late rates included: 1.4770 German marks, down from 1.4870; 1.2468 Swiss francs, down from 1.2499; 4.9700 French francs, down from 4.9940; 1,113.00 Italian lire, down from 1119.00; 1.1664 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1683. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday: 1.4805 German marks, down from 1.4875; 1.2500 Swiss francs, up from 1.2495; 4.9755 French francs, down from 4.9940; 1.6700 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6775; 1,113.25 Italian lire, down from 1,119.50; 1,1665 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1698. Gold declined in light domestic trading. It fell $2.50 a troy ounce to $382.30 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $381.50, down $2.90. In earlier trading, gold fell in London to a late bid price of $382.25 a troy ounce, from $384.75 bid late Friday.In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $381.00, down from $385.80 bid late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold dropped 97 cents an ounce to close at $383.61 on Monday. Silver fell on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $4.19 a troy ounce, down 3.1 cents. In London, silver bullion fell to a late bid price of $4.24 a troy ounce, down from $4.25 bid late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Gold, Silver, Oils Slide as War Fears Ease

DOC.TEXT: Gold and silver futures prices, following the lead of oil futures, declined Monday on a day of light trading highlighted by a consensus that war in the Persian Gulf is not imminent. On other commodities markets, soybean futures rose; grains fell; and livestock and meat were mostly higher. Gold settled on New York's Commodity Exchange $4.10 to $2.50 lower with the contract for delivery in November at $382.30 a troy ounce; silver settled 4.4 cents to 3.1 cents lower with November at $4.19 an ounce. The two precious metals slipped during a quiet Veterans Day holiday session marked by indications that the United States will not go to war with Iraq anytime soon, said Frederick Demler, a metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in New York. ``The session came in with the Japanese markets closed today because of the enthronement (of a new emperor) and later dropped off because nobody thinks we're going to war in the foreseeable future,'' Demler said. ``Oil prices were off a little over $2 and the Dow was up over 60 points, which was a negative for precious metals,'' he said. Oil futures prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange fell after Democratic lawmakers remained adamant that President Bush must get the support of Congress before attacking Iraq or seeking to liberate Kuwait. Light sweet crude settled $2.02 to 17 cents lower with December at $31.87 a barrel; heating oil settled 3.83 cents to 1.83 cents lower with December at 86.52 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline settled 4.70 cents to 3 cents lower with December at 83.53 cents a gallon. Soybeans futures prices rallied from sharp weekend losses on the Chicago Board of Trade as commercial buyers began to cash in on the oversold product. Soybean futures prices slipped to an 8{-month low on Friday, following an Agriculture Department report that indicated a larger than expected supply of soybeans. The USDA monthly crop report, released after Thursday's close, raised the soybean production estimate 4.4 percent to 1.9 billion bushels from the October estimate of 1.82 billion. The market had expected a number near 1.84 billion. The holiday kept most traders on the sidelines, but some commercial buyers snapped up the low-priced commodity, said John Frazier, director of the agricultural division at Gerald Inc. in Chicago. ``Soybeans have been beat down for a long time, so it was expected they would go up,'' Frazier said. Grains, pressured by weak export business in the face of large world supplies, continued their slide. At the close, wheat futures prices were 2\ cents to 1} cents lower with December at $2.64 a bushel; corn futures were } cent lower to } cent higher with December at $2.30{ a bushel; oats were 3} cents to 3\ cents lower with December at $1.14\ a bushel; soybeans were 4\ cents to 3\ cents higher with November at $5.70{ a bushel. Cattle futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange continued their advance, rising on strength in the cash cattle and beef markets. Hog prices at the Merc were lifted by the perception that cash prices are near a seasonal bottom and should begin to move higher later this week as numbers decrease and demands increase. Frozen pork bellies continued higher because of low supplies of frozen stocks. Live cattle settled .05 cent lower to .35 cent higher with December at 78.65 cents a pound; feeder cattle was unchanged to .27 cent higher with November at 88.15 cents a pound; hogs were .57 cent to 1.17 cents higher with December at 53.52 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1 cent to 2 cents higher with February at 71.85 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Appoints New Head Of Trump City Project
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump Monday named a new chief for the Trump City project, a Manhattan office, retail and housing development that has been stalled for five years. Barbara Res, 41, a 10-year veteran of the Trump Organization, will take over the project. She said Trump wanted to signal that ``we are very much going forward with it and putting it in high gear.'' Res oversaw the construction of Trump Tower and is directing the $1 billion redevelopment of the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles. Trump bought the land for the $5 billion project on Manhattan's West Side in 1985 for $100 million. Trump plans the world's largest building, luxury apartments and a shopping mall for the 76-acre parcel, an unused rail yard. The plan has been held up, in part, by activists who oppose the project for environmental reasons. Res replaces Anthony B. Giledman, 48, who announced last week he was leaving Trump to become chief executive of New York-based Amrep Corp., which builds moderate-priced housing in New Mexico and Florida. Res said in a telephone interview she can't predict when the project might get started. ``Unfortunately, we've had this project around a long time. I could have given you a date three years ago and we'd be past it already,'' she said. Stephen Bollenbach, Trump Organization's chief financial officer, said Monday there aren't any payments currently due on the loan for the property. The Trump Organization is supposed to pay $47 million in interest Nov. 15 on $675 worth of bonds sold to finance the Taj Mahal hotel and casino in Atlantic City, N.J. Last month, Trump unveiled a financial restructuring proposal, and warned bondholders that the Taj Mahal might be forced into bankruptcy court if the plan is turned down. The restructuring would give bondholders a nearly 20 percent equity stake in the billion-dollar Taj Mahal in return for changes in the terms of the junk bonds. The plan called for the interest rate on the bonds to be lowered to 9 percent from their current 14 percent. It also calls for the Nov. 15 payment to be met by issuing additional bonds. Wilbur Ross, a bondholder representative, rejected the plan, saying the offer was too low.

DOC.HEAD: Microsoft's Gates Unveils His Vision of Computing's Future
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Microsoft Corp. Chairman Bill Gates unveiled his grand vision of the future of personal computing Monday, an era in which desktop and handheld machines will provide a window to vast amounts of information. In the keynote address at the giant Comdex computer show, Gates described a future in which computers are much more useful and easier to use. Gates, whose company developed the most widely used operating system for personal computers, outlined new technologies that will bring video, voice and handwriting recognition capabilities to personal computers. ``This is a formidable challenge. No single company is going to be able to do this,'' he said. Gates called for cooperation among computer hardware and software companies to bring about his vision, which he calls ``information at your fingertips.'' In an amusing series of videos on a giant screen, Gates depicted how computers containing these new technologies would be used in the mythical town of Twin Points, a spoof of the TV series ``Twin Peaks.'' In one example, he showed how a deliveryman for Twin Points Bakery would use a book-sized handheld computer that recognized handwriting to enter orders at a grocery store. Using a special pen, or stylus, the deliveryman wrote in the orders for various items on the computer screen. The computer verified the order by printing the quantity. When the grocer balked at ordering a certain amount of one item, the deliveryman used the screen to display a bar chart showing how much of that item sold at the store in a certain period. When the grocer also ordered a new display rack, the computer flashed a warning that he was over his credit limit with the bakery. But through a cellular phone device inside the machine, the computer contacted a central computer at the bakery, which then authorized the display rack but required the grocer to ``sign'' for it on the handheld computer screen, using the stylus. In another video, Gates showed how a student using a computerized encyclopedia could do a report on the state of Washington, where Microsoft is based. A ``page'' of the encyclopedia depicting facts about Washington showed a picture of the state bird. Beside the bird was a small picture, called an icon, of several musical notes. When the student moved an on-screen arrow to the icon, and then pushed a button on a device called a mouse, the computer played a short audio passage of the bird's song stored in its memory. The encyclopedia also gave a chart of the state's leading industries, software among them. When the arrow was placed on ``Microsoft,'' a small picture of the company's offices came on the screen. When the arrow was moved to the picture and the mouse button pushed, the computer played a video of several of the company's employees. Gates also showed a video of a couple designing a house. When they wanted to visualize various layouts, their architect allowed them to ``walk through'' a three-dimensional model of their proposed home on a computer screen. The couple also could see on the screen how various color schemes would look, and when they wanted to look at appliances, the architect called up a video advertisement from an oven manufacturer. Gates, 35, said these new technologies are not some science fiction dream, but are under development or already in use. In fact, such combinations of text, graphics, sound and videos - called multimedia computing - are among the hot topics at this year's Comdex. One of the keys to Gates' vision is tying together the technologies of handwriting recognition, computerized video, fax, cellular phones, computing networks and vast data bases in one seamless hardware and software package. But, he said, several obstacles need to be removed before his scheme becomes reality. One is that personal computers are too hard to use. Another, he said, is that ``people have a very narrow view of how the PC should be used.'' Gates' speech kicked off a weeklong Comdex show that promoters say has attracted about 120,000 computer retailers, distributors and others in the industry.

DOC.TEXT: Falling oil prices and hopes for lower interest rates provided the inspiration as the stock market staged a strong advance Monday, extending the rally it began late last week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 44.80 points on Friday, climbed another 51.74 to 2,540.35. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,163 up, 381 down and 433 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 161.39 million shares, against 145.16 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 199.64 million shares. The price of crude oil for December delivery dropped more than $2 a barrel, to about $31.75 a barrel, in Monday's trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Beyond that immediate stimulus, analysts said traders were encouraged by increasing talk of actions soon by the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy. Recent economic evidence has spotlighted signs of economic weakness, along with some indications that inflationary pressures might be easing. That trend is widely presumed in the financial world to be giving the Fed more leeway to loosen credit conditions. Bank and other financial issues extended their recent upswing, which has been spraked by hopes that lower interest rates would ease financial strains and shore up the real-estate markets. In the banking group, J.P. Morgan gained 2 to 42{; BankAmerica 1{ to 23}; Citicorp 1 to 13\; Chase Manhattan | to 11, and Chemical Banking ~ to 12. Elsewhere among financial stocks, Federal National Mortgage rose 1{ to 32; Kemper Corp. 2] to 20\; Great Western Financial 1[ to 11\; Federal Home Loan Mortgage 1| to 39~, and American Express 2 to 21|. Point-plus gainers among the blue-chip industrials included International Business Machines, up 2} at 113; General Electric, up 1| at 55]; General Motors, up 1[ at 38}; McDonald's, up 1{ at 28}, and Procter & Gamble, up 1] at 82. Pan Am Corp. rose \ to 1~ in active trading following the weekend news of a conditional bid for Pan Am by Carl Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines. Other airline issues also fared well. UAL climbed 4| to 100\; Delta Air Lines 2 to 57], and AMR 1~ to 48[. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $52.63 billion, or 1.80 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 2.90 to 174.07. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 6.24 to 373.35, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 5.74 at 319.48. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market jumped 9.51 to 351.46. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 294.78, up 3.75.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators: Milken May Have Made $1 Billion More
DOC.TEXT: Fallen junk bond king Michael R. Milken may have made an additional $1 billion during the 1980s from limited partnerships formed with other Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. employees, congressional investigators claim. Confirming earlier published reports, a House staffer said Monday that information derived from the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, indicates Milken formed some 30 partnerships with other employees of the now-bankrupt securities firm. Those partnerships paid out as much as $2 billion between 1981 and 1989, the House staffer said. There was no indication how much of that amount was actually profit, however and the amounts attributed to Milken and other individuals were only estimates. The House source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also said Monday that convicted stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky testified behind closed doors to the oversight subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee about his dealings with Milken. The oversight subcommittee has been investigating hundreds of Milken-created Drexel partnerships for several years, but no evidence of illegal activity has been presented. Drexel ended the practice shortly after it came to light two years ago, however. A spokesman for Milken declined comment on the matter. But a source close to the Milken camp noted the information about the huge payouts was disclosed shortly before the former head of Drexel's junk bond department is to be sentenced in a massive Wall Street fraud case. Milken pleaded guilty in April to six securities-related felony charges and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties. He faces up to 28 years in prison when he is sentencd by a federal judge in New York, who is expected to set a sentencing date soon. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the oversight subcommittee, wants Milken to testify - after his sentencing - about trading accounts owned by hundreds of limited partnerships he formed with Drexel co-workers, family members and friends. The partnerships bought up significant percentages of hot junk bond issues before they were made available to the general public. Critics say the activity drove up the price of those issues at the expense of Drexel customers. Federal prosecutors revealed that Drexel paid Milken, mastermind of the firm's rise to prominence in the high-yield, high-risk junk bond business, a total of $1.1 billion between 1984 and 1987, including $550 in the final year. That $550 million paycheck put him the Guiness Book of World Records. The information stemming from the subcommittee probe, while not proof of illegal activity, suggests the magnitude of the deals and how lucrative they could be, said the subcommitte source. The information consisted of a list of 30 limited partnerships and the total amount each distributed to investors during the 1980s. But the one-page list does not specify individual investors nor does it indicate how much of the payouts were profit over and above the initial investment. The subcommittee source said investigators knew from court documents what percentage major players in the Drexel scandal held in the partnerships. Using that information combined with the totals generated by the GAO probe ``you worked backwards'' to estimate amounts received by individuals, said the source. ``It gives you a pretty good road map in terms of who was involved in what,'' he said. Milken, who invoked his Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination when called to testify before the subcommittee two years ago, is expected to testify after he is sentenced. Boesky, who settled a massive insider trading case by pleading guilty to one felony count and agreeing to pay $100 million in penalties, has been interviewed extensively by subcommittee staffers and testified for about three hours before the subcommittee in a closed-door hearing in August, the source said.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Regulator Says He'll Ease Way for Conversions to Banks
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 6th graf pvs: ``Of the,'' with one graf bgng: ``The government,'' to CLARIFY that all 300 rescued thrifts NOT acquired by banks. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan regulator Timothy Ryan told thrift executives Monday that his agency will make it easier for them to convert their institutions into commercial banks. The move, based on a legal opinion by Office of Thrift Supervision Chief Counsel Harris Weinstein, could hasten the end of S&Ls as a separate financial industry. Ryan, who is director of the thrift office, told the 98th annual convention of the U.S. League of Savings Institutions that he believed financial institutions could still earn a good profit as housing lenders. ``The ranks of the most successful thrifts ... are dominated by those who stuck to the home mortgage business,'' he said. But, he said, S&Ls should also be free, as contemplated under last year's S&L bailout law, to move into commercial banking if they desired. The government so far has seized more than 500 failed S&Ls, disposing of 300 of them. Most of the 300 have been turned over to banks. Also, so far the thrift office has approved 22 applications from healthy thrifts wanting to become banks. Another 22 applications are pending. However, he said he remained ``deeply troubled'' by S&Ls becoming state savings banks. These institutions are similar to S&Ls, but have fewer restrictions on how they may invest their deposits. Last year's law, for instance, requires S&Ls, but not state savings banks, to devote 70 percent of their assets to home mortgage loans. After delivering a speech to some 1,300 S&L executives, Ryan told reporters that he was less concerned with the housing requirement, which also can be circumvented by conversion to either a commercial bank or a savings bank, and most concerned with S&Ls using conversion to evade bans on buying junk bonds and investing directly in speculative real estate development projects. ``We're not going to put up with that kind of behavior,'' he said. He noted that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. was working on regulations to extend the reforms of last year's law to savings banks. In that case, he said he would not oppose S&Ls converting to savings banks. Frederick L. Webber, president of the league, said most S&Ls want to convert, not to evade reforms, but to shed themselves of expensive examination fees charged by the thrift office. As S&Ls fail or convert to banks, fewer institutions remain behind to support the regulatory apparatus. Ryan drew cheers when he told S&L executives he would cut the assessments they pay. He said he has already cut spending from a planned $330 million this year to $280 million and reduced his staff from 3,500 to 3,000. Despite the reductions, he said he would increase the number of examiners in the field. He said his goal was to examine large institutions and those in poor or average condition every year and others every 18 months. Ryan also drew cheers when he said he favored simplifying the regulatory apparatus so that only one agency regulates financial institutions. Many S&L executives have concluded that they would rather be supervised by banking regulators. On another matter, Ryan said he was discussing with the Resolution Trust Corp., which dismantles failed thrifts, a plan to delay seizing some virtually insolvent institutions. The RTC has so far taken over more than 500 failed thrifts, leaving about 2,400 still operating privately. Of those, the agency considers roughly 170 all but certain to fail. But, because Congress adjourned without providing the RTC with additional rescue money, Ryan said his agency was considering placing some of the 170 into a supervisory management program provided they had little or no continuing losses and stable, competent management. When money became available later, these S&Ls will be rescued without being transferred to the RTC, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Time Warner Loses MCA Records Distribution Deal to German Media Giant
DOC.TEXT: MCA Inc. said Monday that its music unit will shift its $100 million overseas distribution business from Time Warner Inc. to Germany's Bertelsmann Music Group. The deal hands a big chunk of business to Bertelsmann at a time when MCA officials are discussing a buyout for as much as $8 billion by Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. It's another example of how entwined the U.S. entertainment business has become with overseas companies. As worldwide music sales approach $20 billion a year, with only a third of that domestic, four of the nation's six major record concerns are now foreign-owned. Bertelsmann Music Group, part of the giant media company Bertelsmann AG, operates in 30 countries and owns labels including RCA, Arista, Zoo and Ariola. The parent company has indicated it will spend $4 billion on entertainment deals over the next three years. The new three-year deal calls for Bertelsmann to give MCA $37 million a year in promotion, marketing and other support. Officials of both companies said an important part of the partnership will be developing new talent. MCA and Bertelsmann said their agreement covers the distribution and licensing of MCA, Geffen and GRP records. The licensing agreement is worldwide except for North America, the United Kingdom, Germany and Japan. MCA has its own company in the UK and recently announced it was forming a new record company in Japan in a joint venture with Japanese interests. MCA said it also intends to establish its own record company in Germany, the world's third largest record-selling territory behind North America and Japan with about 9 percent of worldwide record sales. Bertelsmann Music Group will be the distributor for that company as well as for MCA's existing company in the United Kingdom, MCA said. MCA's distribution agreement with Time Warner's Warner Music International expires April 1. Geffen Records had its own deal with Warner Music International, and will be distributed by Bertelsmann beginning Jan. 1.

DOC.HEAD: TWA Offer For Pan Am Probably Won't Fly, Analysts Say
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines Inc.'s offer to merge with Pan Am Corp. raises new questions about troubled Pan Am's immediate future, but analysts said Monday they doubted the deal would fly. ``As far as I can see, it's sort of hazy at the moment,'' said Thomas Canning, at Standard & Poor's. ``We've got to wait for the reaction from Pan Am. For their fiduciary duties, they have to consider it.'' Analysts said Pan Am will probably proceed with plans to sell prized London routes to UAL Corp. in a $400 million deal that also includes a cooperative marketing agreement. The airlines would coordinate flights and feed passengers to each other. Pan Am said that the UAL deal, which is supposed to be completed by Wednesday, was its current ``focus.'' But Pan Am refused to comment on the merits or status of TWA's offer, made Friday in a letter from TWA Chairman Carl C. Icahn to Pan Am Chairman Thomas G. Plaskett. ``We are not going to comment on whether or not we have had any communications with Mr. Icahn since we have received his letter,'' Pan Am spokeswoman Pamela Hanlon said. She said, however, that Pan Am understood Icahn's offer would only come into play if the agreement with UAL is not completed Wednesday. ``It is a binding agreement and (the TWA offer) certainly does not change that agreement,'' Hanlon said. But the UAL deal does not prevent Pan Am from discussing a merger, she said. UAL refused to say whether it believes the TWA offer jeopardizes its pact with Pan Am. ``Talk to Pan Am,'' spokesman Joe Hopkins said. Icahn proposed offering about $150 million in cash and securities with a face value of $300 million for Pan Am. Since the cash value of the securities would vary, analysts were uncertain whether Pan Am stockholders would gain money or lose money through the transaction. Pan Am stock rose \ to 1~ in active trading Monday. Pan Am and TWA are the only U.S. carriers to fly into London's Heathrow Airport, the most desirable destination in the city that is considered the gateway to Europe. Analysts predicted a TWA-Pan AM merger would face regulatory troubles because the government would not want to see all of those routes fall into the same corporate hands. AMR Corp., the parent of American Airlines, has said it would pay in excess of $500 million for the London routes, but Pan Am said it was not interested in merely selling the routes. Pan Am said its marketing arrangement with UAL would help build up its Latin American service with flights connecting through Miami. Analysts said a TWA-Pan Am merger would likely benefit both carriers, considered among the weakest in an industry that has been hit hard by rising fuel costs and sluggish demand for travel. ``It would make for a stronger carrier. They would have the strength of the Atlantic, with the Pan Am Latin American routes,'' Canning said. Even if no serious merger talks are held, the publicity surrounding Icahn's offer has probably helped both both airlines, according to an analyst with said Icahn might have other motives. ``What you see isn't what you get with this guy,'' said Kevin Murphy, of Morgan Stanley. ``If he can prevent United Airlines from going into London, that would prevent a more formidable carrier from going into Heathrow,'' Murphy said. ``By creating more market forces for international assets and routes, that can only come back and help him, should he also decide to sell assets.'' Without a merger with Pan Am, TWA will be left in a position where it either needs to buy assets, such as the Atlanta hub and Miami overhaul base of Eastern Airlines that it has expressed an interest in, or sell its own assets, analysts said. The head of the TWA branch of the Air Line Pilots Association, Kent Scott, agreed. ``I think this is Icahn's way of stirring up interest in TWA and saying `Hey, I want to do a deal, whether it's buy, sell or whatever,''' Scott said. Analysts say it was too soon to say whether the TWA offer could spark any reshuffling that would involve more than two airlines. They doubted the deal could enable Pan Am to seek better terms from UAL, because the important aspects of that deal had already been settled.

DOC.HEAD: Volvo Chairman Promises Investigation Of Misleading Ad
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of AB Volvo Monday promised an investigation of a phony television advertisement that portrayed a Volvo withstanding the attempts of a ``monster truck'' to crush it. Volvo Chairman Pehr G. Gyllenhammar said in a statement that he would show customers, suppliers and employees that ``I will never tolerate any kind of misconduct ... that will damage Volvo's name and excellent reputation.'' The investigation would try to clarify how the ad came about and identify those resonsible, he said. Volvo pulled the ads last week after admitting that the car in the ad had been reinforced. The ads had been challenged by the Texas attorney general. Volvo agreed to make no unproven claims, run corrective newspaper ads and pay Texas $316,250 in investigative costs. The ad, filmed in Austin, appears to show a Volvo as the only car left relatively intact after the truck runs over a line of autos. ``It represents an insult to our company and what we represent and an insult against all Volvo owners,'' Gyllenhammr said.

DOC.HEAD: Supervisors Reject Chevron Request for Oil Tankers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 5th graf pvs, to UPDATE with Chevron comment.
DOC.TEXT: County supervisors Monday rejected Chevron USA's bid to carry oil from a rich offshore field by tanker instead of pipeline. Chevron says it is cheaper to send oil by tanker to refineries in Los Angeles, 150 miles south. A pipeline is considered the more expensive but environmentally safer alternative. Tom Rogers, chairman of the supervisors, said Chevron was only being held to ``tough'' standards it agreed to follow when a permit was granted for the offshore project some five years ago. ``There is a pipeline available,'' Rogers said. ``The symbolism is not local government holding up the oil companies. If the oil companies and local government work something out, what is the commitment of oil companies to adhere to those agreements?'' The supervisors voted 4-1 after a daylong hearing. Chevron responded angrily, saying Santa Barbara officials are not interested in reaching a rational solution. The 2-year-old dispute has idled a $2.5 billion oil project that includes three offshore oil rigs capable of producing up to 100,000 barrels of crude oil each day. The three rigs, Hidalgo, Harvest and Hermosa, already are in place 10 miles off of Santa Barbara. A processing plant and other facilities are nearby at Point Arguello. Chevron USA is lead partner on the project. The firm sought a temporary, four-year shipping permit. It was expected Chevron would agree to pursue a pipeline operation if granted the permit, but Rogers said the issue was not raised. Rogers said existing pipelines could handle almost all of the crude produced by the offshore field, sending the oil down to Los Angeles and up to Northern California for processing. ``They don't own pipelines, they own tankers, and that would maximize profit,'' Rogers said.
